fields.verse: To him who is able to keep you from stumbling and to present you before his glorious presence without fault and with great joy— to the only God our Savior be glory, majesty, power and authority, through Jesus Christ our Lord, before all ages, now and forevermore! Amen. - Jude 1:24‭-‬25 (NIV)
fields.content: A benediction seems to be an appropriate way to end this series. It began over two years ago and there are over 700 devotionals in the collection. There was a two-fold purpose behind the exercise. 1) I had grown increasingly aware that my morning time with God had gotten into a rut. I needed a fresh way to breathe life into my quiet time. 2) I wanted to leave a legacy for our children and grandchildren of how I interacted with God. Along the way, the list of recipients grew. It's my prayer that these short devotionals were of benefit to you. Thank you for letting me be a small part of your life. Remember, He loves you with an everlasting love. Keep looking up.

fields.verse: Brothers and sisters, I do not consider myself yet to have taken hold of it. But one thing I do: Forgetting what is behind and straining toward what is ahead, I press on toward the goal to win the prize for which God has called me heavenward in Christ Jesus. - Philippians 3:13‭-‬14 (NIV)
fields.content: It's okay to visit the past, but you don't want to live there. Whether good or bad, time tends to color our memories in shades of nostalgia, or sorrow. Visit just long enough to smile but not so long as to relive pain. There is a day ahead to look forward to. Each moment, minute, and hour, is a step in the marathon of life. Looking back almost always slows us down. We run faster, and straighter when we drop the burdens of the past. Fix our eyes on the finish line ahead; there is a prize waiting. When the finish line is crossed, the pain of the past will be resolved and dissolved; yesterday's joy will be extended and expanded into eternity.

fields.verse: . . .being confident of this, that he who began a good work in you will carry it on to completion until the day of Christ Jesus. - Philippians 1:6 (NIV)
fields.content: We are a work in progress. Like a lump of clay on a turning wheel, little by little we are taking shape. The Potter has determined what the final product will look like and the clay cooperates with the skilled hands that shape it. The value of the clay is enhanced with each turn of the wheel. Observers wonder if the task will be completed, when suddenly the Potter turns the clay in on itself and starts the process all over again. After carefully molding it into shape, different colored glazes are applied and the clay is inserted into the oven. The finished product will be perfect for its intended use. Look around at the various vessels he is creating. Regardless of the stage they are in the Potter has an intention for each work in progress. He will work on the clay until it fits his purpose and won't stop until it is done. We can place our confidence in him for he is faithful. Let's go for another spin today.

fields.verse: And this is my prayer: that your love may abound more and more in knowledge and depth of insight,  Philippians 1:9 (NIV)
fields.content: It is important to know the content of the Bible. If the Holy Spirit is to "bring all things to your remembrance, whatsoever I have said unto you" (John 14:26), then it's important that what he said be in our hearts and minds to begin with. Alongside the information in Scripture, we must strive to know what it means. Knowledge + insight = abundant love. The facts of Scripture might help us in a game of Jeopardy or Trivial Pursuit, but the devoted believer digs beneath the surface looking to find wisdom for the rugged journey of life. Read for breadth, study for depth.

fields.verse: And pray in the Spirit on all occasions with all kinds of prayers and requests. With this in mind, be alert and always keep on praying for all the Lord’s people. Pray also for me, that whenever I speak, words may be given me so that I will fearlessly make known the mystery of the gospel, for which I am an ambassador in chains. Pray that I may declare it fearlessly, as I should. - Ephesians 6:18‭-‬20 (NIV)
fields.content: When in a conversation with people, whether they are believers or not, and the conversation turns to pointing out the faults of the church or Christians, look for an opportunity to shift the conversation. Ask the question, "Without referencing the church and believers, what has Jesus ever done or said that you take issue with?" Most people would find it difficult to respond. This provides a chance to speak to them about the mystery of the gospel. The shortcoming of unbelievers, believers, the church, and the world in general, is precisely why Jesus came. It is a mystery that God would want to save the muddled mess that continually rejects his grace. And yet, here we are. The Apostle asks for prayer-- prayer in the Spirit. Prayer is essential for witness on the giving and receiving end; it opens our eyes and leaves us in awe at the mystery of God's loves for us, regardless of which side of the Cross we are on. He offers saving grace to one, and sanctifying grace to the other. This is the mystery of the message and the message of the mystery. It is always the need of the hour and must be delivered boldly, and unapologetically.

fields.verse: Put on the full armor of God, so that you can take your stand against the devil’s schemes. - Ephesians 6:11 (NIV)
fields.content: Despite the fact that weapons of war are deadlier and more sophisticated than ever, U.S. casualties in war are relatively low. Every death is to be honored and every casualty is a profound and priceless loss. One day we will live in a time and place where wars will cease, but until then we must be prepared for war. On the spiritual battlefield where we fight for souls, God has provided offensive weapons to fight, and defensive armor to minimize casualties. Defensive armor has been credited for many soldiers coming back home alive. Be vigilant, get dressed, march forward to conquer. Stand against the enemy when he tries to reclaim the territory we've taken. We'll need all the help He can give, and he has provided all we need. The victory is ours, because the battle is the Lord's.

fields.verse: Finally, be strong in the Lord and in his mighty power. - Ephesians 6:10 (NIV)
fields.content: Bluto would pummel Popeye until Popeye could "stands no more." He would pull out a can of spinach and proceed to settle the score. When the dust would settle, Popeye would pull out his corncob pipe and declare; "I'm strong to the finish, cause I eats my spinach. I'm Popeye the sailor man." No matter the beating we take in life, even when our enemy walks away as we lay in a crumpled heap, it isn't over. Our strength and hope comes from an outside source. When we access and appropriate the power of God, there is no obstacle or enemy that can stand in our way. It becomes our turn to inflict damage on the enemy. We can't do it in our strength. God is our spinach for the finish. Toot toot! (This one was written for the grandchildren.)

fields.verse: Awake, Lord! Why do you sleep? Rouse yourself! Do not reject us forever. Why do you hide your face and forget our misery and oppression? - Psalms 44:23‭-‬24 (NIV)
fields.content: In an attempt to be encouraging, a minister counseled a parishioner to hold on during the wait for a prayer to be answered. It may take weeks, years, decades, but when it comes the answer will be sweeter, the wait would be worth it, and faith would be stronger. There is a flip side to this counsel that doesn't fit the script. Some have petitioned God for a long time and in the process have grown weary, discouraged, and disillusioned. Some have given up praying and have a noticeable limp in their walk of faith. They resign themselves to a faint hope that the issue will only be resolved on the other side of the Great Divide. So, we plod on hanging by a thread, the bittersweet reminder that His thoughts are not our thoughts, and his ways are not our ways (Isaiah 55:8-9), and that will have to suffice. Let's face it, sometimes God is hard to understand.

fields.verse: Many, Lord my God, are the wonders you have done, the things you planned for us. None can compare with you; were I to speak and tell of your deeds, they would be too many to declare. - Psalms 40:5 (NIV)
fields.content: "Count your blessings, name them one by one;  Count your blessings, see what God hath done;  Count your blessings, name them one by one,  And it will surprise you what the Lord hath done." -- Johnson Oatman, 1897There is not enough time, or room on a page, to record what all God has done for us, but every once in a while we should give it a try. "You shall have no other gods before me." (Exodus 20:3) No other god is necessary, because no other can compare. He is all we could want, and all we need. His blessings attest to his love and commitment to us. We are blessed beyond measure. Count your blessings today; prepare to be surprised.

fields.verse: I waited patiently for the Lord; he turned to me and heard my cry. He lifted me out of the slimy pit, out of the mud and mire; he set my feet on a rock and gave me a firm place to stand. He put a new song in my mouth, a hymn of praise to our God. Many will see and fear the Lord and put their trust in him. - Psalms 40:1‭-‬3 (NIV)
fields.content: Many of the Psalms are written in the first person; they are intimately personal. Although there is room for liturgy and ritual to connect the masses, a personal relationship with God is the glue that holds the people of God together. When we pray for our needs, expect the enemy to accuse us of being selfish because we pray in the face of a world that has great and overwhelming challenges. Faith is reciprocal. Our answered prayers inspire us, and do double duty as a testimony and faith builder for others. We can more optimistically pray and believe God for answers when we have checked some of the things off our list where he has come through. Pray and wait patiently. . .make it personal.

fields.verse: You have made my days a mere handbreadth; the span of my years is as nothing before you. Everyone is but a breath, even those who seem secure. - Psalms 39:5 (NIV)
fields.content: There is a multi-billion dollar industry committed to making us look and feel young, but every facelift has a shelf life, most diets are unsustainable, and exercise slows, but does not stop, the aging process. Someone has said that our life is extended by the exact number of minutes or hours we spent exercising. We can endure the pain in 30 minute increments, or save it all up for the end. There is no need to discourage anyone from being fit or looking good, but keep in mind, our best days are beyond our short lifetime on earth. Some of the most comforting words, on this side of the Great Divide, come at the end of a gratifying meal when we are told to hang onto our fork. Why wait? Life is short; eat dessert first and work it off later. . .maybe after a nap.

fields.verse: “Show me, Lord, my life’s end and the number of my days; let me know how fleeting my life is. - Psalms 39:4 (NIV)
fields.content: What would our lives be Iike if, on the day we were born, we were issued a life card and the expiration date was already written on it? How would that shape our decisions? Some might decide to "eat, drink, and be merry", indulging in all the pleasures the world has to offer. Others might knuckle down and live each day with purpose in order to leave a legacy of a life well lived. We all have an appointment to meet with God when this life is over. Because we don't know our expiration date, and we are not promised another breath or day, our choice of how to live is constantly before us. When we speak to the aged, they often remark on how fast time flies. What do we want said about us when our life card expires? Pursue the righteousness, peace, and joy of the kingdom of God. Jesus promised us life, and more, abundantly. Never forget; life is fleeting, eternal life is forever.

fields.verse: Therefore, in the present case I advise you: Leave these men alone! Let them go! For if their purpose or activity is of human origin, it will fail. But if it is from God, you will not be able to stop these men; you will only find yourselves fighting against God.” - Acts 5:38-39 (NIV)
fields.content: As I am writing this, students at Asbury University in Wilmore, Kentucky are experiencing a spontaneous nonstop move of prayer and worship for the last 7 days. It has caught attention and people from all over the world are starting to show up, to see for themselves, what is going on. It has even been mentioned on the news, and is all over social media. And right on cue, the critics are descending and condescending. What is happening doesn't fit their idea of what a move of God looks like  But, it is never a good idea to criticize, marginalize, or neutralize that which is not understood. What harm can come from a couple of thousand young people, worshiping and praying in a small town in Kentucky? Gamaliel's advice in Acts 5 seems to be the order of the day. Let them be, lest we find ourselves fighting against what God is trying to do. The worst that can happen is that several thousand people will have a sweet memory of their experience worshiping God. The best that can happen is that the movement will spread and we'll have a genuine move of God like the First and Second Great Awakenings, Azusa Revival of the early 20th century, or the Jesus revolution of the 1970s. Let's watch and pray. Something is happening!

fields.verse: I have a message from God in my heart concerning the sinfulness of the wicked: There is no fear of God before their eyes. In their own eyes they flatter themselves too much to detect or hate their sin. - Psalms 36:1‭-‬2 (NIV)
fields.content: Self-righteousness and virtue signaling are twins in the family of deception. Few things are more sinister than self-deceit, and it often comes disguised as sincerity. Demosthenes, the 4th century Greek orator and statesman said, ". . .what every man wishes, that he also believes to be true." The ideals of the deceived are forged into selfmade moral codes of belief and behavior embedded in a foundation of self-sufficiency. The nature of deception is that they don't know they are being deceived. They are willing to die for what they have settled to be their truth, even in the face of new understanding. In our time, we are seeing the manifestation of a generation overfed on praise without substance. They fail to see their need of a Savior because they have been deceived into believing they are good enough and don't need one. They have no fear of God because he has been emasculated or dismissed. The overinflated sense of their own goodness deprives them of the need for repentance and receiving the gift of eternal life. This will not end well, except that God is still at work. As long as there is breath there is hope. Believers get to participate in exposing the lies and declaring the truth. It is the Truth that will expose the deception and set them free.

fields.verse: I sought the Lord, and he answered me; he delivered me from all my fears. Those who look to him are radiant; their faces are never covered with shame. This poor man called, and the Lord heard him; he saved him out of all his troubles. - Psalms 34:4‭-‬6 (NIV)
fields.content: "There is no illusion greater than fear" - Lao TzuAfter years of study, scientists have concluded that people are inherently born with only two fears - fear of loud noises, and fear of falling. All other fears are learned or imagined. Whether real or imagined, fear can be crippling. Fear of the unknown is a unique challenge. It thwarts us from pursuing our dreams and aspirations, by imaging the worst case scenario that may happen, no matter how unlikely. As a result, we may be left wondering, what might have been. It is interesting because we often imagine that what might have been would have resulted in us being successful, happy, and fulfilled. Overcoming our fears opens a panoply of possibilities, but we need help. The Psalmist sought the Lord; he called and the Lord heard him, and saved him out of his troubles. The phrase "fear not" and variations of it, is found 365 times in the Bible. That's once for every day of the year. When we call upon the Lord, he unshackles us from our fears. He may very well show us that we had nothing to fear but fear itself.

fields.verse: Glorify the Lord with me; let us exalt his name together. - Psalms 34:3 (NIV)
fields.content: Nashville is Music City. Aspiring musicians and singers, many of them Christians, move to Nashville hoping to be discovered, looking to launch their careers. One of the treats those who live there experience, is the Sunday morning church service. Whether small or large, every congregation has its share of musicians and singers. The singing is phenomenal as 3 and 4 part unrehearsed harmonies seamlessly fill the air. Gifted musicians play on a level most of us can never achieve. Worshippers are pulled into a common, unified experience. God delights in each of us as individuals, but there is something to be said about collective worship. Interspersed in these worshipping congregations are the everyday people. They are swept up in the current of praise, blending in and adding their layer of texture and color to the songs. A Nashville church service is a glimpse of what the music in heaven might sound like. Join the choir of the redeemed. You can sing alone in your workshop, your car, or in the shower, but make it a practice to "exalt his name together."

fields.verse: Wait for the Lord; be strong and take heart and wait for the Lord.  Psalms 27:14 (NIV)
fields.content: "Your call is important to us, please hold and listen to this boring music until someone is available to assist you." Let's be honest waiting is boring. It's been estimated that on average people spend 6 months of their lives waiting. For many of us, waiting and impatience go hand in hand. Since waiting is inevitable, it's a good idea to find something profitable to do while we wait. Cell phones and iPads have a variety of options to keep us occupied, but sometimes we miss the most important part of pauses in our day. It pays to occasionally put down the electronic devices to focus for a period of time on hearing the voice of the Lord.  When we dial up the Lord, he doesn't put us on hold listening to harp music, he strengthens our hearts, sharpens our minds, and steels our resolve. "They that wait on the Lord, shall renew their strength. . ." (Isaiah 40:31)

fields.verse: In you, Lord my God, I put my trust. - Psalms 25:1 (NIV)
fields.content: As the sun begins to peek over the horizon, it casts a golden hue over the beginning of a new day. Neighbors can be heard starting their vehicles as they prepare to go to work. The birds are overhead cheering them on. Faith will be on display at every turn: when we turn the key, ease onto the highway, bite into the drive-thru breakfast sandwich, and sit in the chair of our workstations; we trust that all will work as intended. So it is with our God. We open our eyes to a new day. He was gracious to extend to us another opportunity to get it done, whatever it is. So we best begin by saying a little prayer; "In you, Lord my God, I put my trust."

fields.verse: All the ends of the earth will remember and turn to the Lord, and all the families of the nations will bow down before him, for dominion belongs to the Lord and he rules over the nations. - Psalms 22:27‭-‬28 (NIV)
fields.content: Living in a time when the influence of God's people is deteriorating can make us wonder how much worse it can get before it gets better. The key word in this passage is "remember." We can only remember that which we once knew. So we pour ourselves into sharing and living the Gospel. Our generation will have its witness in the midst of the encroaching darkness. Fear not; when it seems the most hopeless, they will remember what they saw and heard, and turn to the Lord in search of peace, joy, and contentment. The revival will extend to the nations of the world. Keep believing.

fields.verse: In you our ancestors put their trust; they trusted and you delivered them. To you they cried out and were saved; in you they trusted and were not put to shame. - Psalms 22:4‭-‬5 (NIV)
fields.content: Ever since man had life breathed into him in the Garden, God has revealed himself to his creation. To each generation is given the awesome responsibility of making God known to its progeny. The line is to be uninterrupted, the circle unbroken. There have been dark periods in history, but through the efforts of a faithful few, the light managed to pierce the darkness of its time. "In him was life, and that life was the light of all mankind, and the darkness has not overcome it. The light shines in the darkness." (John 1:4-5) Those who came before us made it possible for those we will send ahead. We must make it our priority to tell our children, to tell their children's children, that we serve a faithful God good for our time, their time, and for all time.

fields.verse: May these words of my mouth and this meditation of my heart be pleasing in your sight, Lord, my Rock and my Redeemer. - Psalms 19:14 (NIV)
fields.content: A young boy was constantly caught talking to classmates, out of turn. Nothing seemed to work to correct the habit. Then the teacher stumbled upon an idea. Since the boy liked to talk, why not enhance his vocabulary? Each time he was called out, the teacher would put a mark on the corner of the chalkboard. At the end of the day he would be assigned a page in the dictionary for each mark, and he would have to write each word, its definition, and use it in a sentence. Throughout the course of the year, he did a lot of learning, and enhancing of his vocabulary. The boy fell in love with words as it made him more articulate in his speech. Learning to pray and how to think about God is a lifelong endeavor. It is complicated by the realization that God already knows what we will say, and the thoughts in our hearts, before we even utter them. Words matter. The use of the correct word in prayer and meditation is not to make it clearer for God's understanding, but for ours. Learn new words; they will enhance your knowledge and appreciation of God.

fields.verse: But who can discern their own errors? Forgive my hidden faults. Keep your servant also from willful sins; may they not rule over me. Then I will be blameless, innocent of great transgression. - Psalms 19:12‭-‬13 (NIV)
fields.content: We fall into the trap of judging others, because their sins are more obvious to us than our own. We tend to justify some thoughts and behaviors by renaming them. We call anger, indignation, we tell "white" lies, being cheap is thriftiness, and meanness disguises itself as tough love. God desires a transparent, humble, and open heart. Any attempt to cover ourselves is as useless as weaving clothes out of fig leaves. The antidote for our weakness, shortcomings, and sin is God's forgiveness and the Spirit's empowerment to break the cycle of trying to hide behind accusing others who we perceive to be worse than ourselves. We don't always see our own errors, but God does. He offers forgiveness for the sins we know about, the sins we try to hide, and even those that escape our awareness. "Search us, O' God. You know our hearts. Nothing is hidden from you. Forgive our sins and free us to walk with you unhindered, in truth and righteousness. Amen"

fields.verse: The law of the Lord is perfect, refreshing the soul. The statutes of the Lord are trustworthy, making wise the simple. The precepts of the Lord are right, giving joy to the heart. The commands of the Lord are radiant, giving light to the eyes. The fear of the Lord is pure, enduring forever. The decrees of the Lord are firm, and all of them are righteous. They are more precious than gold, than much pure gold; they are sweeter than honey, than honey from the honeycomb. By them your servant is warned; in keeping them there is great reward. - Psalms 19:7‭-‬11 (NIV)
fields.content: Someone should write a handbook for life. Oh wait, they have! Inspired by the Spirit of God, writers have taken pen to hand with Divine authority. Interwoven between the history of Creation and the final Conclusion is the grand theme of Redemption. Above everything else, the Bible is about our salvation. In addition, God has been gracious in providing us with counsel for living a good, full life. The Psalmist makes clear that God's word: refreshes the soul, makes us wise, gives joy to the heart, and gives clarity to our eyes. Living by the Book results in great reward. Hunger for it. Thirst for it. His word is a treasure trove that surpasses gold and silver in value.

fields.verse: Keep me safe, my God, for in you I take refuge. - Psalms 16:1 (NIV)
fields.content: With all the talk of bucolic valleys and other beautiful vistas of nature, we actually live in a hostile environment. History is replete with  instances of volcanic eruptions, hurricanes, tornadoes, earthquakes, droughts, floods, and pestilence. In addition we are subjected to human depravity, violence and crime. Take a peek at our Big Blue Marble from outer space; evidence of colossal meteor and asteroid strikes, big enough to end life on the planet, are clearly visible. Our latest attack comes from organisms that cannot be seen with the naked eye, but are capable of taking out millions of lives. It is a wonder we are still around. This Psalm provides a key to our survival; God's protection is available because His plan is yet to be completely fulfilled. So we pray, but not because we don't want to succumb to the inevitable, but because we want to be a part of how it turns out. He is our refuge equipping us for the challenges of climbing the mountains that stand in the way of the fertile, beautiful valleys in between.

fields.verse: When the foundations are being destroyed, what can the righteous do?” - Psalms 11:3 (NIV)
fields.content: Termites: a word that strikes fear in the heart of a homeowner. Termites work silently and leave little evidence of their presence until they are established. If left unchecked, they will undermine and destroy the structure of a home. What has to be determined is their point of entry, how long they have been at work, how far they have branched out, and how much damage has been done. There is no compromise with termites; their nest must be eradicated, and the damage needs to be repaired. We can't remove all of the termites in the world, but we can get rid of the ones in our house. Our societal moral fiber is being inhabited by dangerous forces. They have grown in numbers and intensity and are gaining a foothold in the minds of believers and their churches. The people of God must do a thorough inspection and repel those who undermine the integrity and righteousness of God and His work. If the foundation is compromised, the source must be removed and the damage repaired. That's what the righteous do; they contend for the faith. Join the fight.

fields.verse: Why, Lord, do you stand far off? Why do you hide yourself in times of trouble? - Psalms 10:1 (NIV)
fields.content: Yes, even the strongest believer has, on occasion, doubted that God is fully engaged or present in a current trial. We find ourselves seemingly fighting the battle alone. We fight hoping to stifle the enemy and stay the course. We steal a glance ahead, behind, to the side, hoping that God will show up; but there seems to be no sight of him. If we lose the battle, we ask why? The Lord responds by showing us, and reminding us, that losing a battle is not the same as losing the war. We learn from it and are better equipped for the next skirmish. If we win, he reveals to us that we have the ability to win with the experience we've gained from other previous battles where he was prominently involved. Win, or lose, we must fight. When the war is finally over and the ultimate victory is proclaimed, our scars will be the visual reminders and medals of our participation in restoring the Earth and everything in it to its rightful owner. Fight on, we will win. Though you may not see him, by faith we know, he is there.

fields.verse: But I, by your great love, can come into your house; in reverence I bow down toward your holy temple. . .But let all who take refuge in you be glad; let them ever sing for joy. Spread your protection over them, that those who love your name may rejoice in you. Surely, Lord, you bless the righteous; you surround them with your favor as with a shield. - Psalms 5:7‭, ‬11‭-‬12 (NIV)
fields.content: An employee walked into the coffee room where a number of supervisors were engaged in discussion. The conversation came to an immediate halt. He quickly got his coffee, apologized, and left. If you've ever found yourself in a place where you weren't welcome, the awkwardness and anxiety can be palpable. He later found out the supervisors were talking about downsizing the company, and he was among those who were being let go. On the flip side, think of the times you gathered with your closest friends, visited your Nana's house, or entered into the reverence of a prayer meeting in progress. You were in a safe zone; contentment, love, and gratitude, filled your soul. All who confess God as Father and Jesus as Lord, find themselves surrounded by a shield of protection, an embrace of acceptance, and an abundance of favor. Enter in, you belong, and he won't let you go.

fields.verse: In the morning, Lord, you hear my voice; in the morning I lay my requests before you and wait expectantly. - Psalms 5:3 (NIV)
fields.content: First thing in the morning, have a little talk with Jesus. Let his voice be the first you'll hear. Share your goals and dreams. Get his input in how to go about making them come to pass. Unburden your heart  of cares and concerns. Drink from the fresh streams of encouragement from his Word. Set the mood and pace of your day with the confidence you've been heard. Then wait. Wait with expectancy, the kind of waiting you experience when you place an order from Amazon, the eager anticipation of your server's return from a 5:star: restaurant kitchen, the joy of a toddler when Mom picks her up from the church nursery, the yearning of a sailor's spouse when the ship returns to port. Everyday is filled with potential answers to prayer. Make your requests early.

fields.verse: I lie down and sleep; I wake again, because the Lord sustains me. - Psalms 3:5 (NIV)
fields.content: Even before the sun peeks over the horizon, the birds begin their chirping in anticipation of a new day. Their song is loud and clear; they have made it through the night. We don't know what birds think about when they sleep. They are not burdened with bills, politics, or social media. The extent of their socializing happens when they gather in flocks in a tree, or line up on electrical lines. During the day they have an advantage. Rested and refreshed, their energy seems abundant and endless. They can see their predators more readily, and locate their food more easily. They rely on their God-given intuition and that same God's ability to provide for them. But at night, when they are at the most vulnerable, they put their trust in something beyond themselves. They sleep and then awaken, having been sustained by their Creator.

fields.verse: Blessed is the one who does not walk in step with the wicked or stand in the way that sinners take or sit in the company of mockers, but whose delight is in the law of the Lord, and who meditates on his law day and night. That person is like a tree planted by streams of water, which yields its fruit in season and whose leaf does not wither— whatever they do prospers. - Psalms 1:1‭-‬3 (NIV)
fields.content: To be blessed means to be happy. In this Psalm, happiness has two dimensions. There is the happiness that comes from not walking in evil ways, and the happiness that comes from walking the way of righteousness. If not careful, either by themselves can result in smug self-righteousness. Taken together they complement each other. Forsaking sinful behavior frees us to walk in righteousness. Walking in righteousness reaps the benefits motivating us to shun evil. Those who experience the fullness of blessedness (happiness), are adept at avoiding evil while staying on course in loving and serving God. The added benefit is that those who are happy in the Lord, become like trees that provide shade and fruit to refresh and nourish others. Be happy.

fields.verse: My prayer is not that you take them out of the world but that you protect them from the evil one. - John 17:15 (NIV)
fields.content: Believers in Jesus have a target on their backs. The evil one and his minions are constantly looking to trip us up, destroy our morale, and quiet our tongues. As long as we traipse the dust of the Earth, we can expect opposition. It would be a sweet release if we were to be transported into God's presence to escape the temptation, trials and challenges of life, and soon enough we will be, but until then we have work to do. In the midst of our sharing the gospel and doing the work of bringing comfort to the mourning, peace to those in turmoil, and deliverance to those in mental or physical bondage, Jesus has prayed for our protection. God the Father, his Holy Spirit, and his ministering angels are busily at work providing cover, shielding us and cheering us on. Do not grow weary in well-doing, in due time we will reap what we have sown and bring God the harvest of our labor. At that time we will hear the words that make it all worthwhile - "Well done, good and faithful servant. Enter into the joy of the Lord."

fields.verse: “I have told you these things, so that in me you may have peace. In this world you will have trouble. But take heart! I have overcome the world.” - John 16:33 (NIV)
fields.content: We are surrounded by trouble. Fortunately we are surrounded by blessing as well. Job says it well, ". . .man is born to trouble as surely as sparks fly upward." (5:7) We can avoid trouble to an extent, but no one can escape it. Until the time Jesus returns, our lives goes through cycles of trouble and peace; for some, more of one than the other, sometimes both at once. So what is our response? Do we pull out the stops and celebrate during good times and clench our teeth and fight through, or resign ourselves to letting the bad times run their course? That is one strategy. Or, we can set our sights upward to the one who overcame and now sits above it all for eternity. He knows the end. He knows how it ends. He modeled for us, by experiencing life with us, that our trials and troubles are but for a season. Hear the words of the Apostle Paul, "For this light momentary affliction is preparing for us an eternal weight of glory beyond all comparison, as we look not to the things that are seen but to the things that are unseen. For the things that are seen are transient, but the things that are unseen are eternal." (2 Cor. 4:17-18) We don't have to wait for the sweet by and by when we die. His kind of peace and joy are available now, and last forever.

fields.verse: “I am the true vine, and my Father is the gardener. He cuts off every branch in me that bears no fruit, while every branch that does bear fruit he prunes so that it will be even more fruitful. - John 15:1‭-‬2 (NIV)
fields.content: Many are attached to Jesus. They quote him when they agree with his words, are fascinated by stories of his miracles, and acknowledge his impact on history. They even sport tattoos, or wear Cross necklaces and other fine jewelry, but they often ignore him when it comes to the hard things he had to say about sin, and certain sins in particular. The litmus test to the validity of their attachment is the presence or absence of fruit. Sadly, many who are attached bear no fruit. These branches look promising but they steal nutrients and fail to deliver on that promise. In order to maximize the yield of the plant, the gardener must lopped them off. In contrast, we have branches that bear fruit. These branches are pruned to ensure all the energy from the vine, flowing to that branch, goes into producing fruit, and not into extra foliage that bears nothing. At the time of harvesting, the fruit is picked and the branches remain for another growing season. Those who are true disciples of Jesus are recognized by the fruit they bear. (Matthew 7:15-20) As for the other branches, the jury is still out until they do.

fields.verse: Peace I leave with you; my peace I give you. I do not give to you as the world gives. Do not let your hearts be troubled and do not be afraid. - John 14:27 (NIV)
fields.content: Genie: What's your first wish?  Jack: I want to be rich.  Genie: Granted! And your 2nd wish?  Rich: I want lots of money this time.We need to be clear about what we ask for. The world has a definition of peace that is often little more than a tense agreement to cease hostilities. The two sides are still at odds, only experiencing an anxious hope; the dread of conflict still lingers in the air. Whether it is the temporal nature of riches, the tentativeness of good work relations that can sour over one missed deadline, or the tumult that ensues when a near perfect child makes a decision that is negatively life changing, the peace disappears and the battle resumes. The peace the world offers is short lived. In kingdom language, peace mean completeness and wholeness. It covers good times and bad times. It is the assurance that "God causes all things to work together for good. . . It is the humble acknowledgement that all is well with your soul, regardless of the circumstances. It is the kind of peace that only Jesus can give. That's why he's called, the Prince of Peace.

fields.verse: “If you love me, keep my commands. And I will ask the Father, and he will give you another advocate to help you and be with you forever— the Spirit of truth. The world cannot accept him, because it neither sees him nor knows him. But you know him, for he lives with you and will be in you. I will not leave you as orphans; I will come to you. - John 14:15‭-‬18 (NIV)
fields.content: The Holy Spirit is probably the least understood manifestation of the Triune God. He was there at Creation, his presence is gently woven throughout the Old Testament narrative, but he makes his grand entrance in the Book of Acts after the ascension of the risen Christ. He is called our Advocate, Counselor, Guide and continues the work of the Father and the Son until the day of the Great Conciliation. At no time in history is God more able to be known than now. The mystery of the Father has been revealed in the person of Jesus, and the reality of His presence is more universally evident because His Spirit now lives in his people and works in power through them. This is part of what Jesus meant when he said, ". . .they will do greater things than these, because I go to the Father." (14:12)  The world continues to see only glimpses of what His Spirit can do. It will be amazing to see what God can do when His collective people rediscover the power that is theirs through the Holy Spirit. Arise, O' Lord. Demonstrate your power!

fields.verse: Believe me when I say that I am in the Father and the Father is in me; or at least believe on the evidence of the works themselves. - John 14:11 (NIV)
fields.content: Word and deed are the bedrock of truth. What is done confirms what is said, and what is said confirms what's been done. Jesus made some extraordinary claims; He also performed some incredible deeds. Day after day, as he walked among the people; he taught and healed, exhorted and delivered, prophesied and gave sight to the blind. What Jesus said fit like a hand in a glove. Some were slow to believe, and others rejected him outright, but all had access to the evidence and will one day stand before the Creator without excuse. All will say, "I have no excuse for not believing." Some will hang their heads in shame, others will rejoice in their salvation. Same facts, different outcomes.

fields.verse: Jesus answered, 'I am the way and the truth and the life. No one comes to the Father except through me.' - John 14:6 (NIV)
fields.content: A man was driving down a road when he realized he may be lost. Back in the day before cell phones and GPS, the place to go to ask for directions was the gas station. After several attempts to get the driver back on the correct road to his destination, the attendant paused for a moment before saying, "I don't think you can get there from here." So is the plight of anyone on the wrong road to eternity. No other road will get us there. The Good News is that, if you reread the words of Jesus, the flip side of what he says is astounding! "Everyone comes to the Father through me." What initially sounded exclusive, denying entry into God's presence, turns into a most inclusive statement revealing God's ultimate intention. He wants us all to come to repentance and acknowledge His Son the Savior. Jesus is the Way. The call, is extended to all. We can get there from here.

fields.verse: “A new command I give you: Love one another. As I have loved you, so you must love one another. By this everyone will know that you are my disciples, if you love one another.” - John 13:34‭-‬35 (NIV)
fields.content: The People of God are defined by love -- loving God and loving each other. Somehow this had been lost in the shuffle of history as the Law of Moses, consisting of the 10 Commandments, was expanded to include 613 laws extrapolated out of the books of Moses, the first 5 books of the Hebrew Bible. The rules proceeded to grow in number as each generation of priests and teachers expounded on each of the 613. By the time Jesus came on the scene, it had become virtually impossible to live up to the demands of the Law. Judging and judgment abounded as people chose to become followers of various sects, teachings, or teachers. It was, and interestingly still is, a mess. Jesus spoke clarity into the confusion. He took all the Law, rules and regulations, and consolidated them into 2 simple, yet profound, truths. Love God, love each other. From that point on it would be the criteria by which we are to measure our standing and progression in the Faith. By following his two simple principles, believers stand out in culture and time, and are more easily identified as the people of God. Step away from the burden of trying to live up to the impossible demands of the Law. Love others as we have been loved by God and we will experience the peace of knowing to whom we belong.

fields.verse: Jesus knew that the Father had put all things under his power, and that he had come from God and was returning to God; so he got up from the meal, took off his outer clothing, and wrapped a towel around his waist. After that, he poured water into a basin and began to wash his disciples’ feet, drying them with the towel that was wrapped around him. - John 13:3‭-‬5 (NIV)
fields.content: I had the privilege of speaking at a large Midwestern church where the pastor was known for his gracious hospitality. After the service he invited me for a cup of coffee in their school cafeteria. We went to sit at a table, but it needed cleaning. He nonchalantly went to a cabinet, found some cleaner and paper towels, and thoroughly cleaned the table. He could have called for a member of the janitorial staff to clean it. There were plenty of places to sit at other tables, but this simple act, done without complaint or fanfare, won me over. He demonstrated what we call today, servant leadership. The task of washing the guest's feet was assigned to the house servant at the bottom of the order. Jesus modeled for us that no task is too small in serving God the Father. All things were put under his power. He would never ask his disciples to do something that he himself would not be willing to do. The Apostle Paul's words in his letter to the Philippians remind us that we "can do all things through Him who strengthens" us. (4:13) Included are those things which can be done in confident boldness, and those requiring quiet humility. Washing feet may be the ultimate sign of powerful leadership. Jesus, lead on.

fields.verse: Even after Jesus had performed so many signs in their presence, they still would not believe in him. - John 12:37 (NIV)
fields.content: Follow the evidence no matter where it leads. Jesus presented the facts; some still refused to acknowledge who He was. Facts are a stubborn thing; they affirm convictions, or cause us to reassess a presupposition. We can adjust a belief accordingly, or choose to ignore the fact. Making adjustments takes us closer to a fuller understanding of Truth. Ignoring or rejecting the truth results in living in a self-imposed shade of darkness. Truth cannot be invented, it is discovered. The facts are all around us; they have been there all along.  Light dispels darkness - He is the Truth. Be counted among those who choose to live in the Light.

fields.verse: Now my soul is troubled, and what shall I say? ‘Father, save me from this hour’? No, it was for this very reason I came to this hour. Father, glorify your name!. . . - John 12:27‭-‬28 (NIV)
fields.content: Who am I? Why am I hear? We are on a quest to find significance and meaning. When we find the answers to these questions, life takes on a different dimension. Once Jesus made his first public appearance, the issue was settled. He acknowledged his purpose and from that point on everything he said and did, every place he went, and every person he encountered, received the benefit of his presence. He led a short but significant life. Crowds marveled at his teachings, individuals benefited from his healing and deliverance; those actions served as signs to the reason for his coming. He came to die. Those four words are blunt and stop us in our tracks. Death is not something most of us live for, but ironically fullness of meaning and significance is realized when we find that for which we are willing to die. The words of Gladys Knight come to mind: "I'd rather live in his world, than live without him in mine." (Midnight Train to Georgia, 1973) The words of the great Apostle Paul also come to mind. "I am crucified with Christ, nevertheless I live. . ." (Galatians 2:20)

fields.verse: Meanwhile a large crowd of Jews found out that Jesus was there and came, not only because of him but also to see Lazarus, whom he had raised from the dead. So the chief priests made plans to kill Lazarus as well, for on account of him many of the Jews were going over to Jesus and believing in him. -  John 12:9‭-‬11 (NIV)
fields.content: The attempt to eliminate the Christian faith begins with accusing and arresting followers, then closing places of worship, confiscating Bibles, and ultimately making it against the law. Despots, tyrants, and elite religious leaders despise Jesus' message; it challenges their whole structure of power and promotes freedom to the masses. A free people scare totalitarians.  Lazarus was the innocent recipient of a resurrection miracle, but he became a target because his witness convinced skeptics and seekers that Jesus was the Messiah, the Son of God. Lazarus was guilty by association. In the words of the gospel hit of the 1970s by Larnelle Harris: "If you were arrested for being a Christian, would there be enough evidence to convict you." (Evidence, 1977)

fields.verse: Jesus wept. - John 11:35 (NIV)
fields.content: He is acquainted with our deepest sorrow,  He knows our every need.  Every good that's been attempted,  Every time we've been rejected,  Our failed efforts to succeed.The pain is deep within him,  He wants us to be whole.  At each defeat he takes our hand,  Lifts us up so we can stand,  Dries our tears and heals our soul.It's no wonder there is weeping  We're surrounded by distress,  Lazarus resides in peace,  His contentment will soon cease,  For his work's not finished yet.Joy and laughter fills the air,  Jesus raised him from the dead  An interrupted trip to glory,  Would be the highlight of his story,  But Jesus saw what lay ahead,It's no wonder, Jesus wept.

fields.verse: I have other sheep that are not of this sheep pen. I must bring them also. They too will listen to my voice, and there shall be one flock and one shepherd. - John 10:16 (NIV)
fields.content: There were 8 teams in the league; 7 of them were sponsored by the bigger businesses in town. They had complete baseball uniforms right down to the stirrup socks and full catcher's gear. One team from "the other side of the tracks" could only muster up support from the town's barbershop. The best the owner could furnish was t-shirts and used equipment from the second-hand store. Although outclassed in almost every aspect that doesn't matter, the kids from the other side of town managed to wrestle a second place finish. Then it was time for the awards banquet. It was a coat and tie only affair, but the team manager talked the league into allowing the second-place kids to come to the banquet. They arrived wearing the best they had, which under the banquet rules was not good enough. They were quickly ushered to a back room where they were each outfitted with a new coat and tie donated by a generous benefactor. Some of the coats were a bit loose, and others were a bit tight, but they proudly walked into the banquet hall, were seated at their team table, and blended right in. They had played the game, under the established rules, and although their circumstances were different, they were shown that they belonged. The Gospel offered to the Gentiles, is proof that Jesus has prepared a place for us at the banquet. We belong.

fields.verse: The thief comes only to steal and kill and destroy; I have come that they may have life, and have it to the full. - John 10:10 (NIV)
fields.content: Deception is to contentment what pyrite is to gold. Pyrite is an abundant mineral found all over the world. It mimics gold in appearance, but is virtual useless in application. The California Gold Rush of the mid 18th century featured a cascade of people risking life and limb, to make the trek to California in search of riches. They were often met by bandits, claims jumpers, and others who would forcibly take, or resort to deception, to separate them from their hard earned gains. The saddest of embarrassments was reserved for the miner who filled his bags, headed into town to convert his cache into cash, only to discover he had no gold, only pyrite. His hard work and life's savings would be depleted, leaving him destitute and broken. The enemy of our soul offers us the elixir of a false joy when he tempts us with sin. But all that glitters is not gold. Pyrite is the best he has to offer. Don't be fooled, go for the gold

fields.verse: As he went along, he saw a man blind from birth. His disciples asked him, 'Rabbi, who sinned, this man or his parents, that he was born blind?'. . .After saying this, he spit on the ground, made some mud with the saliva, and put it on the man’s eyes. “Go,” he told him, “wash in the Pool of Siloam” (this word means “Sent”). So the man went and washed, and came home seeing. . .They brought to the Pharisees the man who had been blind. . .To this they replied, 'You were steeped in sin at birth; how dare you lecture us!' And they threw him out. - John 9:1-2‭, ‬6-7, 13, 34 (NIV)
fields.content: We've all heard stories of young people who watch their diets, have no vices, exercise regularly, and yet are diagnosed with cancer. We've also heard about individuals who are obese, never exercise, and indulge in habits that have proven to be dangerous, yet they live into their late 80s. While there is plenty of scientific evidence that good diet and exercise results in a better quality of life, while obesity and vices can have huge detrimental effects, sometimes there is an outlier that defies the odds. The uncertainty of life is not always an indicator or an excuse for our present condition. This is the case of the man blind from birth. He was in a place where we needed God to show up. Some around him were amazed and others scoffed.  It is important to note that no matter where he was in life, he was in a position to glorify God when Jesus crossed his path. Ignore the naysayers. While some persist in debating what and where he was, he was in the right place at the right time. He celebratd his sight and pointes to the one who restored him.

fields.verse: They said this to test him, so that they might have some charge to bring against him. Jesus bent down and wrote with his finger on the ground. When they kept on questioning him, he straightened up and said to them, ‘Let anyone among you who is without sin be the first to throw a stone at her.’ And once again he bent down and wrote on the ground. When they heard it, they went away, one by one, beginning with the elders; and Jesus was left alone with the woman standing before him. Jesus straightened up and said to her, ‘Woman, where are they? Has no one condemned you?’ She said, ‘No one, sir.’ And Jesus said, ‘Neither do I condemn you. Go your way, and from now on do not sin again.' - John 8:6-11 (NRSV)
fields.content: Marriage vows join two people as one. Adultery is an egregious sin; it goes beyond a physical act in that it involves the breaking of vows. Adultery rips apart the fabric of a holy union of which the Scriptures proclaim, "What God has joined together, let no one seek to divide." The result of adultery is one person being shattered into two broken people. Something Jesus said and wrote in the dust resulted in a shift in the case of the woman caught in the actual act of adultery. We can speculate about what he said and wrote, but any conclusion is complete conjecture. We just don't know. But whatever it was, it resulted in her accusers dropping their accusations, turning around, and leaving the scene. Jesus extends his forgiveness while admonishes her to leave her sinful lifestyle. It is the expectation of those who are forgiven to live a different life. The accusers disappear and the record of the entire event is left in the dust for the winds of forgiveness to erase.

fields.verse: On the last and greatest day of the festival, Jesus stood and said in a loud voice, 'Let anyone who is thirsty come to me and drink. Whoever believes in me, as Scripture has said, rivers of living water will flow from within them.' - John 7:37‭-‬38 (NIV)
fields.content: Those who desire to help people, know how physically and emotionally draining that can be. People-helping professions draw compassionate people into their ranks. They see the misery surrounding the human condition and want to do something about it. But the turnover of workers in these fields is high because of burnout. Followers of Jesus growing in their relationship with God, increasingly stand out to others who are suffering. They recognize believers have found the source of contentment and peace they lack. Those in emotional and spiritual pain gravitate to them seeking relief for their maladies. Believers have been gifted with continual supply of living water with which to be refreshed and refresh others. Let's not lean on our own understanding and strength; as long as we draw from the Source of that water, our words and life will bring refreshment to those who thirst.

fields.verse: “Here is a boy with five small barley loaves and two small fish, but how far will they go among so many?”. . . Jesus then took the loaves, gave thanks, and distributed to those who were seated as much as they wanted. He did the same with the fish. - John 6:9‭, ‬11 (NIV)
fields.content: How much does God need to work with? What does it take to feed a large hungry crowd? After a quick inventory, a small boy offers up what he had. He was presented to Jesus and the story took on biblical proportions. Hard to imagine? Of course it is; it is even harder to believe! Scholars have attempted to come up with reasonable explanations, but since the story is so short, the attempts involve conjecture and presuppositions. Even as this is written it raises more questions, but the answer is unchanged. The Gospel according to John records that Jesus fed a large crowd of 5,000 with five small barley loaves of bread and two fish. When we consider God created the universe out of nothing, it becomes feasible he can do anything with a little something. So, let's take what we do have, place it before the Master, step back and see what he can do.

fields.verse: You study the Scriptures diligently because you think that in them you have eternal life. These are the very Scriptures that testify about me, yet you refuse to come to me to have life. - John 5:39‭-‬40 (NIV)
fields.content: It is possible to diligently study the Bible and miss its most important message. There are moral and ethical matters addressed in Scripture. Within its pages can be found wisdom and counsel for issues of life. Advice for living happily with a spouse, principles for raising children, comfort for a broken heart, guidance and common sense, are all given some level of treatment. It's a veritable "how to" book. But, wait, there is more! There is an overriding theme superimposed over the 66 books that comprise our Bible, and it ties together all the writers and writings; the Messiah is coming, has come, and will return to restore the Creation to wholeness. Churches, seminaries, and families are churning out people who receive the benefit of living by the book, but fail to see the Divine intention of the Book. Many are full of misguided purpose yet remain separated from the life-giving Source that unites faith and life. Rightly dividing the Word of Truth must ultimately result in knowing the Way, the Truth, and the Life. Anything less, and we've missed the point. A simple prayer should preface our opening of the book. "Heavenly Father, show me Jesus." - Amen.

fields.verse: Then Jesus said to him, 'Get up! Pick up your mat and walk.' At once the man was cured; he picked up his mat and walked. The day on which this took place was a Sabbath, and so the Jewish leaders said to the man who had been healed, 'It is the Sabbath; the law forbids you to carry your mat.'” - John 5:8‭-‬10 (NIV)
fields.content: You've met them, you know who they are; no matter what is happening they always find fault with something. The sermon was too long, the music was too loud, someone wasn't dressed appropriately, the thermostat was set too high or too low; all these things can be remedied, but they will always find something else to complain about. They called themselves perfectionists, purists, idealist; we are tempted to call them nitpickers. H.L. Mencken defined 'Puritanism as "the haunting fear that someone, somewhere, may be happy." They sacrifice the good on the altar of the imagined best and miss the blessing right in front of them. A disabled man was given the ability to walk, but the religious leaders were more concerned about a commandment being legalistically enforced. Great and beautiful things are happening all around us, but we may not notice because we are fixated on an unimportant detail. Life is not perfect, at least not the perfect we've imagined or constructed, but it is filled with God's miraculous interventions. What He does is to be our focus; everything else is a potential distraction. What matters is that a broken person was made whole.

fields.verse: Once more he visited Cana in Galilee. . .And there was a certain royal official whose son lay sick at Capernaum. When this man heard that Jesus had arrived in Galilee from Judea, he went to him and begged him to come and heal his son, who was close to death. . . The royal official said, “Sir, come down before my child dies.” “Go,” Jesus replied, “your son will live.” The man took Jesus at his word and departed. While he was still on the way, his servants met him with the news that his boy was living. . . When he inquired as to the time when his son got better, they said to him, “Yesterday, at one in the afternoon, the fever left him.” Then the father realized that this was the exact time at which Jesus had said to him, “Your son will live.” So he and his whole household believed. - John 4:46‭-‬53 (NIV)
fields.content: Damar Hamlin, an NFL football player with the Buffalo Bills, dropped to the ground in the middle of a game, a victim of an unexpected heart attack. Immediately, medical personnel ran onto the field, quickly assessed his condition, jump started his heart, and performed CPR. We could say that they saved his life. But something else happened spontaneously. The initial prognosis was grim; a young man at the peak of conditioning was fighting for his life, but he was not fighting alone. Teammates, opposing players, coaches, and a host of fans in the stadium, began to drop to their knees or bow their heads in prayer as the drama unfolded before them. A sports commentator prayed for him on live television. Social media lit up as people across the country and literally around the world posted their prayers for Hamlin. Only in eternal heaven will we know the impact of those prayers fortifying the efforts of excellent medical professionals, but a number of the attending staff acknowledged that an environment of prayerful support gave them hope and confidence as they practiced their skills and training. The royal official was unable to bring his son to Jesus, but Jesus healed his son from afar. There is no amount of distance that can deter the power of God. Damar Hamlin may never know most of the names of the people who prayed for him, but he is recovering and the prognosis is good. Whether near or far, God answers prayer.

fields.verse: But he said to them, 'I have food to eat that you know nothing about.' Then his disciples said to each other, 'Could someone have brought him food?' 'My food,' said Jesus, 'is to do the will of him who sent me and to finish his work.' - John 4:32‭-‬34 (NIV)
fields.content: For three days straight, the young boy brought his lunch back from school untouched. His mom sat him down and asked why? He replied that he was so busy he forgot to eat. Apparently the physical education teacher had introduced soccer to his students. The young boy took to it like he was born to play. There wasn't a moment when he wasn't dribbling a ball, honing his skills, or playing with his friends. Everything else took a back seat to soccer. It's been said that if you can find something you love to do, and get paid for doing it, you'd be the happiest person on earth. Taking it one step further, passionate people will find joy in any job so long as it pays enough and gives them time to pursue their passion. Jesus had a singular focus, to do and finish the work the Father had given him. It was a lesson his disciples would understand more clearly in the future, when the advancement of the Story would be on their shoulders.

fields.verse: They said to the woman, “We no longer believe just because of what you said; now we have heard for ourselves, and we know that this man really is the Savior of the world.” - John 4:42 (NIV)
fields.content: The woman at the well had a bad reputation. It was so bad she had to go to the communal well to fetch water in the hottest part of the day when no one else would be around. Written off by many, but not by Jesus, in one short conversation he was able to amaze her to the point she left her water jar and ran back to the village to tell anyone and everyone what she had experienced. The villagers went back and talked Jesus into staying with them for two days as he proclaimed the truths about himself, the Savior of the world. They made the significant transition from believing the second-hand account of the woman to believing Jesus individually and personally. God can use the most broken of vessels to carry the Water of Life. Those who drink will never thirst again.

fields.verse: Thus the saying ‘One sows and another reaps’ is true. I sent you to reap what you have not worked for. Others have done the hard work, and you have reaped the benefits of their labor.” - John 4:37‭-‬38 (NIV)
fields.content: A commitment to the lordship of Jesus most often comes about through a series of interconnected events. It may have started in the comfort of a God-fearing home where loving parents read us the Bible, took us to church, and modeled the Christ life. A faithful Pastor, Sunday School teacher or youth leader added another layer to the witness, and the circumstances of life were arranged just right for us to consider our need for a Savior. However it happened, it was the culmination of a series of steps that led us to the destination at the foot of the Cross. Each of us is a link in a chain for someone else's successful conversion. Some plant, some water, but it is God who gives the increase. The act of sowing leads to the privilege of reaping. Someone, somewhere, sowed seed in our lives. Someone, somewhere, watered, weeded, and cultivated that seed. Someone, somewhere gathered the harvest of that seed. We are here because of them. Let's do our part to keep the chain intact for someone else.

fields.verse: Yet a time is coming and has now come when the true worshipers will worship the Father in the Spirit and in truth, for they are the kind of worshipers the Father seeks. God is spirit, and his worshipers must worship in the Spirit and in truth.” - John 4:23‭-‬24 (NIV)
fields.content: Acceptable worship is grounded in the Spirit and Truth. The Spirit is our Guide, Helper, and Comforter. He is referred to as the Spirit of unity, power, and obedience. To worship God in Spirit is to take into account who the Spirit is and what he does. Our standard of truth to assist us in knowing and worshiping God, is his Holy Word. As you read the Bible, note the places where the Spirit of God is mentioned. From Creation to the Revelation he makes his appearance. In every case, He is there to facilitate the plan of heaven to restore the fallen world and claim it once again as God's sole possession. Our worship is meaningful when it extols our God, drawing us together as His people, prompting us to work in unity, as instruments in God's hands to establish his kingdom on earth as it is in heaven.

fields.verse: For God did not send his Son into the world to condemn the world, but to save the world through him. - John 3:17 (NIV)
fields.content: The world is already condemned. Pronouncing more condemnation on it will not make it worse, or better. There is plenty of evidence of the dire straits we find ourselves in. In our country alone, we are confronted with rising levels of crime that are at all time highs.  Misdemeanor crime hardly gets a wrist slap anymore. And to that we add: natural disasters causing death and destruction of property. The upheaval of hurricanes, earthquakes, and extreme temperature swings, take months to overcome; we won't even mention, pestilence, famine, and disease. The toll of human suffering is incalculable. Heaping condemnation on the already suffering is tantamount to putting salt on a wound. Everything bad that is going on around us is a reminder of why Jesus came. What the world needs is a word of hope. Hope gives us something to look forward to; it provides assurance that it won't always be bad. Hope is the first rays of sunlight dispelling the darkness that enshrouds us. Jesus, the light of the world is hope for the hurting, the safe destination for the lost.

fields.verse: Therefore, if anyone is in Christ, the new creation has come: The old has gone, the new is here! - 2 Corinthians 5:17 (NIV)
fields.content: And so we say goodbye to 2022. Some of us look back with fondness, others are saying "Good riddance!", most of us have mixed feelings. We look forward to the start of a new year. There is an arbitrary separation between 12/31 and 1/1 that was birthed by the invention of the calendar. Up until then, every new day was just another day that marked a completion of the earth rotation on its axis, and every new year was the completion of the earth's orbit around the sun. Every morning we can look forward to a new 24 hour clean slate. Every 365 days we can wipe the slate clean and start a new year. But on New Years Day, we grant ourselves the opportunity to set massive unattainable goals for the next 365 days. Anything seems possible by a magical turn of the page on the calendar. Wish it were so. One fact is undeniable. A commitment to the lordship of Jesus Christ is a landmark decision that needs to be made only once. Once made, we give God charge of the rest. We've become new creations, the old has been cast away, and each new day is as good as His promises. Indeed, by His miraculous intervention, all things have been made new. Happy New Year!

fields.verse: He came to that which was his own, but his own did not receive him. Yet to all who did receive him, to those who believed in his name, he gave the right to become children of God— children born not of natural descent, nor of human decision or a husband’s will, but born of God. - John 1:11‭-‬13 (NIV)
fields.content: A young girl's muffled sobs could be heard emanating from her bedroom. Her boyfriend had ended their relationship. Her father knocked on the door and asked his daughter if she wanted to go out for ice cream. Good dads know ice cream pretty much fixes broken hearts. Rejection is painful. Whether it is a love interest, being fired from a job, not getting in to the college of your choice, or betrayal by a friend, it hurts to be given the cold shoulder. After giving his daughter a chance to talk, and assuring her she was pretty, smart, amusing, compassionate, and an all around beautiful person, he gave her some excellent fatherly advice: "When you are rejected, remember, it is their loss. Keep being who you are and the right people will take notice." Even Jesus himself experienced rejection, but the right people noticed and they got the benefits of having a relationship with the Son of God, the Savior of the world.

fields.verse: He was in the world, and though the world was made through him, the world did not recognize him. - John 1:10 (NIV)
fields.content: Imagine being in the world created by God, being made in the image of God, being visited by God, and not recognizing God, all because He didn't meet our predetermined perceptions. Our initial encounter with God often becomes the primary way we relate to him. We have a tendency to paint a picture of God that suits our individual, peculiar needs, and we stick to it. If our first meaningful encounter with God was because we had temporal needs, we view him as a Supplier. If we were lonely, he is viewed as a Friend. If we needed healing, he was a Healer; but God is each of these and more. He is more than any one aspect of him we have discovered. The measure of peace and joy we experience in our lives is in proportion to how our understanding of him grows. If what the infidel Voltaire said is true; "In the beginning God created man in His own image, and man has been trying to repay the favor ever since.", we are bound to miss out on tremendous blessings if we lock into a limited understanding of the all-seeing, all-powerful, all-knowing, God. God is a mosaic of all the pieces we believe about him that are true. Our knowledge of Him is clarified in bits and pieces as new tiles are added to the picture. Expand on what you know.

fields.verse: There was a man sent from God whose name was John. He came as a witness to testify concerning that light, so that through him all might believe. He himself was not the light; he came only as a witness to the light. - John 1:6‭-‬8 (NIV)
fields.content: John the Baptizer's task was clearly defined. He was to "prepare the way of the Lord." As he attracted followers, he would remind them there would be one coming, "whose latches on his sandals he would not be qualified to tie." John knew his influence and success had limitations; his calling did not. He stayed in his lane and his success was substantial. It's been said that we stand on the shoulders of those who came before us. The prophets who came before John prepared the way for him, but John would prepare the way for the greatest prophet of all time. In fact, John introduced more than a prophet, for Jesus was also a Priest and King! None of us knows the full impact we will bear in our generation. There is always a likelihood some who succeed us will be greater, much greater than us. It would be pretty hard to beat the one who introduced the Savior of the world, but our task is not a contest. We are charged with preparing our world for the Second Coming. His coming, the second time around, will be amazing!

fields.verse: The light shines in the darkness, and the darkness has not overcome it. - John 1:5‭ (NIV)
fields.content: On December 21, we observed the annual Winter Solstice. This is the day when the Earth's pole reaches its maximum tilt away from the Sun in the Northern Hemisphere on its yearly orbit. We experience the longest night of the year on the Winter Solstice. Many of our traditions of observing Christmas are adapted from other cultures and time. In a number of places throughout history, candles and fires we're lit in observance of the Winter Solstice. It was a belief in the pagan world that these fires would stop the encroachment of darkness and begin to dispel the darkness in the coming days. Most scholars agree that Jesus was born sometime in the Spring, not Winter. Apparently some missionaries saw in this celebration, an illustration to teach that, at the darkest time of our existence, God revealed his light to dispel our darkness. In essence, they redefined a pagan festival. Don't be shocked, or be in despair. While the pagans tried to appease the god of darkness into giving them more light, in our adaptation we celebrate that the Light of the World has come! The Kings of the East are still on the way. Don't forget to leave the light on.

fields.verse: When Joseph and Mary had done everything required by the Law of the Lord, they returned to Galilee to their own town of Nazareth. And the child grew and became strong; he was filled with wisdom, and the grace of God was on him. - Luke 2:39‭-‬40 (NIV)
fields.content: Growth strength, wisdom, and the grace of God; this is the testimony we want to hear about the next generation. Most of us will live long enough to see our children and grandchildren rise to take the helm of leadership, whether in their families or workplace. Each generation has a responsibility to chart a course, but will be successful only if their offspring repeat the process for their successors. Joseph's and Mary's lives were steeped in the understanding and application of the Scriptures. Their godliness laid the foundation for Jesus to recognize and actuate his calling. "Direct your children onto the right path, and when they are older, they will not leave it." - (Proverbs 22:6 NLT) It would be 12 years before we hear anything new about Jesus. The next time he makes an appearance, Jesus confirms his parent's efforts had been fruitful. May our efforts be rewarded as well.

fields.verse: EpilogueBut Mary treasured up all these things and pondered them in her heart. - Luke 2:19 (NIV)
fields.content: Nine months earlier, Mary's and Joseph's life had been only as eventful as any other couple planning a wedding. They hadn't expected an angelic visit would put their preparations in a totally different light. From the time of the visit, their energy would be focused on preparing to be parents; every expectant couple knows that. In addition to the mundane responsibilities of life, room has to be made for a long list of tasks requiring attention before the big day. Mary's growing belly was the hourglass constantly reminding them the deadline was approaching. No matter how well it is planned, babies come at their chosen time. A road trip, a bustling town, no available rooms, labor, birth, and shepherds dropping by for a visit; what a whirlwind! Like most mothers, the first sight of her child brought a sweet smile to her face and deep contentment to her soul. Now it was time for Mary to ponder and treasure her experience. The Prince of Peace had arrived. He would not only bring delight to the couple from Nazareth, he would bring joy to the world!

fields.verse: The Conclusion. . .or is it?This will be a sign to you: You will find a baby wrapped in cloths and lying in a manger. . .“Let’s go to Bethlehem and see this thing that has happened, which the Lord has told us about.” So they hurried off and found Mary and Joseph, and the baby, who was lying in the manger. When they had seen him, they spread the word concerning what had been told them about this child, and all who heard it were amazed at what the shepherds said to them. - Luke 2:12‭, 15-18 (NIV)
fields.content: Having experienced the angelic visitation and been treated to a heavenly chorus of praise, the shepherds knew what they had to do; they raced to Bethlehem to see for themselves. No one knew that the Kings of the East were on their way, the Messiah's first visitors we're humble, hard working, ordinary people. Just as the angel had said, there he was, a baby, wrapped in cloths, lying in a manger. He didn't look like much of a Wonderful Counselor, Almighty God, or Everlasting Father. He was an innocent, helpless, dependent baby. But the angelic messenger and message could not be ignored. Before them lay the promised descendant of David, the Messiah, the Savior of the world. The shepherds knew who he was and they couldn't stop talking about him. If you've seen him, go; go tell it on the mountains, over the hills and everywhere. Jesus Christ is born!

fields.verse: Part 14And there were shepherds living out in the fields nearby, keeping watch over their flocks at night. An angel of the Lord appeared to them, and the glory of the Lord shone around them, and they were terrified. But the angel said to them, “Do not be afraid. I bring you good news that will cause great joy for all the people. - Luke 2:8‭-‬10 (NIV)
fields.content: Simple shepherds would care for their sheep in the pastures surrounding Bethlehem. They would occasionally sling a carefully aimed stone in the direction of a sheep that wandered a bit too far, to turn it back to the fold. Perhaps in the cool of the evening they would pull out a lyre and tenderly play to soothe the sheep before they bedded down for the night. The shepherd would unwrap the chunk of bread, a few figs and some cheese he had packed, that would tide him over till the night watch was over. Suddenly, an angel appeared, unexpected, and seemingly out of nowhere. Light exploded with a radiance that expelled the darkness! The first reaction of a good shepherd would be to grab his staff and sling, to protect his sheep. But, the angel spoke and his first words were; "Do not be afraid." He had good news, not just for the shepherds but for all the people. The long wait for the Messiah has ended! In a typical night, marked by obedience and diligence to everyday responsibilities, with the hope of redemption relegated to summering in the back of their hearts and minds, everything would change in an instant. The angelic choir had rehearsed, prepared to welcome the Redeemer, the Prince of Peace, the King of Glory! Most nights of our lives are uneventful, but not this night.

fields.verse: Part 13In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God. He was with God in the beginning. Through him all things were made; without him nothing was made that has been made.
