In him was life, and that life was the light of all mankind. . .The Word became flesh and made his dwelling among us. We have seen his glory, the glory of the one and only Son, who came from the Father, full of grace and truth. - John 1:1-4, 14 (NIV)
fields.content: Before He was present in time, He existed in eternity. Before anything was made, He was there to create it. He is bigger than His universe, yet capable of making himself small enough to live in a virgin's womb. The God who sat majestically enthroned, ruling his kingdom, traded his robe for swaddling cloths. The All Powerful became vulnerable, defenseless, dependent, and in this Incarnation manifested his glory, grace, and truth. This was the miracle that occurred in the stable; the invisible God became flesh. He who was other, became ordinary. He came to experience the fallen world as we know it, and to rescue us from its brokenness. "You shall call his name Jesus, for he'll save his people from sin."  (To be continued)

fields.verse: Part 12While they were there, the time came for the baby to be born, - Luke 2:6 (NIV)
fields.content: Unlike the quiet pastoral scene many envision of the day of Jesus' birth, Bethlehem was noisy and crowded. It was filled with sojourners who had traveled from all over Israel to comply with Caesar's decree to participate in the census. Shopkeepers hawked their wares competing noisily with each other. Traveling teachers and philosophers filled the air with their words of sophisticated, and often confusing, knowledge and wisdom. The lines for the census takers were long. In the midst of this hustle and bustle, and the cacophony of voices, Mary felt her first contractions. 90 miles away from home surrounded by strangers, and unable to secure a room, she was offered a stable, for there was no guest room available: not exactly how she and Joseph had planned it. She settled in as the rhythm of her labor increased in intensity. From God's perspective, she was right on time. Sometimes he chooses a bad day to give us a good day.

fields.verse: Part 11In those days Caesar Augustus issued a decree that a census should be taken of the entire Roman world. . . And everyone went to their own town to register. So Joseph also went up from the town of Nazareth in Galilee to Judea, to Bethlehem the town of David, because he belonged to the house and line of David. He went there to register with Mary, who was pledged to be married to him and was expecting a child. While they were there, the time came for the baby to be born - Luke 2:1‭-‬6 (NIV)
fields.content: No detail in God's plan is overlooked. Everything happens at its appointed time. Careful planning and execution erases any possibility of coincidence and sets an outcome on the bedrock of certainty. The prophet Micah foretold the Messiah would come from Bethlehem. (5:2) Joseph and Mary lived in Nazareth. With today's modern roads, the two towns are separated by 94 miles. But it had to happen exactly as God planned it. Mary was on the tail end of her pregnancy but prompted by a census decree from Caesar, off to Bethlehem it would be. On dusty, hilly, paths, surrounded by fellow travelers oblivious to what was happening, they made their way to fulfill their appointment with destiny. It was a race against time, and God is never late.

fields.verse: Part 10This is how the birth of Jesus the Messiah came about: His mother Mary was pledged to be married to Joseph, but before they came together, she was found to be pregnant through the Holy Spirit. Because Joseph her husband was faithful to the law, and yet did not want to expose her to public disgrace, he had in mind to divorce her quietly. But after he had considered this, an angel of the Lord appeared to him in a dream and said, “Joseph son of David, do not be afraid to take Mary home as your wife, because what is conceived in her is from the Holy Spirit. She will give birth to a son, and you are to give him the name Jesus, because he will save his people from their sins.” - Matthew 1:18-21 (NIV)
fields.content: An immaculate conception, a virgin giving birth, the Son of God being introduced to the world: imagine being Mary and Joseph having to explain what had just happened! Who would believe them? How disappointed or outraged would the family be? An unwed woman who was pregnant violated the norms of a highly moral and spiritual culture. The penalty was to be stoned to death or at minimum be ostracized to the fringes having to raise her child in shame and poverty. But, Joseph took her as his wife in obedience to his own encounter with the angel. This was no ordinary scandal, but it was Mary's and Joseph's secret to keep. Their love for each other compelled them to trust God in a most unique circumstance. Together they pondered and waited. The fullness of time was coalescing seamlessly. The atmosphere of heaven was pregnant with anticipation. The world was now mere months away from being introduced to the Savior.

fields.verse: The Incarnation, Part 9Therefore the Lord himself will give you a sign: The virgin will conceive and give birth to a son. . . In the sixth month of Elizabeth’s pregnancy, God sent the angel Gabriel to Nazareth, a town in Galilee, to a virgin pledged to be married to a man named Joseph, a descendant of David. The virgin’s name was Mary. - Isaiah 7:14; Luke 1:26‭-‬27 (NIV)
fields.content: From the time of Isaiah's prophecy to the time of the angel's visit, every family descendant from King David, hoped they would be chosen to birth the Messiah. There would be no greater honor. God chose Mary, a virgin, to be his vessel for the promised Redeemer. The nameless, faceless virgin of Isaiah, was about to be revealed and take her place in history. Her place of honor would be secured, no one would be able to dislodge her from being a focal person in the history of redemption. The angel called her, "highly favored," How many times would she have to return to those words as she witnessed her son's life evolve from a child of great promise into that of a simple carpenter? But God's word would be fulfilled. Just as he plucked Mary from anonymity, he would call out her son to take his place in the Story and become the most famous man in all of history. Small, seemingly insignificant people take on prominent roles in God's narrative. Anonymous, the virgin of Isaiah, was given a name, Mary...and her son would soon be named as well. To be continued...

fields.verse: Part 8Then an angel of the Lord appeared to him, standing at the right side of the altar of incense. . .In the sixth month of Elizabeth’s pregnancy, God sent the angel Gabriel to Nazareth, a town in Galilee, to a virgin pledged to be married to a man named Joseph, a descendant of David. The virgin’s name was Mary. . .But after he had considered this, an angel of the Lord appeared to him in a dream and said, “Joseph son of David, do not be afraid to take Mary home as your wife, because what is conceived in her is from the Holy Spirit. - (Luke 1:11; 26-27, Matthew 1:20 (NIV)
fields.content: It is widely believed that Gabriel is the angel delivering the message to Zechariah, Mary, and Joseph. How he was chosen by God, we can only speculate. The sanctified imagination is given permission to ponder what might have happened.  God summoned the legions of angels who serve him. They stand at attention, majestic in their splendor, tall, muscular, fit, and waiting for orders from their Commander in Chief. As he walks up and down between the ranks, he stops at one. For reasons only know in heaven, Gabriel was entrusted with the mission to deliver the message that the kingdom of heaven was about to pierce into the timeline of human history. Gabriel drops down to one knee, looks into the face of the Ancient of Days, nods in agreement, and with one mighty thrust takes to the sky to traverse the heavens. At the precise time ordained by God, Gabriel appears to: a woman beyond her child-bearing years, a virgin who was not yet married, and a young man who's love and faith in his bride to be, would be tested beyond limits. Gabriel delivers the message. He feels humbled to have been chosen and proud to have accomplished his task. The world would be irreversibly changed, the Messiah was about to be revealed.

"This is how the birth of Jesus the Messiah came about: His mother Mary was pledged to be married to Joseph, but before they came together, she was found to be pregnant through the Holy Spirit." - Matthew 1:18 (NIV)Miraculous pregnancies are scattered throughout the biblical text, but this one was more than unusual; it was not from the normal union of a man and woman. The Spirit of God conceived a child in a virgin womb. Impossible? Not if we follow the prophetic narrative. It started in the garden with the promise of the seed of the woman. (Gen.3:15) Isaiah speaks about a virgin conceiving (7:14), and a root coming from dry ground (53:2). The infinite will intersect with the finite. God who is other becomes one of us. How else could he be birthed if not from a virgin. He would be born uncorrupted and incorruptible. The pristine Mary and the humble Joseph would be the chosen vessels to usher in the reconciliation of man to God. They would call his name Jesus, for he would save his people from sin.

fields.verse: Part 6This is the genealogy of Jesus the Messiah the son of David, the son of Abraham: ...and Jacob the father of Joseph, the husband of Mary, and Mary was the mother of Jesus who is called the Messiah. - Matthew 1:1, 16 (NIV)
fields.content: If we look deep enough into our genealogy, we will find royalty and robbers, saints and sinners, and a lot of nondescript people in between. Whichever tells the more interesting story is the one that will be talked about at parties and family reunions. What stands out in the genealogy of Jesus is that he never used his family tree to justify or fortify his claim to Davidic royalty, while others tried to delegitimize him by referring to him as the son of Mary. Some saw royalty, some saw a robber. Some saw a saint, others saw a sinner. Some saw a mere man, while others saw the Messiah. As we travel further into this season of Advent, what will we see? In the midst of the celebration of the season, amongst the myriad of twinkling lights in the darkness surrounding us, we find the son of David, the son of Abraham, the Light of the world.

fields.verse: Part 5After Jesus was born in Bethlehem in Judea, during the time of King Herod, Magi from the east came to Jerusalem and asked, “Where is the one who has been born king of the Jews? We saw his star when it rose and have come to worship him.” - Matthew 2:1‭-‬2 (NIV)
fields.content: Wait! Isn't this event being dealt with out of chronological order? A brief explanation is required. In the East, what used to be Persia and is now modern day Iran, there were stargazers who studied the heavens looking for changes in the configuration of stars and planets that might signify the coming of important events. It is most likely the Wise Men saw the bright star, or a conjunction of planets (where the synchronized orbit of planets bring them in line and shine as one bright emanation in space) and associated it with the birth of a great king. As the great light moved in the heavens and became brighter, they planned their journey to follow and find where the star would reach the zenith of its movement and then start to recede. It was at that point and place the Wise Men believed they would find what they were looking for. They loaded up their caravan, laden with supplies and gifts, followed the star, and were led to Bethlehem...a journey of over 1,000 miles. Before Jesus was manifested to the world, he was already being sought in dedicated earnest. Even today we are surrounded by seekers. They haven't arrived yet, but Bethlehem awaits.

fields.verse: The Incarnation, Part 4And you, my child, will be called a prophet of the Most High; for you will go on before the Lord to prepare the way for him, to give his people the knowledge of salvation through the forgiveness of their sins, because of the tender mercy of our God, by which the rising sun will come to us from heaven to shine on those living in darkness and in the shadow of death, to guide our feet into the path of peace.” And the child grew and became strong in spirit; and he lived in the wilderness until he appeared publicly to Israel. - Luke 1:76‭-‬80 (NIV)
fields.content: Whether it is a political event, a concert, a sporting event, or a business convention, it usually opens with a warm up act, whose responsibility it is to set the crowd's mood for the main event. One can always tell how important the main event will be by the quality of the undercard. These opening acts are more important than we may realize. They are often up and coming stars or veterans with a history of success who want to pave the way for future talent. Enter John the Baptizer. His was a revolutionary message. By his approach, teachings and actions, he directed his audience's attention to see and understand that the future of the faith lay not in Temple rituals and oppressive attention to the fine details of the Law. Salvation would come through a righteousness based on repentance and hope in the coming Messiah. The message of faith, apart from works shook the establishment to the core. John's message cleared the path for Jesus. Pay attention to the predecessors. Listen to their message. When the main act takes the stage, we will be primed to respond and have a life-changing experience.

fields.verse: The Incarnation, Part 3But when the set time had fully come, God sent his Son, born of a woman, born under the law, to redeem those under the law, that we might receive adoption to sonship. - Galatians 4:4‭-‬5 (NIV)
fields.content: Why did it take so long for the Messiah to be revealed? Timing is extremely important. All things must be in order for the precise implementation of God's plan. The lesson can be learned in how God revealed to Abram how the land he had promised him, and the yet to be created nation of Israel, would have to wait until conditions were perfect. "In the fourth generation your descendants will come back here, for the sin of the Amorites has not yet reached its full measure.” (Genesis 15:16) The Israelites did not descend upon an unsuspecting, innocent people to steal their land; they were sent as an instrument of judgement to eradicate a people who had reached their peak in worshipping grotesque idols and killing, raping, and robbing each other. God gave the Amorites time, 400 years, to experience the consequences of rejecting him, all the while sending his prophets calling them to repent and return to Him. The timing was perfect. The Amorites were without excuse; and that was a good thing. The choice couldn't be any clearer. The Genesis story is a microcosm of the condition of the world. Fast forward another 1400 years, God waited until the fullness of time to reveal the seed of the woman. The conditions were perfect to introduce the Savior to the world. He could not have come at a better time.

fields.verse: Part Two.The Lord God said to the serpent, “Because you have done this, Cursed are you more than all cattle, And more than every beast of the field; On your belly you will go, And dust you will eat All the days of your life; And I will put enmity Between you and the woman, And between your seed and her seed; He shall bruise you on the head, And you shall bruise him on the heel.” - Genesis 3:14‭-‬15 (NASB)
fields.content: Adam and Eve sinned and immediately sensed a shift in the balance of their intimacy with God. God pronounced a curse on the earth, but also planted a seed of hope for the crowning jewel of his creation. Salvation was offered and the severed relationship would be restored. A male child (he) will appear, born of a woman (her seed) not a man, who would deliver a fatal blow to the serpent. The promise of a coming Messiah was made, and the plan of salvation began its unveiling to be fully displayed at the right time, in the right place. . . (to be continued)

fields.verse: Part One:He was chosen before the creation of the world, but was revealed in these last times for your sake. - 1 Peter 1:20 (NIV)
fields.content: It all started before it began. We pivot now to the great event of the Incarnation. Before a single galaxy was sprayed into the darkness of space, before our solar system was intricately choreographed, before the 3rd Rock from the Sun was carefully landscaped and manicured to sustain life as we know it, the Triune God designed the plan that would result in fashioning a people, made in His image, who would worship Him in Spirit and Truth. Then He spoke, and it all came into existence. For centuries history has plodded towards it's redemptive destination; it is all going down as planned. The Incarnation would set the path leading to the Crucifixion, the focal point in the history of redemption. In turn, the Crucifixion would make the Resurrection, God's definitive statement about his love for his creation; we would be saved from the penalty of sin. In the heart and mind of God, in the timelessness of eternity past, it all started before it began.

fields.verse: And this gospel of the kingdom will be preached in the whole world as a testimony to all nations, and then the end will come. - Matthew 24:14 (NIV)
fields.content: How close are we to the last day of the last days? Jesus said the earth would be plagued by calamities. Earthquakes, famine, and disease would be signs that we are living in the last days. He also pointed out that wars and rumors of war would be prevalent, and a great crisis of faith, a falling away, would occur before the great Day of His Return. Of notable interest is that all these things have already taken place repeatedly during the cyclical course of recorded history. Perhaps we are more aware today because the 24/7 news cycle brings it to our attention in real time, but Jesus reminded us not to give these occurrences undue attention for there was one overriding thing that must happen before his return; the Gospel must be preached to all nations. Currently there are 195 countries in the world. Within these nations are people groups with their own language and culture who have little to no knowledge of the gospel. Of the over 8 billion people in the world today, evidence suggests that 1-3 billion live in these unreached groups. Efforts are accelerating to bring the good news of Jesus to every corner of the world and modern technology is making it possible for all to eventually hear. The wars, famine, and cataclysms will continue, but it will be our successful effort to reach the lost that will open the door to his Second Coming. Go, tell it on the mountain, over the hills and everywhere!

fields.verse: No one could say a word in reply, and from that day on no one dared to ask him any more questions. - Matthew 22:46 (NIV)
fields.content: There comes a day when the questions cease. We see in Jesus: a miraculous birth followed by a stellar life, teaching that left scholars amazed and yet was understood by simple fishermen, miracles of healing stunned the physicians of his day, he suspended the laws of nature by calming a storm with the power of his words, he walked on water, and he brought the dead back to life. What other proof is needed. Patiently, and compassionately, directly and through parables, over a period of three years he took the time to reveal the indisputable evidence that he was the Messiah they were awaiting. The religious leaders of his day knew they had reached a fork in the road. They must choose to be for him or against him. They chose a different path. Lest there be any doubt, while the plot to kill him was accelerating, the plan to bring redemption to the lost was right on schedule. Soon it would be time for his final proof. There would be no final questions to ask, only a decision to make.

fields.verse: At that time the disciples came to Jesus and asked, 'Who, then, is the greatest in the kingdom of heaven?' He called a little child to him, and placed the child among them. And he said: 'Truly I tell you, unless you change and become like little children, you will never enter the kingdom of heaven. Therefore, whoever takes the lowly position of this child is the greatest in the kingdom of heaven. And whoever welcomes one such child in my name welcomes me.'  Matthew 18:1‭-‬5 (NIV)
fields.content: Interact with a child and at once we get transferred into their world. Theirs is an existence where endless questions abound. Their favorite question is "Why?"as they push adults to the limits of their knowledge. We play peek-a-boo, and our hands over our faces is enough to make us disappear. We hold entire conversations on toy phones and every one of their smiles is paid back with a smile of our own. Children live lives of innocence, dependence, and inquisitiveness.  They start out mirroring their surroundings, and it takes wise, loving, patient adults to teach them discernment, and show them the way they should grow. Theirs is a blank slate where the story of their lives are written. God desires a father/child relationship with us. Being a child of God is the highest calling we can attain. He is our provider, protector, and guide. A child will always, in some way be a child in the eyes of their parents. This is a relationship that we should never seek to outgrow.

fields.verse: Then Peter came to Jesus and asked, “Lord, how many times shall I forgive my brother or sister who sins against me? Up to seven times?” Jesus answered, “I tell you, not seven times, but seventy-seven times. - Matthew 18:21‭-‬22 (NIV)
fields.content: Maybe it's me, but don't you think that after the third or fourth offense we should avoid a person who offends us? Sometimes it's not possible. The offensive person may be a family member, a neighbor, or coworker. Everytime we turn around, they are there. Our quality of life is influenced by how we respond to offensive people. If we carry a grudge, we accept an illegitimate burden. If we respond by fighting fire with fire, there's a good chance both parties will be burned. If we ignore the offense, it may fester, unresolved. Jesus reminds us that forgiveness is God's default. Forgiveness is not passive, it seeks to disarm a situation in the pursuit of advantageous common ground. The goal is to win the offensive person over. That takes time, courage, patience, and wisdom. It may happen on the third opportunity to forgive, or the 7th, the 27th or the 77th. Winning over an offensive person rarely happens by engaging them on the issue of contention. Be the one who proactively deflects offenses and seeks peace. The best way to get rid of an enemy is to make them a friend.

fields.verse: When Jesus came to the region of Caesarea Philippi, he asked his disciples, 'Who do people say the Son of Man is?' They replied, 'Some say John the Baptist; others say Elijah; and still others, Jeremiah or one of the prophets.' 'But what about you?' he asked. 'Who do you say I am?' Simon Peter answered, 'You are the Messiah, the Son of the living God.' Jesus replied, 'Blessed are you, Simon son of Jonah, for this was not revealed to you by flesh and blood, but by my Father in heaven.' - Matthew 16:13‭-‬17 (NIV)
fields.content: "If you've got pain,  He's a pain taker.  If you feel lost,  He's a way maker.  If you need freedom or saving,  He's a prison-shaking Savior.  If you've got chains,  He's a chain breaker." - Zach Williams"Way maker, miracle worker, promise keeper  Light in the darkness, my God  That is who You are" - LeelandJesus did a lot of things. There was his wonderful teaching and mind-blowing miracles, but it was Peter who first uttered the words that changed the dynamic of the disciple's relationship to Jesus. He recognized that the teaching and miracles were possible because of who Jesus is. We may have an encounter with Jesus and end up better taught, or physically and mentally healed, but the main reason for his coming was to save us, to reconcile us to God. Accepting the former will leave us in awe, embracing the latter will secure our eternal place of fellowship with the Father. It all boils down to recognizing who He is.

fields.verse: He said to them, 'Therefore every teacher of the law who has become a disciple in the kingdom of heaven is like the owner of a house who brings out of his storeroom new treasures as well as old.'” - Matthew 13:52 (NIV)
fields.content: A young man met a lovely lady and they expressed mutual interest in each other. Along the way he submitted his life to the lordship of Jesus which presented a dilemma because, although having been raised in a Christian home, the young lady had drifted from God. As he shared his fledgling faith, a renewed interest was triggered in her as well. He would spend long stretches of time reading the Bible; she in turn would help him understand from the store of insight she had from her childhood. They would stay up late at night and she would sing to him the hymns she had learned growing up. "The Old Rugged Cross and What a Friend we Have in Jesus" which added immensely to the foundation of his faith. As she rediscovered the joy of reading God's Word, she would share new insights. He grew quickly and his faith was solidified. Old and new treasures of faith became the core of their relationship with God and each other. It is difficult to live a solitary life of discipleship. Every generation and each individual must discover a personal faith, but they can profit from those who had a head start. Even when some of the treasure needs to pulled from the back of the storeroom and dusted off before they can be put on display, the knowledge and experience are indisputable riches to be invested in others. Pay it forward.

fields.verse: When he saw the crowds, he had compassion on them, because they were harassed and helpless, like sheep without a shepherd. Then he said to his disciples, “The harvest is plentiful but the workers are few. Ask the Lord of the harvest, therefore, to send out workers into his harvest field.” - Matthew 9:36‭-‬38 (NIV)
fields.content: A man and his family moved to a large city believing they were being led by God to do his work. They settled into an apartment in a busy hub of the city. After several days of getting to know their surroundings, the man began to doubt whether he had heard from the Lord. He awakened early one morning and sat by his living room window to pray. As he prayed he asked the Lord for clarity of calling. A still small voice could be discerned whispering into his soul."Look outside your window. What do you see?"  The man replied; "A giant forest of buildings as far as the eye can see."Then he discerned another question:  "What else do you see?"  He answered: "Cars, buses, and trucks creeping along to their morning destinations.A third question was posed:  "What is in those buildings, cars, buses, and trucks?"The man began to choke up and could hardly get the words out of his mouth.  "People, lots of people."The last word he heard from that quiet, still voice was:  "Get started. They've been waiting for you and others I will send."

fields.verse: As Jesus went on from there, two blind men followed him, calling out, “Have mercy on us, Son of David!” When he had gone indoors, the blind men came to him, and he asked them, “Do you believe that I am able to do this?” “Yes, Lord,” they replied. Then he touched their eyes and said, “According to your faith let it be done to you” - Matthew 9:27‭-‬29 (NIV)
fields.content: Seeing is believing, but in the case of this passage, believing is seeing. The Age of Reason, began in the 17th century and was developed and refined through the 19th century. During this period: science, philosophy, and even theology, posited that belief was valid only if it could be observed and synthesized through the senses and reason. Absence of sufficient facts relegated any thoughts or ideas to the categories of fable, superstition, or blind faith. The senses and the mind ruled over the "unobservable and unprovable". Its influence still rules today. Jesus didn't ask the blind men for a detailed history of their malady. He didn't gather up facts, and conduct tests to confirm whether their blindness was curable. There was only one question; did the blind men believe Jesus could do what they were asking? When they replied in the affirmative, Jesus touched their eyes and their vision was restored. Even as the facts verified their blindness, their faith is credited for their ability to see. They believed, and they saw. Some things can only be seen if they are believed.

fields.verse: This is the meaning of the parable . . . - Luke 8:11 (NIV)
fields.content: "It ain't those parts of the Bible that I can't understand that bother me, it is the parts that I do understand." (Mark Twain) We search the Scriptures looking for deeper meaning and often walk past the obvious. Some believers twist themselves into pretzels trying to figure out how the present fits into the equation of the end times, all the while making an insufficient effort to take the easier path leading to an understanding of God's personality, passion, and plan. Jesus taught in parables: simple stories that carry profound truth. When his disciples would get confused or embroiled in debate as to what his parables meant, he followed his teaching with a simple explanation; complex truth became easy to understand. When the parable of life itself seems to overwhelm us, try the simplest interpretation of the story surrounding the facts. A futile search for a more complex, all encompassing answer, often puts us in a position of missing the simple truth that answers a universal question. Keep it simple. Sometimes, a lot of the time, it's just not that complicated.

fields.verse: One of those days Jesus went out to a mountainside to pray, and spent the night praying to God. When morning came, he called his disciples to him and chose twelve of them, whom he also designated apostles: - Luke 6:12‭-‬13 (NIV)
fields.content: Life is chock full of decisions that need to be made; some are simple, while others are complex. According to Adrian Camilleri, Ph.D., the most consequential decisions fall in the categories of: Career, Education,  Family, Finances, Relationships, Relocation, Self-Destruction, Self-Development. There are subcategories under each, but these general categories have the potential to be life changing so therefore decisions are to made only after careful deliberation. Allowing the circumstances of the moment to rule can be disastrous. Jesus had a very important decision to make that would change the trajectory of his calling and the lives of his potential followers. Jesus retreated to pray. Sound familiar? It should; he did it often. But this time it was an all-nighter. He wasn't tossing and turning while laying on a mat in the darkness of the mountainside; His was a concentrated effort directed to his Father seeking wisdom and direction. When he was done, he chose twelve to live out a special calling. Twelve who would experience and then broadcast the purpose of His coming. Twelve who would change the world, but only after having their worlds changed. Decisions have consequences. Big decisions have big consequences. Extended, focused prayer is the key component in making the correct big decision.

fields.verse: But Jesus often withdrew to lonely places and prayed. - Luke 5:16 (NIV)
fields.content: Jesus was a busy man. When he wasn't teaching, he was giving sight to the blind, casting out demons, and healing the sick. Then he would use those miracles as a point of reference for more teaching. It is no wonder that he found a need to withdraw, to recharge. What is discreet in this little verse is that he withdrew "often." We can infer a couple of things: the hectic pace of his ministry drained him; the intensity of his calling demanded he draw his strength from the Spirit. If we look at the needs around us, we may be tempted to think that we can't take time off. But, if we don't replenish our depleted souls, we tend to work harder and experience diminishing results. Jesus knew he needed supernatural strength. He sought out times and places to meet with God. If Jesus needed those pauses, and retreats, we need them too. Take time to refill your soul. . .often.

fields.verse: And should I not have concern for the great city of Nineveh, in which there are more than a hundred and twenty thousand people who cannot tell their right hand from their left—and also many animals?” - Jonah 4:11 (NIV)
fields.content: The Book of Jonah ends rather abruptly with a question. Is it rhetorical in that the answer is obvious and it's the end of the story, or is it intended to give us something to think or even talk about? Unanswered questions are intriguing. They seem to follow us wherever we go and resist being ignored. In this case we may be inclined to ask; What happened to Jonah? Did he resolve his anger? Was Jonah's mind open to accept that the love, mercy, and grace of God could be extended beyond His people, Israel? What about the Ninevites? Did they receive the reprieve from God's judgement with joy? If so, how long did they celebrate? It may be that God simply closes the story for us to focus on what actually happened and not speculate on the woulda, coulda, shouldas. The little book of Jonah focuses on redemption over judgement. To this day, it is still the heart of the Good News. Whether Nineveh, Moscow or Mumbai; Melbourne, Belfast or Bogota; New York, Chicago, or Los Angeles; wherever there is sin, God's grace abounds. And where God's grace is abundant, redemption is only one messenger, one prayer, away.

fields.verse: But to Jonah this seemed very wrong, and he became angry. . .But the Lord replied, 'Is it right for you to be angry?' - Jonah 4:1‭, ‬4 (NIV)
fields.content: Jesus taught us: "It is not the healthy who need a doctor, but the sick." The Apostle Paul also makes it clear: ". . .God demonstrates his own love for us in this: While we were still sinners, Christ died for us." Somehow we've become convinced of two erroneous thoughts: the scales of justice can only be balanced by doing enough good deeds to counter sin, or punishment that is equal to the infraction must be dispensed. But, genuine repentance stops judgement dead in its track. God wanted Jonah to know that being forgiven and offering forgiveness is better than evening the score. The same grace that Jonah benefitted from was extended to the Ninevites and Jonah became angry. God asks Jonah if he had a right to be angry. There is no answer recorded in Scripture, but the context says it all.

fields.verse: When Jonah’s warning reached the king of Nineveh, he rose from his throne, took off his royal robes, covered himself with sackcloth and sat down in the dust . . . When God saw what they did and how they turned from their evil ways, he relented and did not bring on them the destruction he had threatened. - Jonah 3:6‭, ‬10 (NIV)
fields.content: Despite his reluctance, Jonah delivered God's message to Nineveh and the results were astounding. Even the king was moved to repent. True to his character, God withheld his judgment in response to their repentance. Resistant, angry, fear-filled messengers cannot hinder the intentions of God. He works with, or around our weaknesses, to fulfill his plan. Working together, Word and Spirit perform wondrous works; it is a reminder that despite our faults, it is ultimately God who makes things happen. Whatever the task, regardless of our shortcomings, be obedient to carry the light to the darkest places of our lives. Remember, it's about the Message, not the messenger.

fields.verse: But to Jonah this seemed very wrong, and he became angry. He prayed to the Lord, 'Isn’t this what I said, Lord, when I was still at home? That is what I tried to forestall by fleeing to Tarshish. I knew that you are a gracious and compassionate God, slow to anger and abounding in love, a God who relents from sending calamity. Now, Lord, take away my life, for it is better for me to die than to live.' - Jonah 4:1‭-‬3 (NIV)
fields.content: Jonah would rather die than be right. Jonah wanted judgment for Nineveh. He wanted them to be punished for the evil and oppression they had inflicted on Israel. Although he knew that God's default position was to extend grace rather than judgment, Jonah thought justice would be better served through punishing the Ninevites. What he wanted was at odds with what God would do. The wounds from our enemies can be deep and painful. The memories serve as a hounding reminder of our hurt. In our pain, we want to exact our pound of flesh. It is true; hurt people, hurt people. But the cycle of pain needs to be broken, and forgiveness is the cure. God's offer to the Ninevites, if accepted, would stop them from further inflicting pain on Jonah and Israel. Jonah chose to dwell on his previous pain and scars, forgiveness for Nineveh seemed unfair. Yet to this day, if we let go of our pain for a moment, we are reminded that grace and mercy triumph over judgment. It's as true today as it was then. Choose forgiveness.

fields.verse: Then the word of the Lord came to Jonah a second time: 'Go to the great city of Nineveh and proclaim to it the message I give you.' Jonah obeyed the word of the Lord and went to Nineveh . . . - Jonah 3:1‭-‬3 (NIV)
fields.content: Every day comes with a myriad of choices and occasionally a second chance. Obviously we would rather walk through life unecumbered by the consequences of bad choices, but for most of us, that's not possible. We dream of a do over, a second chance. When speaking to someone whose life is shipwrecked, the predictable story is that, although they can point to one incidence that tipped the scale, it was a series of bad choices that got them where they are. Sandwiched in between those choices however, were opportunities to make course corrections. Even when the dominoes began to fall, there were still incidences where the disaster may have, and still could be, averted. From the garden in Genesis to the present day, God gives us second chances. So rich is his grace, he often extends to us a second chance to a second chance. Whether we are running away, experiencing a tumultuous voyage on a ship in an angry sea, if the sea is sucking us under and our lungs are filling with water, even if we find ourselves in the belly of a proverbial big fish, God is there to offer a second chance. Jonah didn't end up in Tarshish or on a boat, in the ocean, or the belly of a fish. Jonah took advantage of his second chance and obeyed the Lord. He wound up in Nineveh proclaiming the word of the Lord that changed lives. Take advantage of second chances.

fields.verse: From inside the fish Jonah prayed to the Lord his God. He said: “In my distress I called to the Lord, and he answered me. . . From deep in the realm of the dead I called for help, and you listened to my cry. The engulfing waters threatened me, the deep surrounded me; seaweed was wrapped around my head. . . “When my life was ebbing away, I remembered you, Lord, and my prayer rose to you, to your holy temple. - Jonah 2:1‭-‬2‭, ‬5‭, ‬7 (NIV)
fields.content: A closer look at this chapter helps us understand how God fulfills his promise of never leaving or forsaking us. At first glance we see Jonah sitting in the belly of a big fish rehearsing what had just happened and making amends with God. On closer inspection we find that Jonah had his "come to God moment" not in the belly of the fish, but before he was swallowed. As the waters surrounded him, he could hold his breath no longer. As salt water was filling his mouth and the light of his eyes became dim, Jonah remembered and called out to God. God answered his prayer by sending a big fish to save him. The belly of the fish was a divinely appointed "time out" where for three days Jonah was able to rethink the consequences of disobedience. It was then that the fish spit him out onto dry land. When we turn our backs on God, he follows, even to the depths of the sea. When we are drowning in the sea of disobedience God is there. When the prospect of death is becoming clearer even as the light in our eyes grows dimmer, God is there accompanying us to death's door. When we cry out in desperation, God answers. He delivers us, sometimes in incredulous ways. He often sends us to a time out room to have our calling restored, and then sets us back on the right road.

fields.verse: The word of the Lord came to Jonah son of Amittai: “Go to the great city of Nineveh and preach against it, because its wickedness has come up before me.” But Jonah ran away from the Lord and headed for Tarshish. He went down to Joppa . . . - Jonah 1:1‭-‬3 (NIV)
fields.content: We'd like to think that, if the Lord spoke clearly to us, we'd obey without hesitation. In Jonah's case, he disobeyed without delay. He was called to warn the Ninevites that their wickedness was about to experience the judgement of God. Jonah did not want to go there. Was it fear that kept Jonah from going? After all, the Ninevites were a wicked people known for their extreme treatment of their enemies. Did Jonah fear that he would be wasting his time preaching to a people who weren't interested or even hostile to a message from an Israelite God? We find out later (3:2) that what Jonah actually feared was success. Although the Ninevites had treated Israel with harshness, contempt, and defeat, Jonah felt that severe judgment on Nineveh was called for. He also knew that in lieu of judgment, God would offer grace if they repented. We know the story. God steered Jonah to rethink his reluctance to preach to Nineveh. The Ninevites did indeed repent and Jonah was not happy about it. God operates under the axiom that salvation is always better than judgment, even when we think that judgment is deserved.

fields.verse: Remember your leaders, who spoke the word of God to you. Consider the outcome of their way of life and imitate their faith . . . Have confidence in your leaders and submit to their authority, because they keep watch over you as those who must give an account. Do this so that their work will be a joy, not a burden, for that would be of no benefit to you. - Hebrews 13:7‭, ‬17 (NIV)
fields.content: Many of the most important contributors to the ease and comfort of our lives labor under the shroud of anonymity. We know very little of those who build our bridges, pave our roads, work our farms, or drive our products to market. More people recognize the names of Ye, Beyonce, Tom Brady, and Elon Musk, than can tell us the names of local, state and federal politicians. (The latter may not be a bad thing, but that's a different subject altogether.) People matter to us for different reasons. Some of the reasons are trivial, some are significant. We remember our favorite teacher, coach, choir director, or doctor. Who can forget the attendant at our favorite deli who piled on the corned beef for our sandwich? Certain people come into our lives and make a bigger than life impression. The Scriptures (1 Timothy 3, and Titus 1) list the qualifications of ministry leadership. Prayerfully look for those who live up to their calling. Trust them, imitate them, as they emulate Jesus. Cooperate with them to accomplish the purposes of God. If you are blessed with such leadership, remember them...especially in your prayers.

fields.verse: Therefore, since we are receiving a kingdom that cannot be shaken, let us be thankful, and so worship God acceptably with reverence and awe, for our “God is a consuming fire.” - Hebrews 12:28‭-‬29 (NIV)
fields.content: Acceptable worship of God consists of contented familiarity founded on reverence and awe. Sweet fellowship and communion await us as we make our way to his throne room as beloved children of God. But it wasn't long before when we were disqualified from entering his presence, objects of his wrath and scorn. His displeasure can be described as a precisely aimed lightning bolt in a thunderous storm, ready to strike and consume us with fiery fury. But his love is greater than his anger. He offered us redemption through the Cross. It was there our peace was secured. The fire that could effectually consume us was replaced with the warmth of his accepting embrace. True, sincere worship understands both sides of this mystery. Because God has canceled the penalty of our sin; we are able to rest in the pleasure of His presence. Enter in.

fields.verse: By faith we understand. . . Hebrews 11:3 (NIV)
fields.content: When the facts fall short, and an outcome we didn't expect, or didn't want, seems a be a forgone conclusion, what do we do? In many cases we go back to reinterpret the facts, or conclude that we didn't have all the facts. In the case of promises from God, where do facts fit in? Facts tell us that: seas don't part (especially at the precise time they are needed to part), manna doesn't appear out of nowhere, abundant water doesn't flow from a rock in the middle of a desert, shoes and clothes don't last 40 years, donkeys don't talk, axe heads don't float, people don't walk on water, and it's a process to turn water into wine. All of the above are recorded in Scripture; none can be explained by facts alone...although that hasn't stopped many from trying. Twenty-one times in this chapter alone, the Bible uses the phrase "by faith." Faith doesn't negate facts; faith expands the definition and understanding of facts to include that which we cannot know by senses and feelings alone. Faith acknowledges that sometimes the facts, as we know them, are not enough to provoke us forward in our pursuit of God. We see by faith that which cannot be seen in facts. The rationalist leans on facts, the righteous live by faith.

fields.verse: And without faith it is impossible to please God, because anyone who comes to him must believe that he exists and that he rewards those who earnestly seek him. - Hebrews 11:6 (NIV)
fields.content: The first step to saving faith is simply believing that there exists some sort of Higher Power. At first, the primitive belief may be difficult to identify or describe, but the idea begins when the complexities around us become almost impossible to explain without resorting to faith statements of some sort. For example, the beginning of life. Because all of life in existence has some DNA overlap, we make the assumption that it all has a common source. It is at that point where a step of faith is taken in connecting the dots. Anthropologists, botanists, chemists, and physicists, all take divergent paths trying to answer the questions of how and where life began. Even theologians and mystics get in on the query. All resulting in different hypotheses of the origins of life. In the midst of that quest is the yearning to know. The sincere seeker continues feeding that simple faith. It is there where the Answer can be found, and God would be pleased to reveal Himself.

fields.verse: But we do not belong to those who shrink back and are destroyed, but to those who have faith and are saved. Hebrews 10:39 (NIV)
fields.content: The Washington Generals are an American basketball team who play exhibition games against the Harlem Globetrotters. Their role is to try to look competitive while the Globetrotters do their comedic routine. They lose almost all the time. At one time they had a 2,495 game losing streak. They play, not expecting to win. They may well be the losingest team in all of sports. At one time, we too were on the losing team. Not only did we not expect to win, but we were destined to lose. But God in his rich mercy and grace, recruited us to play for his team. He provided us with the best Coach and Playbook. We now take the floor confident, not only that we can, but that we will win. The best defense is to have a great offense for the team which scores the most points will always win. When the last buzzer sounds, the score will be lopsided in our favor. Get in the game!

fields.verse: When God made his promise to Abraham, since there was no one greater for him to swear by, he swore by himself, saying, “I will surely bless you and give you many descendants.” And so after waiting patiently, Abraham received what was promised. - Hebrews 6:13‭-‬15 (NIV)
fields.content: He is as good as his word. He needs no one to vouch for him. His actions speak loudly, his words are crystal clear. It may take some time for the fruit of his promises to appear, but it's not because he is slow, or our need isn't of high enough priority. He gets no pleasure in watching us squirm or grovel. God's supernatural process of answering prayer is more concerned in what he is doing in us, than what he is doing for us. When Abraham's anxiety turned to patience, it ushered God's answer into reality. Each time God delivered, Abraham became stronger in his faith. So, make your requests to God. Look forward to his answer. Take inventory of what he has done for us and in us. These are points of reference for what is to come. He will answer.

fields.verse: In fact, though by this time you ought to be teachers, you need someone to teach you the elementary truths of God’s word all over again. You need milk, not solid food! Anyone who lives on milk, being still an infant, is not acquainted with the teaching about righteousness. But solid food is for the mature, who by constant use have trained themselves to distinguish good from evil. - Hebrews 5:12‭-‬14 (NIV)
fields.content: The longer we've been followers of Jesus, the more our thinking and behavior should reflect a growing maturity. Many believers have hit a stall in their relationship with God. We have found a cruising speed that works for us, consisting of: a pattern of church attendance, a few, select, memorized, go-to Scripture verses, a static level of giving, and a reasonable standard of behavior. We settle for sailing leisurely around a lagoon with a light wind at our back, barely leaving a ripple in the water. We tend to not want to stand out, or rock the boat. God has more. He has called us to man a warship sailing the seas, taming the winds, mastering the waves, overtaking slave runners, and fighting pirates. It takes a lot of expertise and experience to be a successful captain. We have our Captain. He knows the dangers and adventures of traversing the seven seas. He trains and equips his sailors and assigns them their roles. Some are deckhands providing auxiliary roles; others contribute learned and earned skills, and the experience needed to accomplish the mission. It's a voyage filled with danger, but the quest is richly gratifying. "A ship in a harbor is safe, but that is not what ships are built for." All hands on deck!

fields.verse: We have much to say about this, but it is hard to make it clear to you because you no longer try to understand. - Hebrews 5:11 (NIV)
fields.content: Relationships come to a grinding halt when one, the other, or both involved, reach a state of inertia. Objects tend to remain set. An unwillingness to move, or change can only be overcome by the  introduction of an outside force. If we are not careful, we can find a comfortable place in our relationships which may result in what we think is peaceful coexistence. But the nature of truth and knowledge is, there is always more to learn, to know, and to experience. Julius Caesar is credited for saying, "Veni. Vidi. Vici." (I came. I saw. I conquered.) He sensed his destiny was to rule over all civilization. He applied himself to making his destiny, reality. Believers are called to a different objective, what is called: fighting the good fight of faith. Our destiny is to live and reign with Jesus, but it is difficult to fight and win a battle from a comfortable seat away from the front line of battle. If we fail to engage, it may be that we have reached a state of inertia. We need an intervention. We may need a nudge, a shove, a swift kick in the pants; whatever it takes to move us forward. It all begins with your gottawanna.

fields.verse: Let us then approach God’s throne of grace with confidence, so that we may receive mercy and find grace to help us in our time of need. - Hebrews 4:16 (NIV)
fields.content: Perhaps we think of God as being too busy for us. After all, there are a lot of people with a lot of needs clamoring for his attention. Or maybe our need seems trivial in light of the important things that God is responsible for. Didn't God create us as intelligent beings capable of figuring things out for ourselves? Some of us think God is so angry that we dare not darken the doorway of his holy room with even the shadow of our presence, or we may not want to visit him because we don't want to add shame and judgement on top of our guilt. Let's not forget that we don't want to see the disappointment on his face for yet another failure on our part. All of these seem to be plausible excuses, but they leave us short of the solutions and peace we seek. Where God dwells and reigns is the place of grace and mercy. His door is wide open for us to approach him. No excuse is recognized or justified to deny us entry. There is a confidence and humility in approaching God. Confidence because he welcomes us as his children, and humility because even his children are subjects of the King. Enter; experience his grace and mercy. He's got time for you.

fields.verse: Nothing in all creation is hidden from God’s sight. Everything is uncovered and laid bare before the eyes of him to whom we must give account. - Hebrews 4:13 (NIV)
fields.content: A friend of mine was having a difficult time with a store manager who was refusing to give him a refund on a returned item. At one point he took a step back, looked up into the sky, and with folded hands said; " Lord, I know you see everything, but if you would turn your back for about 30 seconds, I could take care of this situation right here and now." Thankfully, God's ability to see everything can be a deterrent in certain situations. It can also serve as an eyewitness to steer our conscience. It's hard to deny that we said or did something if we know God was there. But lest we live in the paranoia of guilt, God also sees injustices against us, incidences that caused us pain, and the sorrow that leads to repentance. He witnesses our joy of being forgiven, and the peaceful sleep of a contented heart. Giving an account for our lives includes both sides of the equation, the good and the bad. Those who follow unrighteousness have much to be concerned about. But, for the faithful, the redeemed, the balance is calculated to our positive good.

fields.verse: Jesus has been found worthy of greater honor than Moses, just as the builder of a house has greater honor than the house itself. - Hebrews 3:3 (NIV)
fields.content: One of the most popular tourist attractions in Chicago, is the boat ride on the river featuring the skyscrapers of the city. Many of the edifices were built using technologies, techniques, and building materials that were new discoveries in their era. They stand as memorials and are named for businesses, politicians, and other dignitaries who have made a significant contribution defining the city. It's quite a fascinating tour. Not so clearly seen in the brilliance of these creations is the evidence that they all had a preexistence in the minds of the architects who took their imagination and skills, put it on paper, and then supervised the construction of these marvels. It is there where the miracle abides. Think for a second; those creative, imaginative architects had a Creator of their own! It's not only the buildings, builders, and architects who are worthy of note; there also exists a cosmic Designer behind and beyond it all! That is why, when we understand the mind behind the plan of salvation, we can more fully appreciate redemption itself, and we are left breathless at the beauty of it all.

fields.verse: We must pay the most careful attention, therefore, to what we have heard, so that we do not drift away. - Hebrews 2:1 (NIV)
fields.content: Details are important. An nth of a degree off of level at the beginning of construction, results in continual adjustment on other parts of the building threatening the integrity, or at the very least, the cosmetics of the project. We insist on detail oriented surgeons, automobile and plane manufacturers, and bridge builders; anything less could be catastrophic. In the matter of the quality of our relationship with God, we must strive to live it by the Book. Any effort to adlib or fly by the seat of our pants will be met by a failure to stay on track and a constant adjustment of our course, making it difficult to enjoy the ride. It's been said: "Pay attention to the little things, and the big things take care of themselves." Don't forget, big things are a bunch of little things bound together.

fields.verse: “In the beginning, Lord, you laid the foundations of the earth, and the heavens are the work of your hands. They will perish, but you remain; they will all wear out like a garment. You will roll them up like a robe; like a garment they will be changed. But you remain the same, and your years will never end.” - Hebrews 1:10‭-‬12 (NIV)
fields.content: As beautiful as is the creation of God, all of it will one day be packed up and disappear into the nothingness from which it was created. The sun, the moon and stars; the skies, clouds, and trees, the fauna and the flora, the seas, mountains, and the earth, are the stage on which history will play out. It is comedy and tragedy, and all of it has one purpose: to unveil God's plan of redemption. The play is written with multiple endings allowing the players to adlib and improvise as they make their way to fulfill the playwright's ovation inducing ending. At the pinnacle of the drama, the curtain comes down; Act One will be complete. A new set will be moved into place. The curtain will be raised for Act Two, and we will be riveted to our seats as the awesome splendor of the Story unfolds before our eyes. The Author nods his approval to his cast. He is pleased.

fields.verse: But in keeping with his promise we are looking forward to a new heaven and a new earth, where righteousness dwells. So then, dear friends, since you are looking forward to this, make every effort to be found spotless, blameless and at peace with him. - 2 Peter 3:13‭-‬14 (NIV)
fields.content: "This world is not my home, I'm only passing through..." The old gospel song serves as a reminder that we are citizens of another kingdom. We are, like Abraham, on a pilgrimage looking for a city whose builder and maker is God. It is a place where righteousness dwells. As we wander from remnants of our previous abode, God is meeting our needs, teaching us his ways, and guiding us to our promised destination. Whatever has been left behind is a small price to pay for what lies ahead. Weep not for the leeks and garlic that garnished a miserable existence. In time we will even be told to leave the manna that sustains us on the journey. We will be led to a river we will cross, and on the other side will be a land flowing with milk and honey. A pipe dream? Not a chance! It is a promise made to us from the One who will do it. Wash yourselves clean; put on a clean linen garment. Whether today, tomorrow, or down the road, he will lead us to that place where He reigns, and we will enjoy the benefits of being citizens of his kingdom forever and ever.

fields.verse: So I will always remind you of these things, even though you know them and are firmly established in the truth you now have. - 2 Peter 1:12 (NIV)
fields.content: The pastor was in his study dutifully and diligently preparing his sermon for the upcoming Sunday. As was his custom, he prayed for his congregation. People are creatures of habit, He pictured them in their usual seats and prayed for them by name. His church had a rather large number of seniors who had been followers of Jesus for decades. He found himself praying; "Lord, what can I tell them that they haven't already heard? How can I refresh their faith and add to their understanding?" As he pondered the thought, the answer came in the quietness of his soul. He was reminded of the call to ministry he had responded to. As the old adage put it, he was to "comfort the afflicted and afflict the comfortable." Affirm, confirm, encourage and admonish. The Spirit will strengthen the faith of the faithful. Sometimes we don't need more truth to stack on top of truth. Instead, we need to be challenged to live out the truth we already know.

fields.verse: For we did not follow cleverly devised stories when we told you about the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ in power, but we were eyewitnesses of his majesty. - 2 Peter 1:16 (NIV)
fields.content: Beyond the witness of the four Gospel writers, we have ample historical evidence that Jesus was a real person in real time. The prophets foretold his coming, the Gospels record his teaching and deeds; every generation since, has been blessed with commentary of the impact of his appearing. Ours is the factual rendition of the God who came to seek and save, that which was lost. Our redemption is at stake and we cannot afford to let it rest on the back of an unverifiable fable. The truth is there in full display. A story so extraordinary cannot be made up with the expectation others will blindly believe it. It is undergirded by facts, verified by eyewitnesses. We embrace a faith of substance. Believe and receive.

fields.verse: . . .make every effort to add to your faith goodness; and to goodness, knowledge; and to knowledge, self-control; and to self-control, perseverance; and to perseverance, godliness; and to godliness, mutual affection; and to mutual affection, love. For if you possess these qualities in increasing measure, they will keep you from being ineffective and unproductive in your knowledge of our Lord Jesus Christ. - 2 Peter 1:5‭-‬8 (NIV)
fields.content: New life begins in faith and faith alone, but saving faith is also designed to be a living faith. Faith has add-on features. A basic automobile will get you from point A to point B; that is its essential purpose. The add-on features of a/c, power steering, brakes, and seats, and an upgraded sound system, makes the journey safer and more enjoyable. When we add to our faith: goodness, knowledge, self-control, perseverance, etc., our faith becomes a luxury vehicle that is a joy to ride in and drive. Be grateful for the basic vehicle we've been given as a free gift. At every opportunity, make every effort to upgrade your ride.

fields.verse: But in your hearts revere Christ as Lord. Always be prepared to give an answer to everyone who asks you to give the reason for the hope that you have. But do this with gentleness and respect... - 1 Peter 3:15 (NIV)
fields.content: Children love to ask the "why?" question; their curiosity seems to have no limit. "Why" is the gateway to comprehension, to linking seemingly different things by association. We learn more by asking "why" than by asking any other question. "Why" takes us to thought and intent; it reveals motive, providing us with a purer understanding of the who, what, where, when, and how. The best way to prepare to give a reason for our hope, is to answer the question: "Why do we count ourselves among the followers of Jesus?" By answering that question to our personal satisfaction, we are better able to give others the reason for our hope. Be prepared.

fields.verse: Once you were not a people, but now you are the people of God; once you had not received mercy, but now you have received mercy. - 1 Peter 2:10 (NIV)
fields.content: Social media sites boast about the number and diversity of groups they host. Groups define us and provide a sense of identity and camaraderie. As far back as the early verses of the Bible, God declared that; "It is not good for people to be alone." Loners are rare, most of us seek relationship and companionship. God created the ultimate group to belong to, the People of God. Membership is made available to all who accept his offer of salvation through the shed blood of his Son. As things go, we are by default members of the group on the outside, but the mercy of God offers us the right hand of fellowship. The invitation has been extended to join the People of God. RSVP

fields.verse: Therefore, with minds that are alert and fully sober, set your hope on the grace to be brought to you when Jesus Christ is revealed at his coming. - 1 Peter 1:13 (NIV)
fields.content: We are hopeless without the grace of God. If we are honest with ourselves, we can only come to the conclusion that we cannot live up to God's expectations: we can't earn his approval; we can't buy it. We don't possess the intellectual argument to convince him that we are worth saving. But it is that gnawing inability to gain God's acceptance that is key to redemption. Allan Bloom puts it this way: “Man is essentially an incomplete being, and full awareness of this incompleteness is essential to his humanity and ground for the specifically human quest for completeness or wholeness. Man must resist spurious contentment because it conceals his fundamental condition.” Our discontent keeps us searching until we exhaust the counterfeit means of fulfillment within and around us. Our dissatisfaction drives us to look beyond our understanding, into the spiritual realm where God awaits, ready to answer our deepest cry. He gently, lovingly, and graciously, offers us contentment and completeness in Christ. If we humbly submit to his grace, we experience wellness of soul.

fields.verse: For you know that it was not with perishable things such as silver or gold that you were redeemed from the empty way of life handed down to you from your ancestors, but with the precious blood of Christ, a lamb without blemish or defect. He was chosen before the creation of the world, but was revealed in these last times for your sake. - 1 Peter 1:18‭-‬20 (NIV)
fields.content: GPS apps make it possible to plan a trip with accuracy and efficiency. Most apps will provide detailed directions filtered through chosen criteria. This may include: fastest ETA, direct or scenic route, and avoiding toll roads. The app will also show how long it will take by auto, bike, walking, and bus. We choose our destination before we start and the app adjusts our route in transit as conditions develop in real time. GPS is a modern marvel which is easily taken for granted. Before the world was created, God chose our redemptive destination. He factored in all of life's circumstances and conditions, the easiest way to get there, and the best mode of travel; then he created us and put us on track. When we deviate from the course, God continually recalibrates our trip and offers us alternatives to reach our targeted goal. It is only when we persist in changing our course, believing we know a better way, that we can get hopelessly lost, or arrive at the wrong place. God created us to live with him in loving fellowship. He has provided the way for that to be realized. If we follow his directions, we will safely arrive at our destination .

fields.verse: Praise be to the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ! In his great mercy he has given us new birth into a living hope through the resurrection of Jesus Christ from the dead, and into an inheritance that can never perish, spoil or fade. This inheritance is kept in heaven for you, - 1 Peter 1:3‭-‬4 (NIV)
fields.content: We drove through our old neighborhood not too long ago. It started out as a new subdivision with cookie cutter homes, distinguishable only by the color of the siding. Over time, owners have added landscaping, fences, decks, and other upgrades that provide their individual homes and the neighborhood with character. Owners work diligently to maintain their homes and keep it from deteriorating. The subdivision is mature now, the trees have grown, and everything looks like it's always been there. With careful maintenance, the homes can easily last 100 years or more. In the fallow ground of human hearts God is building his Church. It is not constructed of lumber, brick, and mortar; he is building a home for his people from all walks of life, from every tongue and nation, into a house for his own dwelling. It will have distinguishing features that reflect God's vision, desire, and taste. It will be a beautiful edifice fit for a King. It will last beyond a lifetime or generation. It is being built to last for eternity.

fields.verse: Great is the Lord and most worthy of praise; his greatness no one can fathom. - Psalms 145:3 (NIV)
fields.content: Who was the greatest president? Which athlete stand above all others? Which person made the greatest discovery or invented the greatest product? Who is the greatest person of all time? The best we can do to address this question is to frame it in some kind of context. No matter our choice, there will be others who may have a difference of opinion. Perhaps within the defined parameters of a specific field, individuals may rise above their peers, but what one person leads in all categories combined? Among the gods, none is given the distinction of being so encompassing in so many areas. Whether it is his wisdom, his ability to create, heal, suspend laws of nature, provide and sustain creation, know everything, be everywhere, do anything, no other god, real or imagined, comes close to our God. If we were to evaluate his greatness only on the scale of what has been revealed, he stands head and shoulders above his alleged peers. But, as the commercial says; "Wait! There's more!" He is not done revealing himself and his abilities. One day he will right everything that is wrong and establish a righteous kingdom that never ends. We know what He has done; we can choose to believe it or not, but what he is yet to do overwhelms our imagination's ability to explain or define. Which is why we can state with confidence: "The steadfast love of the LORD never ceases; his mercies never come to an end; they are new every morning; great is your faithfulness." (Lamentations 3:22-23 ESV)

fields.verse: Blessed is the people of whom this is true; blessed is the people whose God is the Lord. - Psalms 144:15 (NIV)
fields.content: As our country becomes increasingly diverse, it is more difficult to sustain our Christian identity. A case can be made that our country is a secular state, but those who downplay the fact that it was founded and built on Christian principles, are denying a fundamental truth. Our founding documents acknowledge a Creator who has endowed us with inalienable rights. Our freedoms come from God, thus they cannot be denied or taken from us by those who have been given the privilege and responsibility of governing. The blessings of life and liberty are not limited to Americans, they are extended to anyone and any nation acknowledging the lordship of God the Creator. Wherever this humble submission is found, the blessings of God are abundantly present. His lordship is rejected at our own peril. "Blessed is the people whose God is the Lord."

fields.verse: Lord, what are human beings that you care for them, mere mortals that you think of them? They are like a breath; their days are like a fleeting shadow. - Psalms 144:3‭-‬4 (NIV)
fields.content: "If it bleeds it leads." That is how the media selects their headlines. If we go by what is reported we would have to conclude that the human race is a sordid mess, a pestilence on the earth. But, that's not how God sees it. He sees a farmer that takes an empty field and turns it into a bountiful harvest. He puts into the mind of a young scientist the ability to look through a microscope and discover the source of a disease and then a cure for it. A song is written, a piece of art is painted, a dance is choreographed, and audiences are enriched, all by nondescript people working in relative obscurity, enhancing the world around them by adding the texture of their creativity. Architects and builders, designers and tailors, doctors and nurses, all work their gifts and skills to make our world better, safer, more beautiful. Life is more than the mayhem and corruption that leads the news. If it isn't, we could justify that it needs to be dismantled and cast aside. Instead, life is the image of God woven into the tapestry of His design. "For we are his workmanship, created in Christ Jesus for good works, which God prepared beforehand, that we should walk in them." (Eph.2:10 ESV) His image is there if we look for it;  it is there when we add our contribution to the world. It is there, and that is why he paid such a great price to redeem us.

fields.verse: Let the morning bring me word of your unfailing love, for I have put my trust in you. Show me the way I should go, for to you I entrust my life. - Psalms 143:8 (NIV)
fields.content: Each day given to us calls for a fresh commitment; it begins with grateful acknowledgement that God has watched and kept us through the night. We awaken to the possibilities that come with a new day. There will be choices to make and the discernment of priorities. If we want to make the most of it, we ask the Lord for guidance. The Scriptures remind us to: "Trust in the Lord with all of your hearts, lean not on your own understanding. In all your ways submit to Him, and he will make your path straight." (Prov. 3:5, 6 NIV) Let's start our day by putting our trust in the Lord. He'll gladly show us the way to go from there.

fields.verse: When my spirit grows faint within me, it is you who watch over my way... - Psalms 142:3a (NIV)
fields.content: It's not a matter of if, it's a matter of when. Sooner or later, we all have a bad day, or a string of bad days. Sometimes we see it coming and prepare, other times it seems to come out of nowhere. Whatever it is, it seems bigger than us, and it gets us down. One person put it this way; "At first I thought I was gonna die, then I was afraid I wouldn't!' Yes, it can seem that way. Yet the Spirit within us beckons. "Come to me, all you who are weary and burdened, and I will give you rest. Take my yoke upon you and learn from me, for I am gentle and humble in heart, and you will find rest for your souls. For my yoke is easy and my burden is light." (Matt. 11:28-30 NIV) When the burden is overwhelming, He volunteers to trade burdens, do the heavy lifting, and give us rest. During our most difficult times, we are never alone.

fields.verse: Set a guard over my mouth, Lord; keep watch over the door of my lips. - Psalms 141:3 (NIV)
fields.content: The Navy has a phrase "Loose lips sink ships." A child knows they are on the edge of trouble when a parent pulls out the; "Watch your tongue, young (man) lady." card. An undisciplined tongue can lead to disaster. Our tongues can be irrationally unruly. Words matter. The right words can bring healing, but the wrong words can inflict enormous grief and pain. That is why the writer penned these words earlier: "May these words of my mouth and this meditation of my heart be pleasing in your sight, LORD, my Rock and my Redeemer." (Psalms 19:14) Lord, set a guard at the gate our mouths. May it be our unquenchable desire for the words of our mouths to match the meditation of our hearts. Amen.

fields.verse: Keep me safe, Lord, from the hands of the wicked; protect me from the violent, who devise ways to trip my feet. The arrogant have hidden a snare for me; they have spread out the cords of their net and have set traps for me along my path. I say to the Lord, “You are my God.” Hear, Lord, my cry for mercy. - Psalms 140:4‭-‬6 (NIV)
fields.content: The meme is funny, but also provoked a thought. "Just because you don't believe in conspiracies, doesn't mean they are not out to get you!" It's safe to say that most, if not all, of us have had experiences with attempts to be sabotaged. Perhaps someone wanted the promotion we got and attempted to make us look bad at work. Maybe the enemy tried to undermine a friendship with some well placed gossip. Even an honest mistake on our part can be interpreted in a way so as to sully our reputation. But we have the Lord covering for us. He often intervenes before we are aware of our need, and certainly will be there to vindicate us when we are wrongly accused. So, don't live in paranoia, walk confidently in life. Don't give way to criticism and accusation. God is directing our steps and will keep us from stumbling, even if someone tries to trip us up.

fields.verse: . . .His love endures forever. - Psalms 136:1 (NIV)
fields.content: This is a call and response Psalm. 26 times the caller makes a statement about God, and the people respond with: "His love endures forever." Repetition is an aid to learning; it embeds information into a deeper part of our brain making it easier to recall and more difficult to forget. Each of the statements made by the caller, speaks to something significant that God has done. Although each of the deeds are worthwhile to remember, the more important truth is that God's love endures, and it endures forever. It is difficult to fathom the concept of forever. There are specific incidences in time when God's intervention stands out from his quieter involvement in our lives. They are strung together by the common denominator of his faithful love. "Give thanks to the Lord, for he is good! His love endures forever! And forever is a long, long time.

fields.verse: The Lord does whatever pleases him, in the heavens and on the earth, in the seas and all their depths. - Psalms 135:6 (NIV)
fields.content: There is a big difference between doing what one pleases and doing what pleases one. Doing what one pleases may result in inconsistent, arbitrary whims depending on how one feels at any given moment. Doing what pleases one takes into consideration that which brings joy and pleasure and is grounded in what leads to the overall good. The Lord's intentions for us are good. He acts in accordance with his nature and declared will. His ultimate goal is to restore his creation to its original order. That is his goal. It is what pleases him.

fields.verse: How good and pleasant it is when God’s people live together in unity!  Psalms 133:1 (NIV)
fields.content: It doesn't matter where it manifests itself, division and discord can make for a tense environment. The unpleasantness of feeling like one is walking on eggshells, in fear of offending someone, hinders relationship building. That fear is magnified by the knowledge that there is much to be offended by. It is more difficult, although infinitely more rewarding, to make the effort to find common ground. The broader our common ground, the more stable and stronger the relationship. Centuries after this Psalm was penned, the Apostle Paul encouraged us to: "Make every effort to keep the unity of spirit in the bond of peace." (Eph. 4:3) We don't have to compromise truth in order to have unity. It's a matter of finding truth together to establish the depth of relationship that squeezes out our propensity to be offended. Division is unruly, angry, and defensive. Unity is good, pleasant, and affirming.

fields.verse: My heart is not proud, Lord, my eyes are not haughty; I do not concern myself with great matters or things too wonderful for me. But I have calmed and quieted myself, I am like a weaned child with its mother; like a weaned child I am content. - Psalms 131:1‭-‬2 (NIV)
fields.content: Most children have big dreams for their future. They start out as astronauts, doctors, professional ballplayers, and law enforcement officers; in their minds the sky has no limit.
