As we grow, our drive to meet those expectations can leave us frazzled and weary. The daily grind of life can temper our desires and we struggle to find the lane which leads us to our goal. We are left with the choices of resigning to our fate, or being content that our natural skill, gifts, and talent are geared for success in a different direction. The psalmist takes a deep breath and humbly accepts his situation. He makes peace with himself and finds rest. Before the song has been written he acknowledges, "Whatever my lot, thou has caused me to say: it is well with my soul." Hundreds of years later the Apostle Paul sings the same, yet to be written tune: "I have learned in whatever state I am in, to be content." (Phil. 4:10) The greatest achievement in life is to find contentment in the Lord.

fields.verse: Those who sow with tears will reap with songs of joy. Those who go out weeping, carrying seed to sow, will return with songs of joy, carrying sheaves with them. - Psalms 126:5‭-‬6 (NIV)
fields.content: There is an end to the dark despair of sorrow; joy is hidden in seeds waiting to be sown. Between the sowing and reaping, there is waiting. After the harvest and sorting, there is waiting. In the waiting is the temptation to worry. What if: the soil was not properly prepared, the seed was bad, it doesn't rain enough or too much? What if: there are not enough laborers for harvest, the yield is small, the market is not favorable? It's enough to make us cry. But what if we bank on God's faithfulness of the past? We take into account that he rewards honest labor, and has promised us cyclical seasons? What if we anticipate that he will send forth laborers? What if we envision a harvest that will, at a minimum, meet our needs, but most likely have an abundance to lift the countenance of others. Surely then the song we sang at the sowing will be a different one than the one we sing at the harvest. God is faithful! Take your seed and sow. The blues of the waiting room will make way for the joyful songs of celebrating the harvest.

fields.verse: How can a young person stay on the path of purity? By living according to your word. - Psalms 119:9 (NIV)
fields.content: If morality is a societal construct and ethics are situational, then there is no standard for either. It is no wonder that we live in what is perhaps the most confusing time in our history. What was wrong yesterday is being declared as being right today, and what was right yesterday is being called wrong today. Neither of those conclusions would be a problem if there was a standard that would hold up tomorrow. But tomorrow may bring another seismic shift with its accompanying confusion. This is why the Bible is so critically important. Throughout history, individuals, and even nations, that have built their foundation on its truths, have created stable and safe lives and societies. The opposite holds true for those who chose to challenge and ignore the biblical standard of morality and ethics. In a time of decline, it is not a good choice to abandon the standard of truth given as a gift from God on high; instead it is time to double our efforts to cling to the truth and teach it to our children and grandchildren. Remember, no matter how dark and difficult the times, we can turn the tide if we hold fast to the unchanging truth of God.

fields.verse: Give thanks to the Lord, for he is good; his love endures forever. - Psalms 118:1 (NIV)
fields.content: In whatever life throws our way, begin with the premise that the Lord is good. The Scriptures are filled with accounts of how bad things were turned into good things, because God is good. Joseph was sold by his brothers to a passing caravan and ended up unjustly imprisoned in Egypt, but through a series of divine interventions was ultimately raised to second in command. As a result, God was able to use Joseph to save Egypt during a time of intense famine. Later Joseph encountered his brothers and could have exacted revenge, but instead offered forgiveness. He declared to the very ones who sold him into slavery; “As for you, you meant evil against me, but God meant it for good." (Gen 50:20) After centuries of God turning the misfortunes of Israel into blessing, the Apostle Paul declared; "...we know that in all things God works for the good of those who love him, who have been called according to his purpose." (Romans 8:28) Whether in hindsight, the present, or projecting into the future, God is good. It is his default; let it be ours as well.

fields.verse: Praise the Lord, all you nations; extol him, all you peoples. For great is his love toward us, and the faithfulness of the Lord endures forever. Praise the Lord. - Psalms 117:1‭-‬2 (NIV)
fields.content: That's it; that's the whole Psalm. Sometimes it doesn't take much to say all that has to be said. It's a call to every person, tribe, and nation; God is to be praised because He has extended to us his great love and eternally, enduring faithfulness. In a world and time of insecurity, we can count on Him walking ahead to prepare the way, walking alongside to catch us if we stumble, and walking behind us to spur us on toward the goal. Let us count ourselves among the redeemed and praise the Lord.

fields.verse: Return to your rest, my soul, for the Lord has been good to you. For you, Lord, have delivered me from death, my eyes from tears, my feet from stumbling, that I may walk before the Lord in the land of the living. - Psalms 116:7‭-‬9 (NIV)
fields.content: "My whole life flashed before my eyes!" There is nothing like a close call, a near brush with death, to get the heart pumping. It is in those moments we realize most clearly, how fragile life is. As the adrenaline rush subsides we respond with relief, which often gives way to thanksgiving. We've been spared; we've been given another chance. Only eternity will reveal how often God stepped in to guide and guard us from unforeseen trouble. In those times when we are aware, we give thanks for his deliverance, for the tears we don't have to shed, for those falls we didn't have to experience, for the great privilege we have been extended to continue our walk with the Lord. Take a moment to be thankful today, especially for those situations where God has acted preemptively.

fields.verse: All God’s people here send you greetings, especially those who belong to Caesar’s household. - Philippians 4:22 (NIV)
fields.content: Tucked in the parting comments to the Philippians, Paul makes a subtle but significant statement. The Gospel had penetrated into the highest levels of government and society. Even while held as a prisoner, opportunities to be a witness were present; Paul took advantage of his situation. Whether free or imprisoned, rich or poor, male or female, God wants to save all who are lost, and all of us are lost. Those who are higher up on the societal ladder are not exempt. Parents, professors, physicians and politicians, all are in need of God's saving grace. The Gospel is for all. Resist the feelings of intimidation of people who have positions of prestige and power. We have been placed where we are to make a difference that has rippling effect.

fields.verse: Brothers and sisters, I do not consider myself yet to have taken hold of it. But one thing I do: Forgetting what is behind and straining toward what is ahead, I press on toward the goal to win the prize for which God has called me heavenward in Christ Jesus. - Philippians 3:13‭-‬14 (NIV)
fields.content: ...This is what he said: "Four years ago I made a bad decision that was going to negatively affect my entire life. In an act of mercy, I was given 2 choices: I could take my chances with the court, or allow the Coach to supervise me during a long period of detention. I chose supervision. I was initially assigned to carry water, distribute towels, and pick up equipment after practice; I was subsequently allowed to take part in workouts and training. At the end of the detention the Coach gave me two choices; go back to what I was doing, or try out for the team. I tried out the next season and barely made the squad. Since then, we've trained together and some of you became stars, winning ribbons and medals. The best I ever did was a second place finish, but I was inspired by your commitment and encouraged by your support, to keep running. You lined the course at every meet where I ran a race, and cheered me on till I crossed the finish line. I am a better person for it. Four years ago I was given two choices: accept the consequences of who I was and what I did, or get on a different track. I chose to put the past behind me and join the race. I was not as good as others who were running, but I kept running because the Coach, and all my teammates who finished ahead of me, were waiting to congratulate me at the finish line. Press on and don't look back; keep running the race."

fields.verse: Brothers and sisters, I do not consider myself yet to have taken hold of it. But one thing I do: Forgetting what is behind and straining toward what is ahead, I press on toward the goal to win the prize for which God has called me heavenward in Christ Jesus. - Philippians 3:13‭-‬14 (NIV)
fields.content: The following Fall, when track tryouts were scheduled, the young man showed up at the field. He approached the coach and said, "Remember me? I'd like to try out for the team." The coach replied with a slight smile on his face, "Go warm up." For 3 grueling days the prospective team members ran through the drills. On the last day the list of those who made the team was posted on the locker room bulletin board. The names were listed in order of the number of points earned to make the team. His name was on the list, third from the bottom. He dedicated himself to improving. By the end of the season, he was stronger, and faster, but he only managed one fourth place finish in all the races. He made the team the following season. Realizing his level of stamina, the coach encouraged him to run cross-country. His best finish was a second place against a team from a small town highschool that barely had enough runners to qualify. In his final year of track, the young man finished what some would call a non-stellar track career. He placed third occasionally, but most of his finishes were in the middle of the pack. At the annual team awards banquet, he received a team participation medal as did all all of his teammates. He approached the coach and asked him if he could say a few words to the team. This is what he said: (To be continued...)

fields.verse: Brothers and sisters, I do not consider myself yet to have taken hold of it. But one thing I do: Forgetting what is behind and straining toward what is ahead, I press on toward the goal to win the prize for which God has called me heavenward in Christ Jesus. - Philippians 3:13‭-‬14 (NIV)
fields.content: Although he was not part of the team, he participated in most all of the conditioning and training. He noticed that time seem to move faster if he was busy. He got physically stronger and his technique improved. He even made a couple of friends. At the end of the the 2 hour workout, he hung around as the coach talked with his runners. It got to the point where he started looking forward to the training. At the end of his detention, the coach took him aside and said. "You don't have to come back after today, but if you do come by, you are welcome to hang out with us. If you decide you want to try out for track next season, you have as good a chance as anyone to make the team." The young man thanked him, said he would think about it, and went his way...(Epilogue to follow...)

fields.verse: Brothers and sisters, I do not consider myself yet to have taken hold of it. But one thing I do: Forgetting what is behind and straining toward what is ahead, I press on toward the goal to win the prize for which God has called me heavenward in Christ Jesus. - Philippians 3:13‭-‬14 (NIV)
fields.content: The coach didn't bring up that he was 10 minutes late for his detention; he put him straight to work. He was to distribute towels and sports drinks to the track team. Two hours later he was to pick up any stray equipment on the field and haul it to the equipment room. One day down. He did the same on day two. On day three, to his surprise, he was assigned the additional responsibility of a stopwatch and clipboard to chart the team member's progress. At the end of practice, he turned in the watch and clipboard, picked up the stray equipment on the field, and hauled it to the equipment room. Day four, the coach tossed him a warm-up suit and said, "You might as well look like you belong here." After day seven, he was asked if he wanted to run sprints with the team since he looked bored. It was at day 10 when he realized there was another young man assigned to picking up towels and distributing sports drinks. (To be continued...)

fields.verse: Brothers and sisters, I do not consider myself yet to have taken hold of it. But one thing I do: Forgetting what is behind and straining toward what is ahead, I press on toward the goal to win the prize for which God has called me heavenward in Christ Jesus. - Philippians 3:13‭-‬14 (NIV)
fields.content: The high school freshman sat in the office waiting for the Principal to call him in. The track coach walked in and struck up a conversation with the young man and then went in to see the Principal. The boy's name was finally called, and in he went. The coach was there and the Principal spoke. "You spray painted an epithet on my car. The fine alone is significant and you may be referred to a Juvenile Hall. If you agree to serve 100 hours of after school detention under the coach's supervision, I'll not press charges. Agree to be overseen by the coach or take your chances with the court. These are the only two choices you have." (To be continued...)

fields.verse: ...though I myself have reasons for such confidence. If someone else thinks they have reasons to put confidence in the flesh, I have more: circumcised on the eighth day, of the people of Israel, of the tribe of Benjamin, a Hebrew of Hebrews; in regard to the law, a Pharisee; as for zeal, persecuting the church; as for righteousness based on the law, faultless. But whatever were gains to me I now consider loss for the sake of Christ. - Philippians 3:4‭-‬7 (NIV)
fields.content: An IRS agent was on his way to a farmer's home to serve an audit. He parked outside the gate's driveway and decided to take a shortcut by climbing the fence of the pasture that was clearly marked, "Beware of Bull." As he was walking, the farmer came down his gravel driveway in his pickup and stopped when he saw the agent. Rolling down his window he said; "Didn't you see the sign?" The agent whipped out his badge and his paperwork for the audit, and said: "This badge and these papers allow me to go anywhere I want, anytime I want!" Just then the bull came out of nowhere and began to chase the agent. As the agent was calling out for help, the farmer leaned out his truck and yelled back, "Show him your badge! Show him your credentials!". The Apostle Paul knew that there were times when credentials were meaningless. The only thing that matters in redemption is whether we embrace  by faith, the grace extended to us by God in Christ.

fields.verse: Do nothing out of selfish ambition or vain conceit. Rather, in humility value others above yourselves, not looking to your own interests but each of you to the interests of the others. - Philippians 2:3‭-‬4 (NIV)
fields.content: At one time or another we've all been guilty of selfish behavior. It manifests itself in subtle ways. We try to squeeze one more thing in the garbage to avoid taking it out; we reach into the middle of the loaf of bread to where the softer slices are; or hide the premium ice cream bars in an old fish sticks box. These may be trivial examples of selfishness, but they are symptomatic of the condition we all suffer as humans. We often value ourselves above others. Kingdom principles flip selfishness on it's head. We are reminded that the last shall be first, and to value others above ourselves. Such radical departure from our human nature doesn't come easy, but it can be developed in small incremental steps. Win the battle over self. Take out the garbage, quit hiding the ice cream, and before you know it you'll be making sandwiches from the first slices of bread.

fields.verse: Therefore if you have any encouragement from being united with Christ, if any comfort from his love, if any common sharing in the Spirit, if any tenderness and compassion, then make my joy complete by being like-minded, having the same love, being one in spirit and of one mind. Do nothing out of selfish ambition or vain conceit. Rather, in humility value others above yourselves, not looking to your own interests but each of you to the interests of the others. In your relationships with one another, have the same mindset as Christ Jesus: - Philippians 2:1‭-‬5 (NIV)
fields.content: Among the Apostle Paul's letters, Philippians is probably the most quotable. It is a vein of gold from which many nuggets can be mined.  His use of the adverb "therefore" (as a result of) links his divine observations to practical applications. It would be quite tempting to bask in the spiritual truths he declares, but he quickly draws our attention to that which is revealed by and of God, is meant to be shared and put into practice. "If we received encouragement if we have any encouragement from being united with Christ, if any comfort from his love, if any common sharing in the Spirit, if any tenderness and compassion" (v.1)  then we are to respond by "being like-minded, having the same love, being one in spirit and of one mind." (v.2) We are to be doers of the word and not hearers only. Being and doing completes the circle of joy.

fields.verse: I eagerly expect and hope that I will in no way be ashamed, but will have sufficient courage so that now as always Christ will be exalted in my body, whether by life or by death. For to me, to live is Christ and to die is gain. - Philippians 1:20‭-‬21 (NIV)
fields.content: Throughout history, in varied times and places, the people of God have enjoyed preferred status or have fallen into societal disfavor. Believers have been appreciated for their commitment to taking care of the sick, feeding the hungry, and providing a solid moral compass for their communities. They have also been mocked, and even persecuted when they have challenged unbridled power, unrestrained vice, injustice, and corruption. Our call is to stand in fearless, humble courage in any and all circumstances. In every aspect of the spectrum, believers are privileged to stand as witnesses to the inescapable and irresistible grace of God. It doesn't come down to it very often, but when it does the worst thing that the enemy can throw at us is the threat of death. We stand triumphantly over such threats because we know that it is not the worst thing that can happen to us. Live unafraid. Keep looking up! No matter what comes our way, we win.

fields.verse: And this is my prayer: that your love may abound more and more in knowledge and depth of insight, so that you may be able to discern what is best and may be pure and blameless for the day of Christ, filled with the fruit of righteousness that comes through Jesus Christ—to the glory and praise of God. - Philippians 1:9‭-‬11 (NIV)
fields.content: Couples who have been together for a long time will testify that what holds them together today, is beyond what drew them to one another In the beginning of the relationship. Love has no limits to its capacity for growth. As we add nuance to our knowledge and detail to our discernment, the dimension of love expands. It would be a shame to stifle or settle for a level of love less than its potential. Seek to add knowledge, depth of insight, and discernment to your present level of love. Add these components to your prayers for yourself and others.  This is a worthwhile pursuit.

fields.verse: I thank my God every time I remember you. In all my prayers for all of you, I always pray with joy because of your partnership in the gospel from the first day until now, being confident of this, that he who began a good work in you will carry it on to completion until the day of Christ Jesus. - Philippians 1:3‭-‬6 (NIV)
fields.content: He was known to be a man of prayer. He believed that any one prayer could tip the balance in favor of an answer, or change a life. When someone would for ask for prayer, he would take that very instant to pray. He prayed in grocery stores, parking lots, and restaurants. He wouldn't wait till a more opportune time lest he forget; he believed every and any moment was the right time. He was particularly diligent in praying for those who unexpectedly came to mind. He knew it was no accident; they were prompts from the Spirit inviting him into the cause and will of God. He prayed with joy. His prayers were infused with confidence that God promised to finish whatever He had started. Pray when prompted. When the reel of our life is played in heaven, we will be pleasantly surprised at how many of our prayers hitched a ride with others to reach their destination to the heart of God.

fields.verse: Then they cried out to the Lord in their trouble, and he brought them out of their distress. - Psalms 107:6, 13, 19, 28 (NIV)
fields.content: Some of us find it hard to ask for help. We double down on our efforts, rely on our abilities to think it through, and we forge ahead. Each attempt that fails, leaves us a bit more dispirited and weaker as we run out of potential solutions. Fortunately for us, God is patient. Like a good father who teaches his children to swim, ride a bike, or bait a hook, He stands alongside us waiting to see if and when we need help. Four times in this psalm, the Lord confirms his promise. The circumstances vary, the troubles his people are enduring differ, but in each case they acknowledged they were in trouble, called on Him, and he came through. He knows when to step in; all we have to do is call.

fields.verse: But they soon forgot what he had done and did not wait for his plan to unfold. - Psalms 106:13 (NIV)
fields.content: There is a principle in sports that fosters success for those who play. "Let the game come to you." It means to allow the play to develop while not forcing a premature move. It's being able to see how your teammates are setting up and executing their role to make the play work. Whether it is a timed pass to a receiver in football, or passing the ball in basketball until the proper player is in position to shoot, coordination and timing is key. It's all written in the playbook and run countless times in practice. When the play is properly executed, it is like a beautifully choreographed dance move, resulting in a score. God's plan is carefully synchronized to insure a winning outcome. We are often given trial runs in practice before the play actually needs to be run. When it's game time, don't forget to run the play as practiced. Take your position, make your pass or run your route. When it all unfolds and the "game has come to you", remember how the play was designed; and celebrate the score.

fields.verse: Praise the Lord, my soul, and forget not all his benefits— Psalms 103:2 (NIV)
fields.content: As we get older it seems that our memory begins to slip, but there is a theory now that seniors don't forget, it's just that they have a lot more of life's experiences stuffed in their heads to sort through. No matter the age, all of us have occasional memory lapses. When life's distractions monopolize our time, when we are tempted to rush to the next task instead of taking a breather to relish the moment, when we are swallowed up by anxiety or despair, do an inventory of God's faithfulness in the past, and what He has promised for our future. The memories of our experiences with God will satisfy us in the present, and provide quiet assurance, that the God who never fails, is leading us safely to where He's already been.

fields.verse: But you remain the same, and your years will never end. - Psalms 102:27 (NIV)
fields.content: Agnes was a model employee. She would punch in at precisely 7:55 am, Monday through Friday, and get straight to work. She was an accountant and was meticulous in her calculations. Everyone got along with her. She brought donuts for her fellow employees every Friday and warmly remembered, and celebrated their birthdays and anniversaries. At 5:05, she would punch out for the day. Over the years new employees would come and go, but Agnes was always there. For years the stability of the company was measured by Agnes's presence. One day, after 46 years, Agnes retired. Her workmates had a nice celebration in her honor and all took their turn saying what a pleasure she was to work with, and how much she would be missed. The following Monday the employees returned to the office; all seemed normal except... It took awhile to get used to Agnes not being there. There is something to be said about predictability. Some claim it is boring, but a predictable, steady order holds together what would otherwise be uncertain. Our God is with us when we awaken, and he is there when we close our eyes for rest. He never sleeps or slumbers. His predictability provides us with peace, even when chaos is all around us. He is here as an anchor to life, and he graciously surprises us with donuts. He has no plans to retire.

fields.verse: Enter his gates with thanksgiving and his courts with praise; give thanks to him and praise his name. For the Lord is good and his love endures forever; his faithfulness continues through all generations. - Psalms 100:4‭-‬5 (NIV)
fields.content: The Earth slowly spins toward its daily meeting with the Sun. In a distant part of the world, the day started hours ago, but in our timezone the Sun is just now starting to peak over the horizon. Soon we'll  leave our beds, start the coffee maker, and get ready for the day ahead. On Sundays it means attending church services. It's time to prep the mind, body, and spirit for our collective experience with the living, loving God. Worshipping as a congregation has a different dynamic than worshipping alone. The harmonies in our songs, the group posture in prayer, the prospects of a common word delivered to the entire Body, expands the dimensions of our personal experience. He is acknowledged as OUR God as much as he is MY God. So, cross the threshold, join in, embrace our mutual bond. Enter into his gates with thanksgiving and into his courts with praise. This God is our God forever and ever!

fields.verse: Sing to the Lord a new song; sing to the Lord, all the earth. Sing to the Lord, praise his name; proclaim his salvation day after day. - Psalms 96:1‭-‬2 (NIV)
fields.content: "I hear a song in that" is a common saying in Nashville. Anytime someone experiences a victory or struggle, it is seen as a potential song. You can't escape it if you live in Music City. Consider that a piano has 88 keys and 12 notes in every octave. A guitar also has twelve notes in a scale, and each type of scale has 12 different possibilities. Both have been sources of innumerable songs. New songs are composed every day; the possibilities are endless. Music is an integral part of every culture. Music can set or reflect a mood. Some music helps us remember, some helps us forget. The sacred songbook of the redeemed captures the story and mood of the People of God. For over 3,000 years now, we have been participants through song, in their experiences of joy, suffering, healing, and triumph. The songs never seem to get old. Each generation writes a contemporary  interpretation to the biblical collection. Whatever we may be going through, there's a song for that. So, find yourself a place, tune your vocal instrument, and "Sing to the Lord a new song..."

fields.verse: How great are your works, Lord, how profound your thoughts! - Psalms 92:5 (NIV)
fields.content: A manufacturing company ordered a machine. When it was delivered, it had to be assembled. They must have ordered it from IKEA. It was exasperating to try to put together. The assemblers finally gave up and told the owner that he would have to fly in, at considerable expense, an expert from where the machine was purchased. A relatively new employee asked the foreman if he could be allowed to look at the schematics. After about 10 minutes, he told the foreman he could put it together. All the others who had tried, laughed. The new employee was known to have had only a fourth grade education and could not speak English, but he had a talent, a gift; He could see hundreds of parts laid on a factory floor and knew instinctively in what order the parts had to be put together. It didn't take him long; he assembled the machine. He was featured in the organization's trade magazine and was promoted to Master Assembler. From His balcony in the heavens, God sees everything about his creation. He knows where every person, thought, and deed is, and how the myriad of parts fit together in his perfect plan. All our experts try in vain but can't seem to put the parts together to work as it was designed. We, however, serve the God who sees what no one else can see which allows him to do what no one else can do.

fields.verse: “Because he loves me,” says the Lord, “I will rescue him; I will protect him, for he acknowledges my name. He will call on me, and I will answer him; I will be with him in trouble, I will deliver him and honor him. With long life I will satisfy him and show him my salvation.” - Psalms 91:14‭-‬16 (NIV)
fields.content: If you ever wondered what the Lord's will is, this short passage provides us with six declarations that clarify His intentions for us. "I will": Rescue, protect, answer, be with, deliver, and satisfy. As you read through the Scriptures and take note of the times God says; "I will" this Psalm just scratches the surface of what God wills for those who follow him. Go about your day meditating on God's will; it will put a skip in your step, a smile on your face, and a song in your heart. Jesus, lead on.

fields.verse: But you, Lord, are a compassionate and gracious God, slow to anger, abounding in love and faithfulness. - Psalms 86:15 (NIV)
fields.content: Awhile back a bumper sticker appeared with the message, "Jesus is Coming, and Boy is He Mad!" In the meantime, He is compassionate, abounding in love, and graciously giving his creation plenty of time, whether a human lifetime or centuries of history, to receive his gift of unimaginable eternal joy and life. It is true that He will come back to judge a sinful people and reclaim what is his, but the fear of what will happen tomorrow must take a backseat to the peace he offers today.9/20/22Today's devotional in a nutshell:"Turn to me and have mercy on me; show your strength in behalf of your servant; save me, because I serve you just as my mother did." - Psalms 86:16 (NIV)Queen Elizabeth II, former Queen of the United Kingdom, was laid to rest yesterday. Her funeral was marked with somberness and celebration. Her eulogy portrayed her as a benevolent ruler and a humble follower of Christ for over 7 decades. Those who knew her best spoke of her abiding faith as the the centerpiece of her life. She is succeeded by her son, King Charles III. His work is cut out for him. He was blessed with a godly mother and her influence was foundational, but He cannot claim the blessing of God through his mother's testimony; He must make his own decision to serve the King of kings. His legacy is to be his own. Rest in peace, Queen Elizabeth. God save the King.

fields.verse: Restore us again, God our Savior, and put away your displeasure toward us. Will you be angry with us forever? Will you prolong your anger through all generations? Will you not revive us again, that your people may rejoice in you? Show us your unfailing love, Lord, and grant us your salvation. - Psalms 85:4‭-‬7 (NIV)
fields.content: It is rare that anyone would consider natural calamities like earthquakes, famines, and floods, as God's direct judgement on sin. Our knowledge and understanding of science defines them as the results of the laws of physics, cycles of nature, and not much more. However, it is difficult to deny the consequences of human decisions and how they contribute to the brokenness and dysfunction around us. We can do practical things to protect ourselves from the effects of natural disasters, but the confession and forgiveness of sins is exclusively a divine transaction. Restoration and revival are the fruit of genuine repentance. The societal upheavals, convulsions, and storms can cease if God's people will humble themselves and call upon His name. If and when we do, righteousness, peace, and joy can once again be the order of the day.

fields.verse: Do not cast me away when I am old; do not forsake me when my strength is gone. - Psalms 71:9 (NIV)
fields.content: Aging presents a number of challenges including: dwindling finances, declining health, and diminished mobility. Of chief concern for the elderly is loneliness. Children mature and often move away. Friends dwindle in number as they retire and move.  The loss of a spouse can be devastating. Our culture does not put much value on the elderly. All of this paints a picture of the lonely senior existing in a tiny, ever shrinking circle of loneliness. We must remind them, and eventually ourselves, that we are never alone; His presence is always with us. When we are on the verge of being overcome by the fear of being alone, we can always call upon the Lord, who lovingly and patiently comes to walk by our side in deep, abiding, sustaining, and refreshing fellowship. No, we will not be forsaken; we will never be alone.

fields.verse: Praise be to the Lord, to God our Savior, who daily bears our burdens. - Psalms 68:19 (NIV)
fields.content: To wish for a carefree life is a pipedream. That's because there are good things we carry that make for a responsible life. But life at its best can sometimes get heavy; we carry the results of decisions we make as well as the consequences of decisions made by others. When it gets overwhelming, it's a joy to have someone to walk alongside of us, coaching and encouraging us. We are especially blessed when we have someone who has the unique ability to lift some of the burden, or even all of it for a spell, to give us an opportunity to catch our breath. Our God is such a companion. He's always there. "Cast all your cares on Him, for he cares for you." (1 Peter 5:7) He's there every single day, weekends and holidays included.

fields.verse: The whole earth is filled with awe at your wonders; where morning dawns, where evening fades, you call forth songs of joy. - (Psalms 65:8 NIV)
fields.content: The earth is divided into 24 time zones. In essence somewhere in the world the sun is setting or rising every hour on the hour. His majesty is displayed for all to see at all times in all places. Peoples before, and after us, will carry the baton for their laps of praise and worship. Songs of joys and hope are filling the air. The sun is rising; it is our turn. Let's lift up our voices, loud and strong. This is the day the Lord has made.

fields.verse: I long to dwell in your tent forever and take refuge in the shelter of your wings. For you, God, have heard my vows; you have given me the heritage of those who fear your name. - Psalms 61:4‭-‬5 (NIV)
fields.content: We are riding a great wave of interest in genealogies. The scientific advances in DNA study have made it possible for us to more quickly and easily fill in our family trees. For some the results have been quite interesting, while others have been surprising or even shocking. Our most significant heritage though, comes from our identification as God-followers. It is the legacy of the good God, who grafted us into his family tree, that gives our lives the deepest meaning. The branches in God's genealogy include former royals, and rascals, but all have been rescued when they cried out for God's redemptive mercy and grace. He pulled out the Divine pen and added our name to his tree. These are the ones who bear His Name and will be extended the privilege to dwell in His house forever.

fields.verse: Hear my cry, O God; listen to my prayer. From the ends of the earth I call to you, I call as my heart grows faint; lead me to the rock that is higher than I. For you have been my refuge, a strong tower against the foe. - Psalms 61:1‭-‬3 (NIV)
fields.content: "When you reach the end of your rope, tie a knot in it and hang on.” (Franklin D. Roosevelt) It's a universal experience: if you haven't reached the end of your rope, you will eventually. Strengthen your grip. Tap into your resolve while you still have rope. It's imperative to hang on and not quit. Tie a knot. Give yourself something solid for leverage. It may be a past experience or a previous accomplishment. You can hang on a lot longer if you have something to hang on to. Even as you feel overwhelmed, hanging over an ominous abyss, shift your focus from the problem and concentrate on the One who is faithful. Trust God; He won't leave you hanging.

fields.verse: In my former book, Theophilus, I wrote about all that Jesus began to do and to teach until the day he was taken up to heaven, after giving instructions through the Holy Spirit to the apostles he had chosen. - Acts 1:1‭-‬2 (NIV)
fields.content: Luke's gospel records the beginning of what Jesus said and did, but wait there's more! The Book of Acts continues the story, telling us what Jesus went on to do and say after his death, burial, and resurrection. Jesus made it clear that salvation had come to the Jewish people, but it didn't end there. The disciples would receive power by the Holy Spirit to take the good news to "the ends of the earth." What follows in the Book of Acts are the concentric circles of the fulfillment of Jesus' command to his disciples. Each of us is part of that ripple effect as the influence of the Gospel expands in real life space and time. The world is waiting. If we've heard the Gospel, we are charged to share the Gospel.

fields.verse: Many have undertaken to draw up an account of the things that have been fulfilled among us, just as they were handed down to us by those who from the first were eyewitnesses and servants of the word. With this in mind, since I myself have carefully investigated everything from the beginning, I too decided to write an orderly account for you, most excellent Theophilus, so that you may know the certainty of the things you have been taught. - Luke 1:1‭-‬4 (NIV)
fields.content: Many of us are familiar with the party game: "Telephone." Participants line up, or form a circle. Someone whispers into the first person's ear, and that person whispers the same message into the next person's ear, and so on, until it is whispered to the last person in the line or circle. Often what comes out at the end is hilariously, or horrifyingly, different. Oral transmission can be highly inaccurate. In contrast, the good news of the Gospel was committed to writing with careful precision. Our Bible is eyewitness testimony in written form. What the writers saw and spoke, is what they scribed. The message cannot be twisted or miscommunicated, because we have an accurate record. All we have to do is compare what is being said to what has been written. God designed it so that we can "know the certainty of the things you have been taught." That which is worth remembering, is worth recording.

fields.verse: The chief priests and the whole Sanhedrin were looking for evidence against Jesus so that they could put him to death, but they did not find any. Many testified falsely against him, but their statements did not agree. - Mark 14:55‭-‬56 (NIV)
fields.content: Even to this day there are attempts to cast doubt and to discredit Jesus and his teachings. What is interesting is that so much of it comes from religious leaders. Committed, passionate Christians often head off to Christian colleges and seminaries, only to return questioning or explaining away God's works, ways, and words. Instead of interpreting the Bible beginning from the simplest of premises, they devise complicated methodologies that reduce it to a book of fabled stories and moral platitudes. Their method of interpretation downplays the supernatural, dismisses what they don't understand, and diminishes the impact of the biblical narrative. Assemble these "teachers" in a room and the voices of disagreement rise to an unintelligible cacophony of confusion; but, in the midst of this babel, truth is undisturbed. Sincere hearts reject teaching that denies who Jesus is and what he came to do. He is more than a teacher, philosopher, philanthropist, or moralist. He is the Lamb of God who came to take away the sins of the world. This cannot be denied or explained away. Everything else is just noise. On this truth we must stake our claim.

fields.verse: Jesus sat down opposite the place where the offerings were put and watched the crowd putting their money into the temple treasury. Many rich people threw in large amounts. But a poor widow came and put in two very small copper coins, worth only a few cents. Calling his disciples to him, Jesus said, “Truly I tell you, this poor widow has put more into the treasury than all the others. They all gave out of their wealth; but she, out of her poverty, put in everything—all she had to live on.” - Mark 12:41‭-‬44 (NIV)
fields.content: A young couple with a meager income sat at the kitchen table and divided their money into the envelopes of the bills they had to pay. They had $21 dollars left over to pay for groceries and gas, both of which were a lot cheaper than they are today. The next payday was 15 days away; it would be tight. That evening they went to church where a missionary from Bangladesh came to speak. As was the custom, an offering would be taken to assist the missionary. The young husband reached into his pocket, although he knew he didn't have much to spare. When he looked at what he had pulled out, it was the $20 bill. He began to reach back into his pocket but stopped short and distinctly sensed he was to give the $20 to the missionary. His wife nodded in agreement. When they got home, they prepared a can of tomato soup, poured a glass of milk and ate in silence. They both knew it was going to be a long two weeks and they had no clue how it was going to turn out, but they acknowledged that giving to the missionary was the right thing to do. She was 8 months pregnant. As they sat on the couch, his arm around her, they heard a small tap on the back door. At first they weren't sure if someone was there, but then they heard a car pulling out of their driveway. They opened the backdoor and found a box of groceries. Bread, milk, eggs, cheese, a pound of hamburger, there was even a package of Chips Ahoy cookies, his favorite. In the box was an envelope with a card. Someone had written: "My God shall supply all your need." Nestled in the envelope was a $20 bill. When you are willing to give all you have, God supplies from all he has.

fields.verse: One of the teachers of the law came and heard them debating. Noticing that Jesus had given them a good answer, he asked him, “Of all the commandments, which is the most important?” The most important one,” answered Jesus, “is this: ‘Hear, O Israel: The Lord our God, the Lord is one. Love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul and with all your mind and with all your strength.’ The second is this: ‘Love your neighbor as yourself.’ There is no commandment greater than these.” - Mark 12:29‭-‬31 (NIV)
fields.content: The greatest commandment is a compound commandment. Loving God and loving others are two sides of the same coin. The kind of love we have for God is revealed by how we love others. The kind of love we show others demonstrate how we understand what it is to love God. The two go hand in hand. But there is a third aspect to the compound commandment: we are to love others as we love ourselves. The way to love ourselves is to discover how God loves us. God loves us in such a way that he gave his all for our redemption. He loves our family, our friends, our co-workers, our neighbors, the stranger, the same way. Therefore, we are to show others the love we ourselves have received. One neatly wrapped compound commandment says it all.

fields.verse: What do you want me to do for you?” Jesus asked him. The blind man said, “Rabbi, I want to see.” “Go,” said Jesus, “your faith has healed you.” Immediately he received his sight and followed Jesus along the road. - Mark 10:51‭-‬52 (NIV)
fields.content: He sat by the side of the road everyday, begging. He heard the conversations, the laughter, the hawking of the street vendors. He could smell the aroma of the baked breads, the fresh fruits and vegetables, and the fish, poultry, and meats that were on display. The sound of music filled the air, but he had no clue what the instruments looked like, or the colorful cloaks of the crowds who had stopped for a moment to listen. He was blind from birth. But, he had heard of the carpenter from Nazareth and how he was healing the sick, delivering the oppressed, and giving sight to the blind. He groped his way through his darkness, calling out for the Miracle Worker in the hopes he could get his attention. Then he heard the question that would change his life. "What do you want me to do for you?" Of all the things he may have wanted, they were all prioritized in an instant. His most recurrent dream, his heart's greatest desire, raced to the top of his list. "I want to see!" At once he received his sight. His eyes were opened and his destiny was no longer limited to begging on the side of the road. He knew what he had to do. He immediately set out to follow Jesus.

fields.verse: Then he called the crowd to him along with his disciples and said: “Whoever wants to be my disciple must deny themselves and take up their cross and follow me. For whoever wants to save their life will lose it, but whoever loses their life for me and for the gospel will save it. What good is it for someone to gain the whole world, yet forfeit their soul? - Mark 8:34‭-‬36 (NIV)
fields.content: A homeless man with a little dog was offered $5,000 to give up his pooch. The man declined. He was offered $10,000, and declined that as well. He said no to $25,000 and also to $50,000, amounts that would be life-changing. When asked why he wouldn't take a large sum of money for a small scruffy dog that could be replaced, he replied. "You can't put a price on what we share together. When people ignore me on the street, he licks my face and hands. When I am asked to leave a place, he trots alongside me to the next place we go. He warms me on cold nights and protects me in dark places. You can't put a price tag on that. I wouldn't give him up for anything in the world!" There is one thing in life that is worth more than anything; our soul. We are constantly being tempted by all manner of things to name our price. Some sell out cheaply, others hold out for more. Those who know the value God has placed on their soul cling to it regardless of what they are offered. There is no profit on earth to be made by selling our soul.

fields.verse: He said to her, “Daughter, your faith has healed you. Go in peace and be freed from your suffering.” - Mark 5:34 (NIV)
fields.content: The Bible records a steady stream of miracles beginning with Creation. At important junctures in Israel's story, God often intervened to build up the faith of his people by showing he was big enough, and powerful enough, to fulfill his extraordinary promises. Miracles are an important feature in the Gospel story. New and younger Christians are more apt to believe in miracles, probably because the miracle of salvation is fresh on their hearts and minds. But as we "mature" in our faith, miracles are redefined or explained away altogether, leaving us with benign, lukewarm, cold, or even dead faith. Miracles don't deny reality, they keep our eyes, minds, and spirits open to the reality of life in the kingdom of God. Look at the brokenness in the world around us. We can use some genuine, miraculous, intervention by God. Don't stop believing! Life is so much more exciting when a miracle or two is added to the mix.

fields.verse: “Listen! A farmer went out to sow his seed. As he was scattering the seed, some fell along the path, and the birds came and ate it up. Some fell on rocky places, where it did not have much soil. It sprang up quickly, because the soil was shallow. But when the sun came up, the plants were scorched, and they withered because they had no root. Other seed fell among thorns, which grew up and choked the plants, so that they did not bear grain. Still other seed fell on good soil. It came up, grew and produced a crop, some multiplying thirty, some sixty, some a hundred times.” - Mark 4:3‭-‬8 (NIV)
fields.content: A parable is a story using a commonly understood narrative to illustrate a more profound truth. Jesus taught in parables. He then goes on to explain the parable later in the chapter. The story highlights  the sower, the seed, and the soil. The main point draws the attention to the soil: hard soil, shallow soil, weed infested soil, and rich soil. Only one type of soil resulted in a harvest. In taking inventory of our lives, we must ask and answer the question. "What kind of soil am I?" The farmer is qualified, The seed is viable, but it is the condition of the soil which determines the success of the harvest. "Lord, break up the compacted soil. Dig deep so the seed can sink its roots. Remove the weeds that can choke your seed. Sow in rich soil so that the harvest of our lives will be worth the work you put into us. Amen."

fields.verse: If a kingdom is divided against itself, that kingdom cannot stand. If a house is divided against itself, that house cannot stand. - Mark 3:24‭-‬25 NIV
fields.content: Divide and conquer is a very effective strategy. When Joshua led the Israelites into the land of promise, he crossed the Jordan at the midpoint of the land. He then led successful campaigns, first to the north, followed by conquest of the south. The inability of all the Canaanites to unite together made it impossible to mount a meaningful defense. Whether it is a nation, workplace, community, church, or family, if unity is missing, defeat is just a matter of time. The Apostle Paul encourages us to: "Make every effort to keep the unity of the Spirit in the bond of peace." (Eph. 4:3 NIV). We can start by rallying around the things we have in common while we work on the things we don't. Keep extending the boundaries of unity until our differences pale in comparison or importance. A united front is a formidable force that successfully defends against attack, and can mount an effective offense to secure victory and security. Be united.

fields.verse: The people were amazed at his teaching, because he taught them as one who had authority, not as the teachers of the law. - Mark 1:22 (NIV)
fields.content: The prophet Isaiah described the coming Messiah as one who "...had no beauty or majesty to attract us to him, nothing in his appearance that we should desire him." (53:2) Unlike most of the depictions of Jesus with long, flowing hair, blue eyes, and fair complexion, Jesus probably didn't stand out in, or attract a crowd based on his looks.  But he had something that was unique. When he spoke, he exuded a confidence that was striking and appealing. People were amazed at his teaching; he taught with authority. We have come to recognize that teaching authority has two basic components: mastery of the content being taught, and the reputation of the person doing the teaching. The more we experience Jesus in action, the more amazing he becomes. When he speaks, the winds obey, the blind are given sight, the oppressed are freed, the lost are shown the way, God becomes real! We have that on good authority.

fields.verse: As Jesus walked beside the Sea of Galilee, he saw Simon and his brother Andrew casting a net into the lake, for they were fishermen. “Come, follow me,” Jesus said, “and I will send you out to fish for people.” At once they left their nets and followed him. - Mark 1:16‭-‬18 (NIV)
fields.content: Who is this One who calls out people to leave their principle livelihood to follow an itinerant teacher? Men and women have altered their course of life and left it all behind to follow Jesus. They may have started as simple fisherman, but history records that lawyers, doctors, business people, and others have answered the Call. The calling is compelling when understood from the Divine perspective. We need to be told, and reminded, that our lives have significance beyond our profession. Life has transcendent meaning beyond the mundane. Simon and Andrew responded to a higher calling with a humble recognition that the profession they had previously chosen, put an unnecessary limitation on their potential to make an eternal difference. Whatever we do for a living is only a means to fulfill our eternal purpose. God's ultimate calling in our lives is to make us fishers of people. A bad day fishing for people is still better than a good day at the office.

fields.verse: I will praise you, Lord, among the nations; I will sing of you among the peoples. For great is your love, reaching to the heavens; your faithfulness reaches to the skies. - Psalms 57:9‭-‬10 (NIV)
fields.content: Fall is approaching. The nights are getting longer and the birds start their chirping a little later each morning. Their song is a signal that the night is over and a new day has begun. It is yet another day to sing the Lord's praises, to communicate to those around us, and beyond, that our God reigns. His love is as great as his faithfulness is broad. Let's lift up our voices and sing; the world needs to know. No matter the length of the night or the brevity of the daylight hours, it's always a good time to praise the Lord.

fields.verse: The fool says in his heart, “There is no God... - Psalms 53:1a (NIV)
fields.content: Throughout the entire semester of science class, the middle school girl would marvel at every section and subject of study. When they watched videos of the planets and stars, she would proclaim; "I see the presence of God there." The section on physical anatomy elicited the response; "The Designer has left his signature on how the body works." When it was her turn to look through the microscope, she exclaimed in awe; "God can be found in the tiniest of places." Her teacher who did not believe in God, became increasingly impatient. He finally took the girl aside and reprimanded her. "God is nowhere!"; he said. "Nowhere!" He set up a desk in the hallway and instructed the girl to write, "God is nowhere!" 500 times. As the young girl sat alone in the empty hallway she began to write. After writing the 500 lines, she gently knocked on the classroom door. The teacher took the papers where she had written her lines and was amazed at what the girl had written. When challenged to recant her faith by denying God's existence, the girl declared her faith humbly, yet boldly. She had been instructed to write, "God is nowhere!" She responded by writing, "God is now here!" God's existence has telltale evidence to those who are willing to look. It is only a fool who says, "There is no God!"

fields.verse: For what you have done I will always praise you in the presence of your faithful people. And I will hope in your name, for your name is good. - Psalms 52:9 (NIV)
fields.content: In all our dealings with God we are served best when we begin with the premise that God is good. It is the thief who comes to "steal, kill, and destroy." No good thing comes from pursuing the wrong path. God, however, is trustworthy. His reputation goes before him. His promise of "life and more abundantly" has ample evidence. He has shown his faithfulness in all of time and in every circumstance. It is because he is good that we can place our hope and faith in him. His goodness is the gateway to the riches of his wisdom, righteousness, holiness, and power. Look at God's faithfulness in the past of his people and we can have confidence he will be faithful going forward.

fields.verse: Blessed are those who mourn, for they will be comforted. - Matthew 5:4 (NIV)
fields.content: Mourning is a lonely place; each person experiences sorrow and sadness uniquely. The emptiness is deep, and the blackness is all encompassing; light has difficulty penetrating. Minutes, hours, and days may pass, taunting our faith, but deep inside, hope will begin its faithful ascent. When darkness foolishly tries to claim our souls, God proves to be the only one who has never left or forsaken us. Brace yourself in the knowledge that, even in your darkest night, you are never alone. "Blessed are those who mourn, for they will be comforted." The blessing is not in the mourning; it resides in the comfort that He has promised will follow. Keep looking up.

fields.verse: The Mighty One, God, the Lord, speaks and summons the earth from the rising of the sun to where it sets. - Psalms 50:1 (NIV)
fields.content: There is no place we can go where we are out of God's range. In every place, in all of time, God calls out to us. He calls us to walk with him, talk with him, to bask in the beauty of his creation, and to be stunned at his explanations as to why he does what he does. Nothing is too big for him, nothing too small to escape his notice, and that is why his love is so amazing. We are a speck of dust in his vast universe, yet he invites us to be with him. It is of great comfort to know, that although he has a universe to run, he has time for us. Take the time to answer his call.

fields.verse: Why, my soul, are you downcast? Why so disturbed within me? Put your hope in God, for I will yet praise him, my Savior and my God. - Psalms 42:11 (NIV)
fields.content: Sadness, disillusionment, and discouragement can visit us without warning. In many cases it stems from unmet expectations or putting our hope in the wrong place. A shift of focus can make all the difference. If we turn our gaze from what disappoints us, and look to the One who never fails, there will be plenty of reason to be joyous and happy. Let's put our hope in God today, and while we're at it, let's give him our tomorrow as well.

fields.verse: I waited patiently for the Lord; he turned to me and heard my cry. He lifted me out of the slimy pit, out of the mud and mire; he set my feet on a rock and gave me a firm place to stand. - Psalms 40:1‭-‬2 (NIV)
fields.content: Waiting and patience are two words that have difficulty coexisting. Time seems to stand still when waiting, and patience is inversely proportional to the ever-present demands of life. But there is no hurrying God; his timing is impeccable. Our fidgeting and pacing the floor puts no pressure on the implementing of God's plan for our lives. At the appropriate time, he acts. God doesn't always pay on the first and fifteenth, but he always pays on time. Ask, seek, and knock; the wait is always worth it.

fields.verse: Many, Lord my God, are the wonders you have done, the things you planned for us. None can compare with you; were I to speak and tell of your deeds, they would be too many to declare. - Psalms 40:5 (NIV)
fields.content: From time to time, as a boost to our faith, we should consider writing a list of what God has done in our lives, and another list of what we would like to see him do going forward. More than likely the list of what he has done is longer than the list of what he is yet to do. Acknowledging what he has done fills our hearts with gratitude. It also builds anticipation and hope for our yearnings and desires. Our future does not exist in a vacuum; its foundation is made up of God's faithfulness in the past. Keep believing. The best is yet to come.

fields.verse: The blameless spend their days under the Lord’s care, and their inheritance will endure forever. In times of disaster they will not wither; in days of famine they will enjoy plenty. - Psalms 37:18‭-‬19 (NIV)
fields.content: God is our defender when we are threatened, our security in times of need, our shade in the noonday sun, our shelter in the time of storm. Whatever challenges may come, we can endure and overcome because God is faithful. So, pitch a tent under his stars, scurry under his umbrella when it rains, take a trip to his storehouses when we find ourselves in need, and stand behind his shield when we are attacked. This is his promise to those who have pledged to follow him. To infinity and beyond!

fields.verse: Blessed is the nation whose God is the Lord, the people he chose for his inheritance. - Psalms 33:12 (NIV)
fields.content: From a moral and spiritual perspective it can be concluded that our nation, at present, is in decline. These words are difficult to write, but the decline is not unusual in history. Numerous nations and empires have come and gone. Either another more powerful nation arises to challenge and defeat it, or moral deterioration will topple it from within. It doesn't look good for us, unless you look at that same history and see that nations go through periods of decline and renewal. We have had several national awakenings, renewals, or revivals in our history. One such period occurred in the 1730s-1770s, before we were even a nation! Another from 1795-1830s. These were instrumental in providing early course corrections in the beginning of what is called "America, the Great Experiment." Subsequently we have had the Pentecostal outpouring from 1906-1950s, and the Jesus movement from the late 1960s through the early 1980s. Can it happen again? Their beginnings can be traced to deep desires in the hearts of the People of God leading to fervent intercession on behalf of the nation. Although these renewals last only a relatively short span of time, they set the national tone for decades after. God has answered these prayers in the past. We can pray that he'll do it again. We need a national revival.Revive us again;  Fill each heart with Thy love;  May each soul be rekindled  With fire from above.Hallelujah! Thine the glory.  Hallelujah! Amen.  Hallelujah! Thine the glory.  Revive us again.  - William Mackay, 1863

fields.verse: Sing the praises of the Lord, you his faithful people; praise his holy name. For his anger lasts only a moment, but his favor lasts a lifetime; weeping may stay for the night, but rejoicing comes in the morning. - Psalms 30:4‭-‬5 (NIV)
fields.content: Yes, God gets angry. The nature of his holiness calls for it. These are not flashes of impatience causing him to indiscriminately lash out when things don't go his way. They are measured moments where he indisputably manifests his displeasure that the choices we make are not working in our favor. Thankfully his anger serves as a course correction and only lasts as long as needed for us to get back on course. Our discomfort and weeping are meant to reinforce the lesson that it doesn't pay to walk in disobedience. Our sorrow can quickly turn to laughter and our tears converted to joy. God's momentary displeasure offers us an opportunity to sing the praises of his holiness and goodness. Get on track. Stay on track. His favor lasts a lifetime.

fields.verse: The Lord is my light and my salvation— whom shall I fear? The Lord is the stronghold of my life— of whom shall I be afraid? - Psalms 27:1 (NIV)
fields.content: Fear is a motivator and/or a debilitator. There is no shame in backing away from a bear; bears can genuinely hurt us. But when we are challenged to compromise our moral and ethical convictions, fear of what others may say or do to us can keep us from taking a stand. Failure to stand often leaves us with feelings of shame and defeat. Having a firm grasp in the power and strength of the Lord fortifies our resolve to stand up against injustices and attacks from the enemy. As the Angel of the Lord told Joshua; "Do not be afraid." Be strong in the Lord and in the power of His might. The victory is ours because the battle belongs to the Lord.

fields.verse: Lord, I love the house where you live, the place where your glory dwells. - Psalms 26:8 (NIV)
fields.content: The Bible doesn't provide us with a whole lot of information about where God dwells. The bits and pieces where it does, points to a beautiful, magnificent place. Our surroundings also provide clues that declare the glory of God: celestial bodies placed in perfect, synchronous order, an atmosphere where the elements are perfectly balanced to sustain life, majestic mountain ranges, valleys, lakes, springs, plentiful pastures, the fauna and flora that decorate his creation, sunsets and sunrises, all give us a hint; but the half has never been told. God has revealed just enough to let us know it is a place where we want to go. As wild as our imagination can be, we haven't scratched the surface of what it will be like. We know enough to be certain we won't be disappointed.

fields.verse: Show me your ways, Lord, teach me your paths. Guide me in your truth and teach me, for you are God my Savior, and my hope is in you all day long. - Psalms 25:4‭-‬5 (NIV)
fields.content: Have you ever wondered what happened to the people you gave the wrong directions to? The one wrong turn we gave them probably has them circling aimlessly in a desert somewhere to this day! With the invention of the GPS those days are pretty much behind us. When we think we know a better way, our GPS gives us several opportunities to get back on the right track. Even when we ignore the recalculations, it continually finds new ways to reach our destination. GPS is very reliable. Believers have a highly reliable navigation system in the Spirit and Word. Whether we willfully or unintentionally make a wrong turn, we are given opportunities to correct the course.  Even when our choices have us spinning in circles in the desert, God continues to recalculate our course. Follow God's directions. He unfailingly knows the best, safest, and fastest way to get us where we need to go.

fields.verse: The Lord is my shepherd, I lack nothing. - Psalm 23:1 (NIV)
fields.content: A good shepherd knows what his sheep need: green pastures, quiet still waters, and the correct paths leading there. He protects them from the perils of the dark valley; with his staff he guides and with his rod he fights off predators. He boldly and confidently sets a table, and his enemies dare not challenge him. With anointing oil he refreshes those who have been cleansed. He serves them a cup that overflows with abundance. His goodness and love are more than pleasantries to be enjoyed for a moment; they linger unabated for a lifetime. He provides for his sheep a safe place to dwell forever. The Lord is my shepherd, our shepherd; we have all we need.

fields.verse: Posterity will serve him; future generations will be told about the Lord. They will proclaim his righteousness, declaring to a people yet unborn: He has done it! - Psalms 22:30‭-‬31 (NIV)
fields.content: The favor of the Lord is intended to be an inheritance to perpetual generations. There is great joy when parents witness their children, and children's children, faithfully serving the eternal God. He is more than enough for our lifetime and lifetimes of our progeny. Visualize through eyes of faith, an unbroken genealogy of faithful followers. Pray for it unceasingly. Live and share a vibrant faith in the presence of your children, and their children. Before they are even born, believe in God's ability to make himself known to them. Let the future belong to God and His people.

fields.verse: May the Lord silence all flattering lips and every boastful tongue— those who say, “By our tongues we will prevail; our own lips will defend us—who is Lord over us?”. . . And the words of the Lord are flawless, like silver purified in a crucible, like gold refined seven times. - Psalms 12:3‭-‬4‭, ‬6 (NIV)
fields.content: Politicians, philosophers, preachers, and pitchmen have one thing in common; they all use words to persuade. Some are so gifted in language, they are said to be able to sell ice cubes to Eskimos. Although words are important, intent is even more so. When words are utilized for personal, selfish gain, they can be manipulated and redefined in such a way as to obscure or compromise truth. The ability to properly discern a speaker's words can make a big difference in what we accept. God's words prevail like precious metals exposed to the purifying heat of refinement. Over millennia, the People of God have experienced His Truth. Read it, believe it, act on it. "For the word of God is alive and active. Sharper than any double-edged sword, it penetrates even to dividing soul and spirit, joints and marrow; it judges the thoughts and attitudes of the heart." (Heb. 4:12)

fields.verse: When the foundations are being destroyed, what can the righteous do?” - Psalms 11:3 (NIV)
fields.content: A young boy was walking on the beach with his father when they came upon hundreds of starfish stranded ashore by the receding tide. The boy picked up a starfish and threw it back into the sea, and then another, and another. The boy's father said; "There are so many; what difference will it make?" The boy replied, as he cast back another starfish; "For that one, it'll make all the difference in the world." When we are tempted to think there is nothing, or too little we can do, do that which can be done. No matter what is going on around us it's always right to do good. In our perception of what needs to be done, it may not seem like much, but it can make all the difference in the world.

fields.verse: I will give thanks to the Lord because of his righteousness; I will sing the praises of the name of the Lord Most High. - Psalms 7:17 (NIV)
fields.content: Sometimes it is difficult to ignore the darkness and evil that exists in our midst. The airwaves are filled with the accounts of crime and injustice. If we aren't careful we can become overwhelmed, discouraged, and jaded. But with disciplined eyes of faith we lift up our eyes beyond the horizon of our present reality. There the Righteous one sits as the standard of goodness and justice. The Lord reigns - always has and always will. He will settle the score with his enemies and establish his kingdom. We await the one of whom it has been said; "The light shines in the darkness, and the darkness has not overcome it." (John 1) Keep looking up. The bad guys don't win. In His time, the fullness of our redemption will be revealed.

fields.verse: In the morning, Lord, you hear my voice; in the morning I lay my requests before you and wait expectantly. - Psalms 5:3 (NIV)
fields.content: God is accessible 24/7, but there is something about connecting with him in the early hours of the morning. Outside of the "to do" list forming in our heads, we are less encumbered by distractions. It is not so much that we have God's attention but that he has ours. So click the Bible app on your electronic device or gently turn the pages of a well worn Bible, pull out your prayer requests lists, and ask God what he wants to talk about today. We may still be shaking off the cobwebs of sleep, but he's been on all-night watch waiting for you to awaken, looking forward to having a conversation. It's morning, Lord. Let's talk.

fields.verse: Know that the Lord has set apart his faithful servant for himself; the Lord hears when I call to him. - Psalms 4:3 (NIV)
fields.content: The Lord summons into his presence only those who have been set aside as righteous and faithful. How can we hope to be among the chosen when our righteousness fails to live up to his standard and our sins disqualify us from entering into his holy presence? We can, through his decree imputing onto us the forgiveness of sins secured by the work of his Son. It is all the Lord's doing. Nothing we do can earn us an audience with the King; the choice is his. In Christ, we have been chosen. Just as a parent's ear can pick out their child's voice in a crowd, our Father hears our voice because we belong to him. Call out to him, he hears you.

fields.verse: I lie down and sleep; I wake again, because the Lord sustains me. - Psalms 3:5 (NIV)
fields.content: Some of us awaken in the morning with the cheery song of birds in our hearts and say with great satisfaction; "Good morning, Lord!" Others unfurl one eye just enough to see where the alarm clock is, and grumble; "Good Lord, it's morning!" No matter the start, it's a day the Lord has made. God has given us another chance to put the past behind and pursue a better future. No matter what happens today, the Lord will be there to sustain us through it. So, let us put on the coffee, wash our faces, brush our teeth, and seek God's direction for today's adventure. Whether we run with him, or plod along, he's right there with us. We're not doing this alone.

fields.verse: 3 (NIV)
fields.content: When surrounded by detractors, distracters, abusers, and accusers; if your enemies are engaged in premature gloating and you are forced to walk through the valley of the shadow of death; hold your head high and keep on walking; act like you own that space. With God as your shield, and the sword of the Word of truth, safe passage is assured. God's got your back and front and sides. Confidence in God is never misplaced.

fields.verse: Blessed is the one who does not walk in step with the wicked or stand in the way that sinners take or sit in the company of mockers, but whose delight is in the law of the Lord, and who meditates on his law day and night. That person is like a tree planted by streams of water, which yields its fruit in season and whose leaf does not wither— whatever they do prospers. - Psalms 1:1‭-‬3 (NIV)
fields.content: In the arid lands of the Middle East, having a source of water can literally be a matter of life and death. Crops were planted and nurtured near the predictable rise and fall of rivers and creeks, and the ability to irrigate inland as far as the waters could reach. Water sustains life. The Word of God is compared to streams of water, and the People of God are likened to trees planted near to the source. The vitality and fruitfulness of our lives is determined by our ability to drink the water of the Word. So, let our roots sink deeply as we drink from the Stream; a prosperous life is promised to those who do.

fields.verse: The Lord blessed the latter part of Job’s life more than the former part. . .After this, Job lived a hundred and forty years; he saw his children and their children to the fourth generation. - Job 42:12‭, ‬16 (NIV)
fields.content: And seemingly, just like that, the ordeal was over. Job underwent the most arduous experience ever recorded, and he passed the test. "And they all lived happily ever after." It reads like the ending of a fairytale, except that it was all too real. Our future fortunes are often realized after we overcome our most difficult struggles. The scars of battle would be worn by Job as ribbons of victory. We may not know why a particular part of the journey passes through the most dangerous terrain, and yet we are asked to put our trust in the One who said; "I am the Way."  Stand strong, unwavering, resolute in faith. Let's make it our ambition, our goal, our conviction, to say as Job said, ". . . he knows the way that I take; when he has tested me, I will come forth as gold. (23:10)

fields.verse: Then Job replied to the Lord: “I know that you can do all things; no purpose of yours can be thwarted. You asked, ‘Who is this that obscures my plans without knowledge?’ Surely I spoke of things I did not understand, things too wonderful for me to know. “You said, ‘Listen now, and I will speak; I will question you, and you shall answer me.’ My ears had heard of you but now my eyes have seen you. Therefore I despise myself and repent in dust and ashes.” - Job 42:1‭-‬6 (NIV)
fields.content: Think of it for a moment. Job had it all; he was riding high on the wave. He practiced the fundamentals of his faith and reaped the benefits of a righteous life. You see, it's relatively easy to worship God when all is going well, but it is also difficult to resist the temptation to believe that all is going well because we figured out the formula. Sometimes what we know gets in the way of God. But when it is all stripped away, there are more questions than answers. When the questions persist, we are left humbled in the knowledge of how little we know. We are reduced to the realization that our inadequacy is at the mercy of the grace of God. Without it, we are hopeless and helpless. Do not despair, His grace is sufficient. Hold on, the end of the trial is nearer than you know.

fields.verse: “Where were you when I laid the earth’s foundation? Tell me, if you understand. Job 38:4 (NIV)
fields.content: God answers Job's questions with questions of his own. In fact, there is a shortage of answers and an abundance of questions. There are a lot of questions about the predicaments we find ourselves in, but there are also many questions about God we don't know the answer to. We know in part, but one day we will know fully. In fact, there is more we don't know about God than what we do know. Questions help put things in perspective. As long as we have questions, there is room for growth in understanding. While it is not a good idea to question God, he doesn't seem to mind when we ask him questions. It is somewhere between what we know and don't know where faith flourishes.

fields.verse: Then the Lord spoke to Job out of the storm. He said: . . . Job 38:1 (NIV)
fields.content: "When all is said and done, there is more said than done." Job has had his say. His 3 friends have added their thoughts and insights. Even a fourth bystander has chimed in. Nothing of Job's situation has changed. Then, God speaks. Anything said beforehand is preamble. It airs out everything that is inside of us aided by the subjective and objective musings of our family and friends. God allows analysis to the point of paralysis until we get to the point where our thoughts, arguments, and conclusions are proven inadequate; and then he speaks. It isn't over until God speaks. Wait for God to speak. He has the final word.

fields.verse: My feet have closely followed his steps; I have kept to his way without turning aside. I have not departed from the commands of his lips; I have treasured the words of his mouth more than my daily bread. - Job 23:11‭-‬12 (NIV)
fields.content: The little boy asked his father;  "Where are we going?"  The father replied: "To Denver, Colorado."  "Will the train take us there?"  "Yes, son, all the way there?"  "What if we get lost?"  "I promise you we won't get lost."  "How do you know we won't get lost?"  "Because the train is on the tracks that take us all the way to Denver."As long as we stay on track we'll get to our destination.

fields.verse: “But if I go to the east, he is not there; if I go to the west, I do not find him. When he is at work in the north, I do not see him; when he turns to the south, I catch no glimpse of him. But he knows the way that I take; when he has tested me, I will come forth as gold. - Job 23:8‭-‬10 (NIV)
fields.content: When our prayers bounce off the canopy of the heavens, when we gaze into the sky and darkness swallows our sight, when our ears are deaf to God's voice, we may be tempted to believe God has forsaken us. Even then, our faith speaks softly and tenderly into our troubled souls.
