Though we search with all our hearts, though we know not where he is, we are comforted in that he knows our name and knows where we are. Hold on, you'll turn the corner soon.

fields.verse: “Oh, that my words were recorded, that they were written on a scroll, that they were inscribed with an iron tool on lead, or engraved in rock forever! I know that my redeemer lives, and that in the end he will stand on the earth. - Job 19:23‭-‬25 (NIV)
fields.content: Job's words were indeed recorded, and 3,000+ years later we are still benefitting from them. We are witnesses to the fact that life can be difficult for the righteous as well as the evildoer. The significant difference is that the righteous have a seed of confidence and hope that refuses to be uprooted. We can be shaken to the core but still maintain faith in the Redeemer. In the midst of suffering, imperfect friends, doubt, and even blaming God for his predicament, Job always came back full circle. He couldn't stay in his despair; he venture out of his misery and continue to call on, and believe in, God. Deep inside, he was resolute in his belief that God will prevail. In Job's story is a lesson. Faith doesn't deny reality, it transcends it.

fields.verse: “I have heard many things like these; you are miserable comforters, all of you! Will your long-winded speeches never end? What ails you that you keep on arguing? I also could speak like you, if you were in my place; I could make fine speeches against you and shake my head at you. But my mouth would encourage you; comfort from my lips would bring you relief. - Job 16:2‭-‬5 (NIV)
fields.content: Job's friends offered what they thought were solutions, when what he needed was encouragement and understanding. They pressed Job to acknowledge that he was suffering because of a lack of faith, hidden sin, or payback for how he had supposedly mistreated others. But Job knew in his heart that their diagnosis and accusations were wrong. He had clean hands and a pure heart, yet he wondered why calamity befell him. When the words of comforter friends sting and accuse, they can hurt more that the barbs and stings of an enemy. When someone we know is in the stages of suffering and mourning, let them ask their questions; allow them to work through it. There is a time to speak and a time to be silent. When the time finally comes to speak, resist offering answers; there will be a time for that as well. Instead, let tender words of understanding and encouragement rule the moment. Those are the words that bring comfort and relief

fields.verse: “Yet if you devote your heart to him and stretch out your hands to him, if you put away the sin that is in your hand and allow no evil to dwell in your tent, then, free of fault, you will lift up your face; you will stand firm and without fear. You will surely forget your trouble, recalling it only as waters gone by. Life will be brighter than noonday, and darkness will become like morning. You will be secure, because there is hope; you will look about you and take your rest in safety. You will lie down, with no one to make you afraid, and many will court your favor. - Job 11:13‭-‬19 (NIV)
fields.content: Job's situation was an outlier, "a person or thing differing from all other members of a particular group or set." Everything his friend Zophar said about Job's situation was true, but Job wasn't experiencing any of it at that moment. His case was unique. It is puzzling, when we know we're doing everything correctly, and the results don't pan out as expected. Sometimes it's not just a matter of doing things correctly, sometimes it's about looking at the situation differently. In the midst of his suffering, Job listened, he sought God, and he waited. Perhaps the most difficult part was the waiting, but waiting often defines and refines our faith. Somewhere in the waiting is the unique answer to our unique situation. Persevere, although we may appear to be stalled, God is closing the gap.

fields.verse: “Can you fathom the mysteries of God? Can you probe the limits of the Almighty? They are higher than the heavens above—what can you do? They are deeper than the depths below—what can you know? Their measure is longer than the earth and wider than the sea. - Job 11:7‭-‬9 (NIV)
fields.content: When we find ourselves at the limits of our knowledge and understanding, we instinctively know there is more. Even when we have answers to our initial question, new questions pop up. There is always something new to learn... especially about God. When the captain of the boat in the movie Jaws saw the size of the shark he was hunting, with wide eyes he proclaimed; "We're gonna need a bigger boat!" When faced with the magnitude of the issues, problems, and consequences of life, they often exceed the size of our faith. Our limited level of understanding God cries out, "We're gonna need a bigger God!" The good news is that God is big, enormously big. He's bigger than our needs, desires, and dreams though you may not know it yet. Keep asking, seeking, and knocking. With a bit of patience, we'll see enough to quiet our spirits and soothe our souls.

fields.verse: Blessed is the one whom God corrects; so do not despise the discipline of the Almighty. For he wounds, but he also binds up; he injures, but his hands also heal. - Job 5:17‭-‬18 (NIV)
fields.content: When surgeons make an incision in order to remove a cancerous tumor, the patient is being wounded for the purpose of healing. A mechanic takes an engine apart and makes it inoperable to get to the parts that need to be replaced. Once it is put back together again, it runs the way the designer intended. The context of this passage has its emphasis on how discipline restores. Patients are not being punished and engines are not being scrapped, they are being corrected. When God sees the need to fix us, sometimes it's painful, sometimes it puts us out of commission for a while, but it is always to make us better. Hang in there you'll be feeling better soon.

fields.verse: “But if I were you, I would appeal to God; I would lay my cause before him. He performs wonders that cannot be fathomed, miracles that cannot be counted. - Job 5:8‭-‬9 (NIV)
fields.content: We could spin our wheels seeking advice with little or no results. We can read books that promise us answers, only to discover that our problem is more complicated than we thought. We can apply our minds, calculating every possible solution, and still come up short. What now? Turn to the One who's in charge? Petition the One who can make things happen? When all else fails turn to God? But, why not start with God? He can gently lead us at the beginning to the ones who have the correct advice. He can direct us to the Good Book which has our answer. He can unleash our brain and reasoning powers to see the solution that is only obvious when seen through a spiritual lens. Before all fails, turn to God. He never runs out of miracles and his solutions inspire awe. That's what I would do, if I were you.

fields.verse: For hardship does not spring from the soil, nor does trouble sprout from the ground. Yet man is born to trouble as surely as sparks fly upward. - Job 5:6‭-‬7 (NIV)
fields.content: The Earth does not spin perfectly on its axis; it actually wobbles. The moon revolves around the Earth, but its orbit is not a circle, it is oblong. We can predict their movements with great precision if we factor in the irregularities. We don't live in a perfect world, but much of it is predictable. For most of us, life moves in a comfortable pattern with occasional periods of interruption. A key fundamental of life is that "stuff happens." We've seen that expressed more crudely on bumper stickers and tshirts, but it is fundamentally true. When confronted with challenges, we recalculate, recalibrate and move forward. When we understand the fundamentals, the adjustments are easier to make. So it's not what happens to us in life, as trouble is a given, but how we react, respond, and make course corrections, that counts. As long as we live on this side of the Great Divide, expect it won't always go smoothly. Don't despair or be paranoid about it; factor it into the equation and make your adjustments. It's all part of running the race on a wobbly, imperfect course we are destined to finish. Jesus, lead on.

fields.verse: Think how you have instructed many, how you have strengthened feeble hands. Your words have supported those who stumbled; you have strengthened faltering knees. But now trouble comes to you, and you are discouraged; it strikes you, and you are dismayed. Should not your piety be your confidence and your blameless ways your hope? - Job 4:3‭-‬6 (NIV)
fields.content: Giving advice is easier than taking advice. We tend to see other's needs and problems more clearly than we see our own. When a similar calamity strikes us, our objectivity is clouded by our discomfort or suffering; yet the comfort we gave others, that emanated from a pious life of godliness, is as appropriate for us as it was when it was extended to someone else. When in trouble, doubt, and despair, ask yourself, "If it was someone else going through what I am going through right now, what words would I use to bring them encouragement and comfort?" Then act on those words, it's probably good advice.

fields.verse: For sighing has become my daily food; my groans pour out like water. What I feared has come upon me; what I dreaded has happened to me. I have no peace, no quietness; I have no rest, but only turmoil.” - Job 3:24‭-‬26 (NIV)
fields.content: We all harbor fear on some level. Imagine our worst nightmare coming true. It's scary enough in our minds, let alone lived in real time! When the worst case scenario collides with us head on, our lives are quickly turned upside down. The normal reaction to fear is what is called the "fight or flight response." We either fight the fear, or flee to a place of perceived safety. Job didn't know what he was fighting and he had no place to go. He was surrounded by his friends, but he was alone in his predicament; or was he? Job found himself in the early stages of learning the most important lesson of his life. You see, the purpose of a test is to reveal the limits of our faith. While he sat and suffered, his faith was being challenged to the core. In order for faith to conquer our worst fears, we have to take the trip to the darkest places where fears reside. It's never pleasant. It's always scary. And though we may feel alone in our journey, ironically it is our faith that accompanies us there. Keep looking up!

fields.verse: When Job’s three friends, Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite and Zophar the Naamathite, heard about all the troubles that had come upon him, they set out from their homes and met together by agreement to go and sympathize with him and comfort him. When they saw him from a distance, they could hardly recognize him; they began to weep aloud, and they tore their robes and sprinkled dust on their heads. Then they sat on the ground with him for seven days and seven nights. No one said a word to him, because they saw how great his suffering was. - Job 2:11‭-‬13 (NIV)
fields.content: Friends mobilize: they come to you. They'll leave their comfort zone and pause their daily routines to be with you. Friends empathize: they relate to you. They share your pain and mourn with you. Friends sympathize; they feel for you. They acknowledge and understand that your predicament is unique to you. They hold their tongues because they know your first need is to process your grief. "Just call out my name, and you know wherever  I am, I'll come running to see you again. Winter, Spring, Summer or Fall, all you have to do is call, and I'll be there... you've got a friend." (James Taylor) Be a friend.

fields.verse: So Satan went out from the presence of the Lord and afflicted Job with painful sores from the soles of his feet to the crown of his head. Then Job took a piece of broken pottery and scraped himself with it as he sat among the ashes.” - Job 2:7‭-‬8 (NIV)
fields.content: "Well, at least you have your health." Job couldn't even say that! Along with his psychological angst Job was now afflicted with physical pain to add to his misery. We all experience pain at one time or another, but long term pain is a challenge of a different sort. There is little solace and comfort that can be applied to pain; it affects every aspect of life. "Pain insists upon being attended to. God whispers to us in our pleasures, speaks in our consciences, but shouts in our pains. It is his megaphone to rouse a deaf world.” (C.S. Lewis) The collective voices of Job's psychological, and physical pain shout to us about the condition of our world. Outside the hedge of God's protection lies a world in immense pain. Even good people experience and suffer pain. Only God has an answer to that level of hurt. Hang on! Relief is coming.

fields.verse: At this, Job got up and tore his robe and shaved his head. Then he fell to the ground in worship and said: “Naked I came from my mother’s womb, and naked I will depart. The Lord gave and the Lord has taken away; may the name of the Lord be praised.” In all this, Job did not sin by charging God with wrongdoing. - Job 1:20‭-‬22 (NIV)
fields.content: One day, seemingly out of nowhere, a series of messengers rushed in to tell Job that everything he owned was either stolen or destroyed. The final shocking news was that his children also died. Imagine the pain of losing it all, literally in one fell swoop. Job tore his robe and shaved his head, a sign to all around him that he was mourning. His instincts, training, and discipline kicked in. He fell to the ground and worshipped God. In the midst of his most excruciating loss, his most heartbroken moment, Job knew that God would be his source of comfort and answers. No matter what he used to have, no matter what his present need, Job still had God. And so it is with us. Keep looking up, that's where our help comes from.

fields.verse: In the land of Uz there lived a man whose name was Job. This man was blameless and upright; he feared God and shunned evil. - Job 1:1 (NIV)
fields.content: Many of us share a common experience of knowing someone we looked up to who was instrumental in shaping our lives the most. It may have been a parent, coach, teacher, or friend. In his time, Job was that kind of person. He had it all: respect from his friends, a beautiful family, good health, and material riches, and then in one day he lost it all. As in the past, success in our day is measured primarily by our accomplishments and wealth; but the narrative of what happens next, while painful to read, reveals another facet of Job that further cements in history what kind of man he was. Who we are when we have nothing may be a better indicator of the kind of person God wants us to be.

fields.verse: Dear friends, although I was very eager to write to you about the salvation we share, I felt compelled to write and urge you to contend for the faith that was once for all entrusted to God’s holy people. - Jude 1:3 (NIV)
fields.content: "Remember, It's not a lie if you believe it." - George Costanza (Seinfeld)  In our times, truth has become a moving target. It dismisses accepted standards and is subjective depending on the interpretation of an ever fickle culture kicking its heels against anyone or anything claiming authority. When truth rejects facts and reason, it becomes confusing and chaotic; everyone does what is right in their own minds. Conflicting truths invite inevitable collisions. However, the People of God have had God's truth delivered to them in principle and precept through the written word. The Word is defined as eternal truth that will survive the ages. It is an unchanging standard by which all understanding is measured. It is an anchor for the individual as well as for a society as a whole - "the faith that was once for all entrusted to God's holy people." Costanza was wrong. A lie is a lie even if one believes it. The truth is the truth even if one does not believe it.

fields.verse: I have much to write you, but I do not want to do so with pen and ink. I hope to see you soon, and we will talk face to face. - 3 John 1:13‭-‬14 (NIV)
fields.content: It is estimated that, 150 years ago, over 90% of people, lived and died within a 25 mile radius of where they were born. The invention of the steam engine and development of railroads brought about phenomenal social change. People began to move, and settle where they thought was the best opportunity to thrive: sometimes cross country, sometimes to another country altogether. The families and friends they left behind were occasionally connected by letter, telegram, and eventually a phone call. Media methods have grown exponentially to accommodate family and business. Whether by televideo, email, text messaging, or other social media, it is possible to stay in touch. But, there is nothing like seeing someone in the flesh. John wrote letters, but there were things he knew must be said face to face. Cherish the few times when we are blessed with a face to face encounter. Look into their eyes. Enjoy the twinkle in their eyes and absorb the warmth of their smile The loving hug of someone you love is difficult to replicate long distance.

fields.verse: This is how God showed his love among us: He sent his one and only Son into the world that we might live through him. This is love: not that we loved God, but that he loved us and sent his Son as an atoning sacrifice for our sins. -  1 John 4:9‭-‬10 (NIV)
fields.content: A companion verse to this is Romans 5:8, "...God demonstrates his love to us in this, while were yet sinners, Christ died for us." He could have sent his son in judgement (which he will the second time around) but he sent him to redeem us. He did this while we were steeped and lost in sin: when we were least deserving. He is the definition of love. We reflect our understanding of God's love by living in and for him. It is him that we now live, move, and have our being. What wondrous love is this, oh my soul.

fields.verse: See what great love the Father has lavished on us, that we should be called children of God! And that is what we are!. . . - 1 John 3:1 (NIV)
fields.content: John Newton was a slave trader. The epitome of debasement is to put monetary value on the freedom of another human being, subjecting them against their will to a life of misery. How can a slave trader be redeemed? He wrote a song 250 years ago providing us with the answer. He came face to face with his own wretchedness, and in his hopeless state threw himself onto the grace, mercy, and love of God. At once he was made aware of the immensity of that love's ability to forgive sin, even his sin. He then went on to assist William Wilberforce in founding the Society for Effecting the Abolition of the Slave Trade. That's the kind of love Newton encountered - a love that turned his life around completely. Amazing Grace indeed!

fields.verse: The world and its desires pass away, but whoever does the will of God lives forever. - 1 John 2:17 (NIV)
fields.content: A point to ponder. Baby Boomers are those Americans who were born between 1946-1964. They number approximately 70+ million Americans. A couple of statistics and then an observation. The youngest Boomers are 58 years old; the oldest are 76. They are currently passing away at a rate of over 2 million per year, and the rate will accelerate. Everyone has an expiration date; Boomers are just closer to it. That's the bad news. The good news is that there is more to life than the brief period we inhabit on this earth. The Big Blue Marble is a wonderful place created by God with a beauty that surpasses every other planet in our solar system. It is a world filled with texture, color, and sounds, filling our lives with incredible joy. But, it is also a place filled with sorrow, crying and pain. That's why God has filled our hearts with a yearning for heaven. Earth is not our final home; we are pilgrims on a journey to a better place. Let's encourage as many of our family and friends as we can to join us there.

fields.verse: But if anyone obeys his word, love for God is truly made complete in them. This is how we know we are in him: Whoever claims to live in him must live as Jesus did. - 1 John 2:5, 6 (NIV)
fields.content: Coming up short is something we are all too familiar with. While perfection in this life is impossible, consistency is attainable. There is a difference between a professional carpenter and a homeowner who breaks out his tools only on the weekend. Practice makes perfect, or at least it makes for a better finished product. A steady life of obedience to God's word and will is sure fire evidence that we have been born again. Although perfection may be the goal, a practicing Christian is more likely to get better results than one who only works on weekends.

fields.verse: He is the atoning sacrifice for our sins, and not only for ours but also for the sins of the whole world. - 1 John 2:2 (NIV)
fields.content: As Mama entered the dining room, the children saw she had a plate of brownies. They crowded around her, reaching and pleading for the delicious treat, but she would gently pull the plate back and patiently asked the children to take their seats at the table. One by one, as she worked her way around the table, she would take a brownie from the pile and lovingly set it before each child. As the pile grew smaller the children at the end of table would have worried looks on their faces. The last child would sigh with relief as the brownie was set on her plate. Everyone had a brownie and there was one left over. Each child wanted dessert, and there was enough to go around. In the foresight of God, before he executed his plan, he scanned the future generations that would come after the creation of the first pair. He calculated the need of everyone who wanted and needed salvation and he filled the platter of redemption with enough for each one...and he added a little extra. Do not be anxious. There's enough to go around.

fields.verse: They promise them freedom, while they themselves are slaves of depravity—for “people are slaves to whatever has mastered them.” - 2 Peter 2:19 (NIV)
fields.content: Beware of false teaching; we are surrounded by it. We live in a land founded on the promise of freedom, but there are those who have distorted the meaning of the word and the results are devastating. The noble idea that we can pursue our dreams and desires for happiness is contaminated by the evil twin of defiance in the face of the benevolent rules that order a peaceful society. Those who cast off all restraint find themselves enslaved by their own passions. They become the centers of their own little universes and eventually clash into other universes trying to occupy the same space. You see, we were not created to do anything we want, we were created with the ability to exercise self-control and not do everything we want. As the Apostle Paul has said: “I have the right to do anything, you say—but not everything is beneficial. I have the right to do anything—but I will not be mastered by anything." (1 Cor. 6:12) Those who have learned to harness their freedom toward righteous ends are far greater than those who are slaves to their fickle passions.

fields.verse: Grace and peace be yours in abundance through the knowledge of God and of Jesus our Lord. - 2 Peter 1:2 (NIV)
fields.content: The farther out we look through a telescope, or the deeper we stare into a microscope, the more our perception of the world needs to be recalibrated. The vastness of space and the intricacies of the molecular world confront us with how little we know and how much more there is to learn about our existence. Most of us are humbled at the immensity of space and the complexity of cells; so it is with God. When our understanding of God extends beyond the initial amazement at the awesomeness of his creation, and when we delve into the beauty of his plan of salvation, it fills us with awe of his grace and we find rest in the peace that passes understanding. Make it your ambition to grow everyday. Our present knowledge is a mere thimbleful of water compared to the vast ocean of what God is willing to reveal.

fields.verse: Dear friends, do not be surprised at the fiery ordeal that has come on you to test you, as though something strange were happening to you. - 1 Peter 4:12 (NIV)
fields.content: Life is full of surprises, but is it really? Ever since the first act of disobedience in the Garden, struggle, testing, and temptation have been the norm. The Book of Job says, "...man is born to trouble as surely as sparks fly upward." (5:7) It's a feature of life, not a bug. Don't be surprised when trouble comes our way; prepare for it. While we may not know the specifics of what is coming, there are character exercises we can engage in to ensure we overcome whatever tries to slow or stop us. The Apostle Paul urges us to "Put on the full armor of God so that when the day of evil comes you may be able to stand your ground." (Eph. 6:10) He then goes on to list the armor with which we have been provided. We are not helpless victims of a shipwreck waiting to be rescued. We are a people fully equipped and prepared to sail the seas in search of new worlds to explore and enjoy. Expect opposition, but have no fear of the enemy or the unknown. Jesus, lead on!

fields.verse: Above all, love each other deeply, because love covers over a multitude of sins. - 1 Peter 4:8 (NIV)
fields.content: A characteristic of deep relationships is the ability to overlook shortcomings in people. Not every infraction is a hill to die on. Love has as its foundation the willingness to do right. It's difficult to fault someone who you know is trying to be a better person. Love also has a desire to forgive...and forget. It is disconcerting to have someone grant us forgiveness if we know they are keeping score and will eventually bring it up again later. It is painful to be on the receiving end of that manner of "forgiveness." When it comes to offenses, love has deep faith and a short memory. Loving others, and being loved, is the secret to enduring relationships. Love deeply.

fields.verse: For 'you were like sheep going astray,' but now you have returned to the Shepherd and Overseer of your souls. - 1 Peter 2:25 (NIV)
fields.content: Charlie was a good dog. His temperament was sweet. He possessed a warm home, regular food and water and a big yard to play fetch. He was loved by the members of his pack and had finely tuned instincts to protect them when he sensed danger. Charlie only had one fault: he didn't like to be on a leash. On occasion, when he was walked, he would wriggle out of his collar and he was off to the races like greased lightning. His nose in the air, he would run willy nilly until he was barely within hearing range. He was oblivious to the perils of life in the big city. He was in grave danger though he thought he was free. After much chasing, cajoling, and bribing with treats, he would eventually tire and return to the safety of his yard and the love of his owner. Resist the lure of unfettered freedom. It's a dangerous world out there. Stay under the guard of the Overseer. And when you think you have a better idea of how to live, and cast off restraint, be like Charlie. Come back to the comforts and safety of home.

fields.verse: But you are a chosen people, a royal priesthood, a holy nation, God’s special possession, that you may declare the praises of him who called you out of darkness into his wonderful light. - 1 Peter 2:9 (NIV)
fields.content: We are a chosen people with a clear purpose. Our holy nation is not limited by geographic borders, and our King rules over all the rulers of the world. This privilege of citizenship is extended to a people called out from every tongue, tribe, and nation who are bound by a common, collective purpose - to declare the praises of him who rescued us from darkness. Being counted among the chosen brings a sense of peace, comfort, deep satisfaction, and joy that is difficult to explain or contain. In fact, we are not to contain it; we are to proclaim it everywhere we go, and every time we can. Declare it confidently, yet humbly, in word and deed; we are God's special possession.

fields.verse: As obedient children, do not conform to the evil desires you had when you lived in ignorance. But just as he who called you is holy, so be holy in all you do; for it is written: “Be holy, because I am holy.” - 1 Peter 1:14‭-‬16 (NIV)
fields.content: The Food and Drug Administration sets the limits for the amount of contaminants allowed in our food, water, and therapeutic drugs. 100% purity is the goal, although virtually impossible to attain. Where purity is impossible, safety is the objective, so limits must be set. Nothing is allowed to enter the supply chain that doesn't meet the standard of the FDA. Holiness is God's standard. As imperfect, frail vessels our thoughts and actions fall short of God's ideal. The circumstances of life serve as the process through which the goal of a holy life can be realized. The statutes of the Lord are designed to be filters for our thoughts and actions. Through obedience in yielding to the process of making us holy, our impurities are caught and eliminated. God wants us to be holy. We represent God best to the world when we are living a holy life.

fields.verse: He was chosen before the creation of the world, but was revealed in these last times for your sake. - 1 Peter 1:20 (NIV)
fields.content: When the world was created, Jesus was there - not just as Creator, but also as Redeemer. In the plan of God is the knowledge that a creature created with a free will, could decide to break fellowship and would need a Reconciler. God, who is all knowing, knows any, and all variables in our decision process. Any way we choose can ultimately be a redemptive road; if we take it. Humans were created to have fellowship with God, and Jesus is the Way. If we initially make the wrong decision, God is the God of second chances. Whenever and wherever we find ourselves on the wrong path, we can be steered to the right fork of that road, or an exit ramp to make a course correction. It's been God's plan from the beginning. Choose wisely...choose God.

fields.verse: Though you have not seen him, you love him; and even though you do not see him now, you believe in him and are filled with an inexpressible and glorious joy, for you are receiving the end result of your faith, the salvation of your souls. - 1 Peter 1:8‭-‬9 (NIV)
fields.content: The Scriptures declare that Jesus was sent "in the fullness of time." He was born to an obscure family, in a nondescript village, at a time when people were looking for a messianic figure that didn't look like him. A handful of people were drawn to him out of curiosity, or his direct appeal to follow. For most of the people in his time, It didn't take long for life to go back to "normal" after he was crucified and buried. But for those who believed, his death, burial, and resurrection changed their lives. Their faith was sparked into life and their joy overflowed and could not be contained. Their experience was so vivid it dissolved any doubt that may have been left, and their mouths were open to testify to everyone they met. The next generation of those who came to believe never got to see him with their own eyes, but the experiences were just as real. Their faith was rewarded with the gift of abundant and eternal life that overcame the struggles of the here and now. And so it continues to be. Though we haven't seen, we believe and are filled with an inexpressible joy for our salvation secured by our faith in His promise.

fields.verse: Who is wise and understanding among you? Let them show it by their good life, by deeds done in the humility that comes from wisdom. - James 3:13 (NIV)
fields.content: The litmus test for wisdom and understanding is humility. We are accustomed to putting our sages on pedestals for their ability to make sense out of our times. We have certainly profited from their wisdom. Wisdom is supposed to translate into a life well lived, and good deeds matching our declarations. Genuine wisdom is best expressed in a humble life and service. As we get wiser, our lives are greatly enriched, and we recognize our service to others has profound implications as a witness to the world. Faith and actions go hand in hand. Faith saves; actions emanating from our faith are proof. We are saved by faith and faith alone, but faith is not static; we are saved by a faith that works. The wise humbly concur.

fields.verse: My dear brothers and sisters, take note of this: Everyone should be quick to listen, slow to speak and slow to become angry, because human anger does not produce the righteousness that God desires. - James 1:19‭-‬20 (NIV)
fields.content: A man was out for a nice drive on a winding mountain road. As he approached a blind curve, two men were standing on the side of the road and one of them yelled out, "PIG!". The driver yelled back, "IDIOT!" Whereupon the driver continued through the curve and promptly collided with a pig. The man on the side of the road said to his friend, "I guess I could have been clearer." Responding without understanding can result in unexpected repercussions. Reacting without clarity of the facts can lead to misunderstanding or humiliation. "Someone once said, "The only exercise some people get is jumping to conclusions." Take time to gather the facts. Listen carefully to what is being said. Fight the temptation to respond in anger when our positions are challenged. Listen carefully before we speak. When everyone else is hot, maintain your cool.

fields.verse: He chose to give us birth through the word of truth, that we might be a kind of firstfruits of all he created. - James 1:18 (NIV)
fields.content: It's the peak of summer in the South and the heat of the Sun is starting to take its toll on the fragile flowers of Spring. It wasn't that long ago when the first evidences of the coming summer peeked their little leaves above the ground or formed as buds in the trees and shrubs. Those seedlings and buds were the beginning of the fulfillment of God's promise that flowers, fruits, and vegetables were coming. They are the evidence of a new cycle of replenishing nourishment for the Earth's inhabitants. It's a stage in the circle of life. Likewise, we are seeds planted in the soil of history. God tends the garden. He provides the spark of life and we sprout in our due time. To us is given the opportunity to grow and reproduce after our kind. We are his declaration to the world that those who have received life are the promise of an abundant harvest to follow. Grow in the place you've been planted. Bear fruit; for in that fruit is the seed of hope for the next generation.

fields.verse: But when you ask, you must believe and not doubt, because the one who doubts is like a wave of the sea, blown and tossed by the wind. That person should not expect to receive anything from the Lord. Such a person is double-minded and unstable in all they do. - James 1:6‭-‬8 (NIV)
fields.content: Farmers who cast their seed into the wind without preparing their fields will get mixed results if any at all. Similarly, sailors who push away from shore without oars, sails, a motor, and fishing gear, cannot expect to reach their destination and catch their haul. Effective prayer has as its starting point a simple belief that: God is, he is good, he listens, and he responds. This basic belief strangles doubt and creates a path from our lips to God's ears. Approach God with a single mind and He will answer your prayers to the delight of your heart.

fields.verse: Remember your leaders, who spoke the word of God to you. Consider the outcome of their way of life and imitate their faith. - Hebrews 13:7 (NIV)
fields.content: It happened in the late 1980s; scandals struck the American church. Sexual immorality, infidelity, and financial misconduct were reported and confirmed in some of our biggest religious organizations. It rocked the Church to its very foundation and many were unsure if it would ever recover. It's amazing how a small number of people can influence our perspective. The innocents were defined by the few involved in the scandals, but as the old expression states; "Don't throw out the baby with the bathwater." There has always been a few bad apples in the basket of God's work, but the discerning know better. There are many faithful servants who diligently labor among us. Give them your attention and support. Encourage them in their leadership by following them as they live out genuine lives of faith following Jesus. Look beyond our leaders. Remember, it is the Leader of our leaders that we are a actually following. He won't disappoint.

fields.verse: No discipline seems pleasant at the time, but painful. Later on, however, it produces a harvest of righteousness and peace for those who have been trained by it. - Hebrews 12:11 (NIV)
fields.content: Discipline can be painful, but it is not punishment. A distinction must be made. Discipline is; a course of study or training leading to profitable gain. Musicians practice their scales to attain coordination of mind and fingers. Aspiring doctors endure the rigor of long nights learning their profession in the library, labs, and clinical observations. Athletes engage in varying exercises to gain the stamina, strength, and mental acumen to excel in their sport. Believers are tasked to train their faith through the discipline of prayer, scripture study, and relevant practical application. We put our faith under disciplined duress so that it will stand the test against unbelief, temptation, and doubt. Training can be mundane, taxing, and to a degree painful, but it pays great dividends when the demands of life call our faith into action.

fields.verse: All these people were still living by faith when they died. They did not receive the things promised; they only saw them and welcomed them from a distance, admitting that they were foreigners and strangers on earth. - Hebrews 11:13 (NIV)
fields.content: For over 2,000 years the world has been waiting for the Second Coming of Jesus. Generations have come and gone. All those before us lived in the entire spectrum of faith, and none so far has received the full reward of their belief. Sometimes the promises of God take more than one lifetime to fulfill. To be sure, we are given glimpses from a distance, but these glimpses are meant to inspire us to keep on believing. We see the City on a Hill, but we don't know how many valleys lie between us and our destination.  Pass the faith to your children, and to your children's children. Keep believing. Keep walking. The promise is real and true. Jesus, lead on.

fields.verse: For he was looking forward to the city with foundations, whose architect and builder is God. - Hebrews 11:10 (NIV)
fields.content: We invest a lot of time, effort, and resources into this life. We seek to enjoy the fruit of a life well lived; but in the back of our mind lies a thought which from time to time creeps to the front. Nobody gets out of life alive even though God created humans to live forever. Eventually we all board the trains to eternity and the Conductor punches our ticket to our final destination. The difference between one train and another is the quality of life the passengers choose for eternity. It is in this life we are given the opportunity to decide which train we're going to board and which city will be our eternal home. Jesus said; "I am the Way." Choosing to follow Him gets us on the train that reaches the city having no earthly equal. God himself designed and built it. It is marvelous to behold! We get to live there forever, and forever is a long, long time. It truly is something to look forward to.

fields.verse: And without faith it is impossible to please God, because anyone who comes to him must believe that he exists and that he rewards those who earnestly seek him. - Hebrews 11:6 (NIV)
fields.content: In a debate with an atheist a Christian posed a series of questions:  Christian: Of all the world's collective knowledge, how much of it do you possess?  Atheist: I don't know.  Christian: 50%?  Atheist: No.  Christian: 40%  Atheist: No.  Christian: 30%, 20, 10%?  Atheist: No, no, and no. Probably less than 1%. I suppose I possess a minute percentage of the world's collective knowledge.  Christian: Is it possible God exists in the knowledge you do not possess? Perhaps you will find him there.It doesn't take much, but it all begins with faith; faith that God rewards.  /20/2022Today's devotional in a nutshell:"You need to persevere so that when you have done the will of God, you will receive what he has promised. . .But we do not belong to those who shrink back and are destroyed, but to those who have faith and are saved." - Hebrews 10:36‭, ‬39 (NIV)Surrendering to the enemy is not an option. His objective is to steal, kill, and destroy. Nothing is off limits in his attempts to get us to submit. He is relentless. But "greater is He who is within us, than he who is in the world." God has equipped us with faith, hope, and the Word of God to wage war and win. We are to take the fight to the enemy and put him to flight. The best defense is a good offense. When we bowed to the Lordship of Jesus Christ, God turned us from victims to victors. Fight! Never, never give up.

fields.verse: Let us hold unswervingly to the hope we profess, for he who promised is faithful. - Hebrews 10:23 (NIV)
fields.content: Before the days of GPS, farmers relied on their own sight and skill to make straight rows for planting and harvesting. They would pick a spot at the end of their land (perhaps a tree, stone or stake driven into the ground) and fix their undivided attention on that marker. If their vision drifted to the left or right their team of horses would inevitably start drifting in that direction. If they concentrated on their furrows by looking back, the rows would end up wavy as they continually had to make corrections. Focusing on the marker insured the lines were plowed straight. So it is with being a follower of Jesus. He is our marker. He guides the way on the straight and narrow path. The distractions of life will come, as well as the temptation to look back, but fixing our unwavering eyes on Jesus keeps us walking straight toward the hope of his promises.

fields.verse: And so after waiting patiently, Abraham received what was promised. - Hebrews 6:15 (NIV)
fields.content: Waiting patiently is not a trait many of us possess. There is: anxious waiting, frustrated waiting, annoyed waiting, bored waiting, impatient waiting, but rarely is there patient waiting. Some things just take time. A house being built, a baby developing in the womb, graduation day, or even a prodigal child returning home, all take time. While we wait, the necessary preparation is taking place. At the proper time what we are waiting for is finally delivered. Waiting builds anticipation. When we receive what God has us waiting for, the weight of the wait falls off our shoulders and we will know, like Abraham, the promise was worth the wait.

fields.verse: We have much to say about this, but it is hard to make it clear to you because you no longer try to understand. - Hebrews 5:11 (NIV)
fields.content: "We've never done it that way before." and its cousin, "That's the way we've always done it." can be as troublesome as they can be comforting. Routine facilitates accomplishment; familiarity makes us feel safe because we can pretty much predict the outcome of our past efforts and experiences. Psychologists call it "confirmation bias." But, what if there is another way, a better way? What if, the way we've been doing it is the wrong way? Progress requires change, but the promise of better results must outweigh the effort it takes to change. It all starts with an open mind. If we are comfortable with what we know about God, if we are cruising toward our final destination, there is a good chance we are missing out on how much more of God there is to know. Consider the prayer of the psalmist: "Open my eyes that I may see wonderful things in your law." (Psalm 198:18 NIV) It may be time for a change.

fields.verse: Nothing in all creation is hidden from God’s sight. Everything is uncovered and laid bare before the eyes of him to whom we must give account . . . Let us then approach God’s throne of grace with confidence, so that we may receive mercy and find grace to help us in our time of need. - Hebrews 4:13‭, ‬16 (NIV)
fields.content: Since he sees all and knows all, we might as well quit trying to hide. God's desire is not to punish, but to extend grace. The ledger of our lives is filled with the red ink of sin that we cannot atone for. But God, who is rich in mercy, cancels our sin and writes "Paid in Full" on the bottom line. There is no hidden sin that he doesn't know about. There will be no surprises depriving us of his eternal fellowship. We can approach with confidence because he dispenses grace in abundance.

fields.verse: He also says, “In the beginning, Lord, you laid the foundations of the earth, and the heavens are the work of your hands. They will perish, but you remain; they will all wear out like a garment. You will roll them up like a robe; like a garment they will be changed. But you remain the same, and your years will never end.” - Hebrews 1:10‭-‬12 (NIV)
fields.content: The beauty of God's creation causes us to reflect. Away from the light pollution of the city, a multitude of stars, too many to be counted, puncture the black canvas of an endless space and fill the sky with an array of tiny points of light. It is a splendor to behold!  Then, as the early morning mist hovers over the water and the waning moon casts its reflection on the surface of the lake, the horizon begins to glow and the Sun begins its slow trek to gently dismiss the shadows of the forest trees. A lone moose saunters to the edge for a drink; all is serene. Our thoughts are steered to Other things. God's word declares that all of this will one day go away. He has plans for a new and better version of heaven and earth that will surpass the beauty of the present. It's hard to believe and even harder to understand how it can be any prettier, or better, but God has endless layers of creativity. He specializes in making something out of nothing. He created all we have experienced out of nothing. When it is all gone and there is nothing visible to work with, we know God has been there before and knows what to do. We will watch, wide-eyed and with bated breath, to see what God does with nothing. It's going to be glorious!

fields.verse: In the past God spoke to our ancestors through the prophets at many times and in various ways, but in these last days he has spoken to us by his Son, whom he appointed heir of all things, and through whom also he made the universe. - Hebrews 1:1‭-‬2 (NIV)
fields.content: We marvel at the sight of a bridge that spans a space that most thought would be impossible to cross. We gaze up in awe at a building that is so tall it seems to scrape the clouds. We are amazed when an aluminum tube streaks across the sky at 600 mph carrying 300 people to a destination in a mere few hours. But what is most incredible is that all these things were in the mind of the architect and engineer before they were built. They saw it before anyone else could see it. Before the planets were put into orbit; before the 3rd Rock from the Sun was singled out; before the mountains were shaped and the finger of the Creator drew the lines of the shore and sea and the valleys and rivers; before the fish of the sea and the animals in the fields were crafted, and the breath of God was inhaled by the human form He gathered from the dust of the earth; it was all in the mind of God. And so was the plan of God for the inevitable redemption that we'd need. It's all subtly declared in his creation, whispered in the longing of our soul, revealed by the message of the prophets, and manifested fully in the life and work of His Son. Before any of it became our reality, the Architect saw it.

fields.verse: I have fought the good fight, I have finished the race, I have kept the faith. - 2 Timothy 4:7 (NIV)
fields.content: "Lisa Jackson has run 110 marathons and ultramarathons around the world. After each, she has a tradition of sleeping with the new medal around her neck to celebrate her accomplishment. In 25 of those races, she was the final finisher -- and she revels in coming in last." When the starting horn sounds and the mass of participants set out on the course, we may feel like a drop in a bucket, but we will instantly be aware of the cloud of witnesses who have gone before us, lining the path cheering us on. We picture in our minds Jesus himself waiting at the finish line with a medal to drape around our necks and a laurel to set on our heads. No concern is given as to what place we will finish among the other competitors. So even if we find ourselves alone at the back of the pack, run. The goal of the marathon of faith is to finish. Everyone who finishes, wins.

fields.verse: For the time will come when people will not put up with sound doctrine. Instead, to suit their own desires, they will gather around them a great number of teachers to say what their itching ears want to hear. They will turn their ears away from the truth and turn aside to myths. - 2 Timothy 4:3‭-‬4 (NIV)
fields.content: The fundamentals of the faith is the glue that holds the Christian church together. In the fifth century the church finalized a concise statement of faith known as the Apostolic Creed. It contains, in abbreviated form, the essentials of Christian belief. If we edit it to explain away any of its foundational truth, we erode the basis of our fellowship. When we expand it to accommodate ideas and principles that contradict its basic truth, it can easily be a point of contention and division. To be sure, there are doctrinal distinctives that define particular denominations or movements, but the fundamentals keep us rooted and unified as believers regardless of the label we wear. When exposed to teaching and teachers expounding about the Message, we must continually ask the question; How does this help us to understand Christ and the core of Christianity? If it does, embrace it. If it doesn't, no matter what itch it may seem to satisfy, reject it outright. The building is sound when the foundation is secure.

fields.verse: All Scripture is God-breathed and is useful for teaching, rebuking, correcting and training in righteousness, so that the servant of God may be thoroughly equipped for every good work. - 2 Timothy 3:16, 17 (NIV)
fields.content: An artist set up her easel in a kiosk at a county fair. She had an array of brushes and other tools of the trade. Of interest was that she only had a handful of tubes of paint. She would expertly mix dabs from different tubes to make the exact colors she would use to interpret the world around her. She breathed life into her mixes as she deftly covered her canvas. On display were samples of her work. She was good...very good. God has chosen a handful of people out of millions, over hundreds of years, to communicate his Message. Using the limits of language, He masterfully mixed personalities, circumstances, and history to flawlessly declare and deliver his plan to his people. These are not dead words from dead people; they are infused with the life-giving breath of God. As a whole, they communicate everything we need for life and service. His work is on display everywhere we look. He is good...very good.

fields.verse: Do your best to present yourself to God as one approved, a worker who does not need to be ashamed and who correctly handles the word of truth. - 2 Timothy 2:15 (NIV)
fields.content: It was the bottom of the ninth, the score was tied, bases were loaded, there were two outs, and the batter had already struck out 3 times before. The incoming pitch was an outside fastball that clipped the corner for a called strike. The next pitch was exactly like the first, but this time the batter swung and missed; strike two. The next two pitches were outside the strike zone as the pitcher tried get him to chase a bad pitch. The batter settled in and waited for the next pitch. It looked like the curve ball would slide out of the strike zone, but he couldn't take a chance. He swung. He swung hard. The ball barely hit off the end of the bat and a very slow roller dribbled out between the pitcher and first baseman. As the runner raced to first, the pitcher threw to the second baseman covering first and the umpire called the runner safe. . .safe by an eyelash. The runner on third scored and the game ended with a 1-0 decision. It wasn't the best swing, but it was his best swing. In a different inning it may not have mattered, but in the ninth inning it was the swing that won the game. Give it your best. Do your best. Sometimes 80% is 100% if it's the best you can do.

fields.verse: Flee the evil desires of youth and pursue righteousness, faith, love and peace, along with those who call on the Lord out of a pure heart. - 2 Timothy 2:22 (NIV)
fields.content: Immature people make the same bad decisions repeatedly. A sign of stunted growth is the failure to learn from past experiences. Sometimes we need to walk away from a detrimental desire; other times we need to run. But it is not enough to run away, we must also have a positive place to run to. Evil desires can be neutralized and replaced by righteousness, faith, love, and peace. Learning from past mistakes is a sign of maturity. While immaturity is rife with drama; mature people live lives of greater contentment.

fields.verse: Reflect on what I am saying, for the Lord will give you insight into all this. - 2 Timothy 2:7 (NIV)
fields.content: Hindsight is 20/20, but it is bittersweet if we've made a premature, incorrect decision. Whenever a difficult decision has to be made, the words of my mother echo in my soul. "Piénsalo bien," (Think it well through.) Some decisions seem casual, reasonable, instinctual, and then we find out later there was more that should have been taken into consideration. Other times there is a perceived urgency that demands action, but rare is the situation when one can bypass giving our decisions some thought. Resist the bait. Take the Apostle's advice. Spend enough time in reflection until you sense the Lord has spoken. Piénsalo bien.

fields.verse: I am reminded of your sincere faith, which first lived in your grandmother Lois and in your mother Eunice and, I am persuaded, now lives in you also. - 2 Timothy 1:5 (NIV)
fields.content: Noted evangelist D.L. Moody was once asked how many converts he had at a gospel meeting. He responded; "Two and a half." His questioners followed up; "Two adults and a child?" "No", Moody replied; "Two children and a man who had already wasted half his life." We rejoice in the sensationally saved. Those who have a history of a wild life devoid of any interest in spiritual things, who seemingly, suddenly have an eye-opening encounter with God get a lot of attention. But those who gently and unassumingly follow after God without fanfare, because they responded to the living witness of a mother or grandfather, often go unnoticed. A half life of devotion and service is wonderful, but several generations of continuous faithful service is a miracle of a special kind. Pray that the legacy of family faith will be the testimony of your children, and your children's children.

fields.verse: . . .God, the blessed and only Ruler, the King of kings and Lord of Lords, who alone is immortal and who lives in unapproachable light, whom no one has seen or can see. To him be honor and might forever. Amen. - 1 Timothy 6:15‭-‬16 (NIV)
fields.content: Jesus was God in the flesh. He made God identifiable and approachable. He walked among us, talked to us, ate with us, healed us, and taught us. In Him we saw a glimpse of the Father, yet God continues to remain in a shroud of mystery. He can relate to his creation, but as one who exists outside of it. He himself is invisible, but can be seen through eyes of faith in all he has created. He is immortal, invisible, and the depth of his wisdom is unimaginable. The life of Jesus reveals much we can praise God for, but there is another dimension that is superimposed over what he has revealed. He is more, much more than we can see, and that inspires eternal reverence, awe, and praise.

fields.verse: Do not rebuke an older man harshly, but exhort him as if he were your father. Treat younger men as brothers, older women as mothers, and younger women as sisters, with absolute purity. - 1 Timothy 5:1‭-‬2 (NIV)
fields.content: "R-E-S-P-E-C-T, find out what it means to me" was blasted from transistor radios in the 1960s, and is considered a MOTOWN classic to this day. Whether as a client, patient, customer, employee, neighbor or family member, we all desire to be treated with respect. Some say it has to be earned, but what if respect was the default? After all, we are created in the image of God who is worthy of the highest level of respect. Consider a world where we treat, and are all treated with kindness, compassion, and love, dressed elegantly with respect. A little respect goes a long way toward establishing and maintaining civility. Loving one another includes R-E-S-P-E-C-T. It reflects the values of the Kingdom.

fields.verse: I urge, then, first of all, that petitions, prayers, intercession and thanksgiving be made for all people— for kings and all those in authority, that we may live peaceful and quiet lives in all godliness and holiness. This is good, and pleases God our Savior, who wants all people to be saved and to come to a knowledge of the truth. - 1 Timothy 2:1‭-‬4 (NIV)
fields.content: It's been said that politicians only care about two things: getting elected and staying elected. The electorate is dissatisfied with their performance in office, yet almost 90% of our politicians are reelected in any given cycle. Is cynicism inevitable? Those in authority need prayer. Prayer for: wisdom, for godly counsel and counselors, for courage in the face of temptation, for strength of conscience, and for moral and ethical clarity. Our times, as all times in history, require that we pray for those in authority. What would happen if we prayed for our leaders at least as much as we complain about them? Paul, under the guidance of the Holy Spirit writes that we can "live peaceful and quiet lives in all godliness and holiness" if we pray for our leaders. Prayer changes things.

fields.verse: Here is a trustworthy saying that deserves full acceptance: Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners—of whom I am the worst. But for that very reason I was shown mercy so that in me, the worst of sinners, Christ Jesus might display his immense patience as an example for those who would believe in him and receive eternal life. - 1 Timothy 1:15‭-‬16 (NIV)
fields.content: We don't have to look far to see that there are some really bad people in the world. Our daily headlines attest that this is true. We may believe they are irredeemable, yet Paul, the worst sinner of his day, was brought to his knees by Jesus. Keep praying for the worst sinners you know. Continue witnessing to them at every available opportunity. The patience of God is at work as he steers them towards an encounter with the Savior. Don't give up. As long as there is breath, there is hope.

fields.verse: And as for you, brothers and sisters, never tire of doing what is good. - 2 Thessalonians 3:13 (NIV)
fields.content: A retired pastor was asked to come back to his former church to speak at an anniversary dinner. He opened his remarks by saying, "I labored faithfully in this part of God's vineyard for almost three decades. I was paid for being good. Now that I'm retired, I'm good for nothing." The call to be a disciple is a lifetime calling regardless of tangible benefits. We labor on in devotion to our God even when the returns are slim or not at all. Being good is its own reward. It's ironic and difficult to understand, but the One who will greet you at the end, is the same One who was alongside you the entire way. Slow your pace if you have to, but keep running the good race until you cross the finish line.

fields.verse: As for other matters, brothers and sisters, pray for us that the message of the Lord may spread rapidly and be honored, just as it was with you. - 2 Thessalonians 3:1 (NIV)
fields.content: What an honor and joy it is when people respond favorably to the Message! Currently, in our nation, we are struggling with spiritual stagnancy and decline. Conversion rates are being reported that are among the lowest recorded since surveys have been conducted. Church attendance is at the lowest percentage in a century. The telltale sign is the unraveling of our social fabric. That's the bad news. The good news is that the Gospel thrives and prevails under these conditions if the People of God humble themselves, seek God's face, pray, and share the hope that is in Jesus. The Bible talks about a great falling away that will take place, but it will happen alongside a great season of soul harvesting. We can curse the darkness around us, or we can light a candle. Share the light.

fields.verse: May our Lord Jesus Christ himself and God our Father, who loved us and by his grace gave us eternal encouragement and good hope, encourage your hearts and strengthen you in every good deed and word. - 2 Thessalonians 2:16‭-‬17 (NIV)
fields.content: "May the wind be always at your back. May the sun shine warm upon your face; the rains fall soft upon your fields and until we meet again, may God hold you in the palm of His hand." - Irish PrayerThe Irish have a tradition of composing some of the most beautiful prayers and benedictions. They are often used as a congratulatory toast at weddings and parties, or pronounced upon the People of God when they are dismissed from church services. The first and last words uttered when we encounter family and friends should be a blessing they can walk under and remember as a sweet fragrance of our meeting. Note especially the prayers in, and the closing benedictions at the end of Paul's epistles. They linger in our hearts and minds long after the good Book is closed.

fields.verse: The one who calls you is faithful, and he will do it. - 1 Thessalonians 5:24 (NIV)
fields.content: "One day Jesus said to his disciples, “Let us go over to the other side of the lake.” So they got into a boat and set out. As they sailed, he fell asleep. A squall came down on the lake, so that the boat was being swamped, and they were in great danger. The disciples went and woke him, saying, "Master, Master, we’re going to drown!” He got up and rebuked the wind and the raging waters; the storm subsided, and all was calm. “Where is your faith?” he asked his disciples. In fear and amazement they asked one another, “Who is this? He commands even the winds and the water, and they obey him.” - Luke 8:22-25 (NIV)Our faith may falter in the midst of a storm, but concentrate on what he said he would do. He said they were going to the other side of the lake. Even a storm couldn't stop him. He is faithful, and he will do it. Bank on it.

fields.verse: Rejoice always, pray continually, give thanks in all circumstances; for this is God’s will for you in Christ Jesus. - 1 Thessalonians 5:16‭-18 (NIV)
fields.content: We stress over wondering what God's will is for our lives. Sometimes he lays it out clearly, served on a silver pattern. Look around, there's always something to be joyful about, pray for, or be content with. When we occupy ourselves with these things, we'll be dead-center in the will of God. Other aspects of God's will are more readily revealed while we are engaged in the parts of God's will that are obvious. When they are, do that too. Until then, there is a lot of God's will that will keep us busy and fulfilled.

fields.verse: . . .make it your ambition to lead a quiet life: You should mind your own business... - 1 Thessalonians 4:11‭ (NIV)
fields.content: It is no secret that social media has transformed our world. It has made it almost impossible to escape the noise of life; it follows us no matter where we go. It encumbers us with information, from near and far, that inhibits our ability to carve out a quiet space. This cacophony of countless voices often distracts us from thinking and acting through on the things that matter most. They compete with our inner voice calling us to step away. We must whittle away at insignificant intrusions by periodically turning off the smart phone, radio, or television, and build, even if it is a minute at a time, the discipline of observing quiet time. Take a leisurely walk with no specific destination in mind. Browse through a museum, art gallery, or thrift store. Read a story to a child. Simplify and add value to your life and find contentment in peace and quiet. Remember, even God stepped back and took a break.

fields.verse: For now we really live, since you are standing firm in the Lord. - 1 Thessalonians 3:8 (NIV)
fields.content: Exhilaration! Mountain climbers, experience it when they finally reach the peak of their climb. Skydivers bathe in it as they fly through the sky. Mother's glow moments after the most arduous experience of their lives. For believers, it is the pure satisfaction of knowing they are walking in perfect harmony with the Lord. These are examples of life at its best. Every cell in your body pulses with excitement when you venture out to the edge of your faith and take one more step. Playing it safe is a good strategy most of the time, but testing your limits reveals a broader arena in which you can play it safe. He came to bring us life, and that to the full! Surprise yourself; reach out beyond your accepted limit. Really live!

fields.verse: For this reason, when I could stand it no longer, I sent to find out about your faith. I was afraid that in some way the tempter had tempted you and that our labors might have been in vain. - 1 Thessalonians 3:5 (NIV)
fields.content: We live in a time of unbelievable mobility. Our families are scattered. Friends we grew up with, or made in college, can now live in other towns, states and even countries. We also live in a time of unlimited connectivity. It used to be easy to lose track, but now with electronic devices we carry in our pockets, it is possible to communicate with them at will. We value these conversations as we delight in their exploits, catch up on the latest developments in their lives, reminisce about times past, and share our dreams and goals. But the most important question we can be asked is; "How is it with your soul?" Anything else pales in comparison. Because we are surrounded by temptation and offered distracting options, it is easy to drift and lose our way. A godly friend or family member can remind us to stay on the right road. Make a connection today.  Encourage your family and friends in their faith. It is the best way to show them how deeply you care. How goes it today with you?

fields.verse: You became imitators of us and of the Lord, for you welcomed the message in the midst of severe suffering with the joy given by the Holy Spirit. - 1 Thessalonians 1:6
fields.content: We've seen the scene played out numerous times in movies. In the midst of darkness, despair, and distress, there is a sudden sigh of relief and then a smile, as the rescuer appears. The gospel is a welcomed message, especially in times of severe suffering. While we were yet sinners, Christ died for us. He rescued us from our gloom and doom and replaced our sadness with joy. "Amazing grace, how sweet the sound, that saved a wretch like me. I once was lost, but now I'm found, was blind but now I see." Weep no more! Smile, we've been redeemed.

fields.verse: Let the message of Christ dwell among you richly as you teach and admonish one another with all wisdom through psalms, hymns, and songs from the Spirit, singing to God with gratitude in your hearts. - Colossians 3:16 (NIV)
fields.content: It's been said that the two most important books in a believer's library are the Bible and a hymnal. The hymnal is a great collection of the truths of the Word combined with beautiful music and lyrics. Whether in times of joy or struggle, it is not unusual for us to seek comfort by reading the Bible or singing a spiritual song. Singing as a people gathered for worship, the sound of 3 part harmony stirs us deep within our souls. In many churches the hymnal has been replaced by words projected on a screen, but it would be worth it to take some time to revisit and reflect in a hymnal. The richness and the depth of Biblical teaching is a wonderful complement to the Word of God. "I love thee for wearing the thorns on thy brow. If ever I loved thee, my Jesus tis now."

fields.verse: Therefore, as God’s chosen people, holy and dearly loved, clothe yourselves with compassion, kindness, humility, gentleness and patience. Bear with each other and forgive one another if any of you has a grievance against someone. Forgive as the Lord forgave you. - Colossians 3:12‭-‬13 (NIV)
fields.content: Retaliation and vengeance may provide short-lived satisfaction, but: "An eye for an eye makes the whole world blind." A life of holiness is counterintuitive. Followers of Jesus are called to a different standard. When wronged, our flesh cries out for retribution while our faith whispers to respond with kindness and compassion. The flesh declares war; faith seeks peace. Flesh ignites, faith disarms. How far do we take gentleness, patience, and forgiveness? As far as God took it on our behalf. We follow a standard the world doesn't understand, but the only way they'll understand is if we follow the standard.

fields.verse: For he has rescued us from the dominion of darkness and brought us into the kingdom of the Son he loves, in whom we have redemption, the forgiveness of sins. - Colossians 1:13‭-‬14 (NIV)
fields.content: On this, the Lord's day, we gather for inspiration, instruction, and fellowship. We sympathize with our fellow travelers and encourage one another to keep pressing forward with our eyes on the prize. But sometime during the day, we should pause and reflect on the Great Work that we celebrate each time we come together. Our sins have been forgiven, we've been transferred from darkness to light, our redemption is complete because of what Jesus did on the Cross. "How marvelous! how wonderful! And my song shall ever be. How marvelous and how wonderful! Is my Savior's love for me!"

fields.verse: In those days Israel had no king; everyone did as they saw fit. - Judges 21:25 (NIV)
fields.content: This is the second time we come across this statement. Between the two references is recorded the disaster of internal fighting. Israel was charged to conquer the land of Promise as a single, unified people. It didn't take long for divisions to form. As a result, energy that was to be harnessed for fighting a common enemy was wasted fighting amongst themselves. Jesus' final prayer was for his followers "to be one." After his Ascension, his disciples gathered in the upper room "in one accord." The Apostle Paul urged the believers at Ephesus to "seek the unity of the Spirit in the bond of peace." Unity is not compromise. It is working together on common ground to secure the blessings of God. In unity there is strength.

fields.verse: In those days Israel had no king; everyone did as they saw fit. - Judges 17:6 (NIV)
fields.content: In order to function successfully, leadership is indispensable. Individual autonomy is likely to be chaotic when it overlaps with other members in a group. When people are committed to doing what each seems fit to do, varying and multiple standards can be confusing. Good, true leaders see the bigger picture. They lead the group to the greatest common good. Families, communities, or nations, function best when one person is leading at any given time. Two heads may be better than one in brainstorming potential solutions, but one head at the helm will lead to getting the problem solved.

fields.verse: You will become pregnant and have a son whose head is never to be touched by a razor because the boy is to be a Nazirite, dedicated to God from the womb. He will take the lead in delivering Israel from the hands of the Philistines.” - Judges 13:5 (NIV)
fields.content: Samson's mother's name is not recorded in scripture, yet she was entrusted with bearing and raising a child who would one day be a hero in Israel. History is replete with anonymity. The supporting cast that makes things happen play small connective roles that complete the collective whole. Without their anonymous contributions, things would never happen. Resist the idea that your life is mundane or meaningless. Your diligence in fulfilling your role, no matter how small, is critical to the completion of God's plan. He knows your name.

fields.verse: Then they gathered around him and asked him, 'Lord, are you at this time going to restore the kingdom to Israel?' He said to them: “It is not for you to know the times or dates the Father has set by his own authority. - Acts 1:6‭-‬7 (NIV)
fields.content: Some things are better left unknown. When a seed is planted, it must remain undisturbed. Digging it up every day to check on its progress is not how seeds are meant to work. There is mystery in what happens in the seed's interaction with soil and water, but it results in the germinated seed starting its trek toward the life sustaining sun. The Seed of our redemption was planted for three nights in the parenthetical place where miracles happen. There it burst into new life. No one knows how it happened, but now it is growing, flourishing, preparing to bear the eternal fruit of God's love. The fruit will come in its appointed season. It will be provision and sustenance for all who want to partake. In the meanwhile, anticipation is building as we prepare for the day when we will be seated at the Lord's table.

fields.verse: If you are afraid to attack, go down to the camp with your servant Purah and listen to what they are saying. Afterward, you will be encouraged to attack the camp.” So he and Purah his servant went down to the outposts of the camp. The Midianites, the Amalekites and all the other eastern peoples had settled in the valley, thick as locusts. Their camels could no more be counted than the sand on the seashore. - Judges 7:10‭-‬12 (NIV)
fields.content: At times, how and why God wants to do something is puzzling. The army of the enemies of God were vast in number, impossible to count. Yet God whittled down the size of the Israelite army to 300 soldiers whose main qualification had to do with how they drank water from a river. The whole situation seemed set up for failure, except that the fear in the enemy's camp was vast, deep, and real. Chaos descended amongst them and it was a rout. When we stand strong in the Lord and the power of his might, our enemies scatter. Do not fear the size of the opposition. God's way may be unconventional, but the result speaks for itself.

fields.verse: Gideon said to God, 'If you will save Israel by my hand as you have promised— look, I will place a wool fleece on the threshing floor. If there is dew only on the fleece and all the ground is dry, then I will know that you will save Israel by my hand, as you said.' And that is what happened. . . -Judges 6:36‭-‬38a (NIV)
fields.content: The line between faith and unbelief is definitively bold. Faith has evidence that is not seen, unbelief rejects undeniable facts. On the other hand, faith and doubt are often found walking side by side. Doubt seeks authentication; faith is having just enough verification to prompt a response to action. Each of us is found on a different part of the faith/doubt spectrum. God is not offended by our request to bridge the gap between the two. Go ahead; ask God for confirmation. When the gap is sufficiently narrowed, take the leap of faith and reap the blessings of obedience.

fields.verse: The Lord turned to him and said, “Go in the strength you have and save Israel out of Midian’s hand. Am I not sending you?” - Judges 6:14 (NIV)
fields.content: Many things stand out in Scripture and this is one of them: If you doubt your ability, you come from a lineage of people God has used mightily. It almost seems to be part of the job description. The strength we have is enhanced by the fact of God's calling. Exploits are waiting to be undertaken that don't require more than what we already have. Let our motto be: They told me it couldn't be done, but God was calling and I did it anyway.

fields.verse: When the angel of the Lord appeared to Gideon, he said, “The Lord is with you, mighty warrior.” “Pardon me, my Lord,” Gideon replied, “but if the Lord is with us, why has all this happened to us? Where are all his wonders that our ancestors told us about when they said, ‘Did not the Lord bring us up out of Egypt?’ But now the Lord has abandoned us and given us into the hand of Midian.” - Judges 6:12‭-‬13 (NIV)
fields.content: There are times when we experience doubt. Our circumstances obscure our view like clouds that hide the sun. Even looking back at what God has done        fails to spur our faith for the present, let alone our future. Our enemies declare victory. Gideon was about to experience how God can stir up dormant, or even dead faith to prevail over a bad situation. Faith is often at its best when it's not working. It's easy to believe when the evidence supports our faith, but when we are in full blown doubt, when we have nothing left but pure faith, God uses those moments to expand our understanding of what it is to believe. The evidence may say we are forsaken, but it just may be setting us up for a fresh visitation from God.

fields.verse: Speaking of Sisera, the commander of the Canaanite army: Because he had nine hundred chariots fitted with iron and had cruelly oppressed the Israelites for twenty years, they cried to the Lord for help. Now Deborah, a prophet, the wife of Lappidoth, was leading Israel at that time. - Judges 4:3‭-‬4 (NIV)
fields.content: The culture of biblical times was patriarchal (led by men). We can discuss that issue at a later date. But let's look at a specific time when a woman was called to lead. The size of the enemy's army impressed and oppressed Israel. Leave it to God to pick an unconventional way to make a point. God chose a woman to take on what looked to be an impossible task. She rose to the occasion and beat back the enemies of the people of God. Some call it "operating outside the box," except God can't be put in a box. Look beyond the status quo. Be prepared to break a routine. Expect the unexpected. The greatest victories come when God chooses the method and means.

"After that whole generation had been gathered to their ancestors, another generation grew up who knew neither the Lord nor what he had done for Israel." - Judges 2:10 (NIV)Joshua's generation had experienced slavery, deliverance, God's miraculous provision during 40 years of wandering in the desert, and a successful campaign to claim the land promised to them. Yet somehow the next generation failed to see the Lord and his hand in making it all happen. Nothing can be more devastating than to see our children live as if God doesn't exist. But the story is not over.
