God creates all things out of his will and for a purpose; and is why life has meaning. An artist paints for pleasure, but the pleasure is enhanced when he creates it for a particular use. The finished masterpiece hangs in a gallery for all to see and enjoy. We gaze at the art in awe, and marvel at the creativity of the Master. The skill of the Creator is all around us for his, and our, enjoyment. Yes, He is worthy of glory and honor. Our proper and only response is to bow.

fields.verse: You say, ‘I am rich; I have acquired wealth and do not need a thing.’ But you do not realize that you are wretched, pitiful, poor, blind and naked. I counsel you to buy from me gold refined in the fire, so you can become rich; and white clothes to wear, so you can cover your shameful nakedness; and salve to put on your eyes, so you can see. - Revelation 3:17‭-‬18 (NIV)
fields.content: "We work our fingers to the bone and all we have to show for it is bony fingers." We find ourselves trying, working, even praying, harder to the extent of being filled with anxiety, depression, and defeat. We find it difficult to ask for help. Our confidence in ourselves tries desperately to conjure up the ideas, schemes, and plans for success. We can do it! We tell ourselves; but sometimes we have to admit that, no we can't. Those who don't reach the point of acknowledging their weaknesses suffer from the delusion of self-sufficiency. The all sufficient Savior bids us to stop spinning our wheels. Let us humbly go to that quiet place to meet with the One who longs to supply us with the antidote to poverty of soul when the shame of our naked inability is exposed. Admit your weakness and be clothed with his strength. He will richly supply.

“To the angel of the church in Laodicea write: These are the words of the Amen, the faithful and true witness, the ruler of God’s creation. I know your deeds, that you are neither cold nor hot. I wish you were either one or the other! So, because you are lukewarm—neither hot nor cold—I am about to spit you out of my mouth." - Revelation 3:14‭-‬16 (NIV)Some like their coffee or tea hot or iced. We'd be hard pressed to find a person who likes room temperature coffee or tepid tea. So it is in our approach to serving the Lord. Laodicea was know for hot springs and cool refreshing streams. People would journey there depending on their needs. John endorses the two as alternatively good approaches to walking with Jesus. We seek out people who refresh us or deliver therapeutic warmth. They make invaluable contributions to the Body. But we avoid those who are indifferent or unconcerned. Depending on the need, the choices are as clear as hot or cold. Choose one or the other. Anything in the middle pleases no one.

fields.verse: “To the angel of the church in Philadelphia write: These are the words of him who is holy and true, who holds the key of David. What he opens no one can shut, and what he shuts no one can open. I know your deeds. See, I have placed before you an open door that no one can shut. I know that you have little strength, yet you have kept my word and have not denied my name. . .Since you have kept my command to endure patiently, I will also keep you from the hour of trial that is going to come on the whole world to test the inhabitants of the earth. I am coming soon. Hold on to what you have, so that no one will take your crown.  The one who is victorious I will make a pillar in the temple of my God . . . Whoever has ears, let them hear what the Spirit says to the churches. - Revelation 3:7‭-‬13 (NIV)
fields.content: Unlike the messages to the other churches, John's word for the church in Philadelphia is all encouragement, no rebuke. They had little strength, but what little they had was invested in faithfulness to Jesus. They endured their hardship patiently as they awaited the coming of the Savior. To them was promised an open door of unlimited potential and possibilities. They just had to keep doing what they were already doing...holding on. When we find ourselves surrounded by enemies, feeling like our strength is failing, and questioning whether we have what it takes to make it, remember; He is there. At our darkest hour and in our weakest moment, He shows His strength. We are fortified by his promises. Hold on!

fields.verse: “To the angel   of the church in Sardis write:. . .I know your deeds; you have a reputation of being alive, but you are dead. Wake up! Strengthen what remains and is about to die, for I have found your deeds unfinished in the sight of my God.  Remember, therefore, what you have received and heard; hold it fast, and repent. . .Yet you have a few people in Sardis who have not soiled their clothes. They will walk with me, dressed in white, for they are worthy. The one who is victorious will, like them, be dressed in white. I will never blot out the name of that person from the book of life, but will acknowledge that name before my Father and his angels. Whoever has ears, let them hear what the Spirit says to the churches. - Revelation 3:1‭-‬6 (NIV)
fields.content: Within the people who call themselves the people of God, reside the actual people of God. The church at Sardis is an example. It was a mixed bag of genuine believers and imposters. It is not uncommon for goats, and even wolves, to mingle with the sheep and lambs. It can all be bundled up to look like a healthy environment, but the composition of a church can often be different than the character of a church. There will come a time to separate the sheep from the goats; there is no mistaking which is which. Look for and associate with the ones who are sincere about their faith and service. Better yet, be one!

fields.verse: To the angel of the church in Thyatira write: These are the words of the Son of God. . .I know your deeds, your love and faith, your service and perseverance, and that you are now doing more than you did at first. Nevertheless, I have this against you: You tolerate that woman Jezebel, who calls herself a prophet. . .Now I say to the rest of you in Thyatira, to you who do not hold to her teaching. . .‘I will not impose any other burden on you, except to hold on to what you have until I come.’ To the one who is victorious and does my will to the end, I will give authority over the nations... - Revelation 2:18‭-‬20‭, ‬24‭-‬26 (NIV)
fields.content: Thyatira, the fourth church, was facing the danger of false prophets and heretical teachers. The effects cannot be understated. A long history of being and doing right can be undermined and undone by drifting or being led into false teaching. Compromising conscience and condoning immorality are two obvious signs that the spirit of Jezebel is in our midst. Incessant pressure must be applied to purge the Church of false teachers and followers of heresy. We are charged with protecting and preserving the holiness of the people of God. To do so ensures we have moral authority and the respect of the nations.

fields.verse: “. . .These are the words of him who has the sharp, double-edged sword.  I know where you live—where Satan has his throne. Yet you remain true to my name. You did not renounce your faith in me. . .Nevertheless, I have a few things against you: There are some among you who hold to the teaching of Balaam, who taught Balak to entice the Israelites to sin. . .Repent therefore! Otherwise, I will soon come to you and will fight against them with the sword of my mouth.   Whoever has ears, let them hear what the Spirit says to the churches. To the one who is victorious, I will give some of the hidden manna. I will also give that person a white stone with a new name written on it, known only to the one who receives it. - Revelation 2:12‭-‬17 (NIV)
fields.content: John turns his attention to the third church he has a message for. We are all aware of places in the world that are defined by the lies, crime, and corruption in them. One in our own country is pridefully nicknamed "Sin City." There are some places that are saturated with spiritual wickedness and heresy as well. Their way of life has become so normal that the people of God drop their guard and get swept up in it. Once made aware of these unholy beliefs and practices, the call is to do a 180 degree turn to return to truth. It takes hearing that is tuned to the Spirit's voice to be aware of our spiritual condition. But those who hear will be fed with spiritual food and be acknowledged as victors. Don't vacillate. Stay the course. Be in the world, but not of the world.

fields.verse: “...These are the words of him who is the First and the Last, who died and came to life again. I know your afflictions and your poverty—yet you are rich!...Do not be afraid of what you are about to suffer. I tell you, the devil will put some of you in prison to test you, and you will suffer persecution for ten days. Be faithful, even to the point of death, and I will give you life as your victor’s crown... - Revelation 2:8‭-‬11 (NIV)
fields.content: John's message to the church at Smyrna is a word of encouragement to persevere during difficulty and duress. The People of God throughout the world, live in various levels of freedom or persecution. Those who are suffering need the provision of God and support of His people. It is the presence of God that turns our poverty into riches, our tests into a testimony. We grasp ahold of the victory that is now, or will eventually come, regardless of the circumstances. Faithfulness is a lifetime pursuit.

fields.verse: I know your deeds, your hard work and your perseverance. I know that you cannot tolerate wicked people, that you have tested those who claim to be apostles but are not, and have found them false. You have persevered and have endured hardships for my name, and have not grown weary. Yet I hold this against you: You have forsaken the love you had at first. - Revelation 2:2‭-‬4 (NIV)
fields.content: We've seen it, and perhaps we have personally experienced it; commitment without passion. It's like employees who put in the time, do their job, punch the clock, and then go home. It is revealed in the couple who sit across the dinner table and rarely make eye contact or share a word. The People of God are not immune. We take orders, defend the gates, march forward to free occupied territory, return to the barracks, put the day behind us, and prep for the next battle. Duty without devotion. When that happens, we are reminded to return to the love that attracted us to the Savior; the love that compelled us to give it all up to follow Him. Abundant life requires that we love with abandon.

fields.verse: Whoever has ears, let them hear what the Spirit says to the churches... - Revelation 2:7a (NIV)
fields.content: Seven churcheTdressed in the Revelation; each ends with the statement, "Whoever has ears..." John makes clear that it is not him, nor the church leader, the one he is directing his audience to hear. It is the Spirit's voice that we are to discern. Certainly there is a role for apostolic leadership and teachers in the Body of Christ, but there is a voice that transcends and interprets the message, so that it conforms to the purposes and will of God. When listening to a teacher, or reading the Word of God, we must ask; "What is the Spirit saying?"  Listen and you will hear words of life.

fields.verse: . . .“Write on a scroll what you see and send it to the seven churches: to Ephesus, Smyrna, Pergamum, Thyatira, Sardis, Philadelphia and Laodicea.”   . . .“Write, therefore, what you have seen, what is now and what will take place later.  The mystery of the seven stars that you saw in my right hand and of the seven golden lampstands is this: The seven stars are the angels  of the seven churches, and the seven lampstands are the seven churches. - Revelation 1:11‭, ‬19‭-‬20 (NIV)
fields.content: All believers share common characteristics and yet each person is unique. The same is true of churches. The common ground holds us together, the nuances provide us with personality. In the gathered community the me melds into we. God speaks to the collective a word that is greater than its individual parts. The Revelation continues as God provides the course corrections to 7 churches and their leaders to keep his people on track. Pay close attention. What God speaks to us, he speaks to all.

fields.verse: I, John, your brother and companion in the suffering and kingdom and patient endurance that are ours in Jesus, was on the island of Patmos because of the word of God and the testimony of Jesus. On the Lord’s Day I was in the Spirit, and I heard behind me a loud voice like a trumpet, - Revelation 1:9‭-‬10 (NIV)
fields.content: John was banished to a lonely place because he wouldn't stop talking about Jesus; but it was in that lonely place where Jesus was able to speak to him. It happened on the Lord's day while he was worshipping. The voice was loud and clear blasting away any and all distractions. It was a perfect place and a perfect time to hear from the Lord. When the world shuts its ears to our witness and we are relegated to the fringes, let's take the time to worship and receive a clearer picture from the Lord of where we've been, where we are, and where we're going. In the quiet, lonely places, we prepare for the next time we get to speak.

"“I am the Alpha and the Omega,” says the Lord God, “who is, and who was, and who is to come, the Almighty.”  Revelation 1:8 (NIV)And so we begin our look at the inspiration of Revelation. We start with the One who is the beginning and the end, the Alpha and Omega. God was there at the beginning of our history though he has no beginning of his own. He has always been. He'll be there at the close of history as he ushers in the Eternal Epoch. But these are not mere parenthesis of his presence; he is here right now, orchestrating his plan for us. Come near to him and he will draw near to you. It is not only that he was, or will be, but he is. His companionship and guidance are available to us now; it always was and always will be. To infinity and beyond!

fields.verse: Blessed is the one who reads aloud the words of this prophecy, and blessed are those who hear it and take to heart what is written in it, because the time is near. - Revelation 1:3 (NIV)
fields.content: In Genesis, we see where it all began for us, in the Garden. In Revelation we will take the last leg of the trip to our final destination, the New Jerusalem. In between, we've been admonished, encouraged, consoled, challenged, taught and inspired, mostly in words we understood. Now we will encounter symbols, creatures, second and double meanings, and visions that are difficult to interpret. Life is like that. There are things we understand, others we can interpret, and a part of life that we may experience, but never fully understand. Yet we press on; we plow through it, because it is a vital part of our faith walk with our Creator. Keep reading the Book. You'll experience the blessing of God if you do. There is enough there we can understand to gird us up while we go through the part that isn't clear.

fields.verse: But you, dear friends, by building yourselves up in your most holy faith and praying in the Holy Spirit, keep yourselves in God’s love as you wait for the mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ to bring you to eternal life. - Jude 1:20‭-‬21 (NIV)
fields.content: The life of a Believer is built in the dynamic tension between the Divine imperative and the human initiative. Intimacy with God does not happen in a vacuum. God provides us with everything we need to build a temple wherein he will dwell. He provides the blueprint and materials; we are to utilize the tools he provides while he supervises what we build. The chief building blocks include: knowing what and why we believe, praying with the Spirit's guidance, and keeping ourselves in God's love. Applying ourselves to these disciplines assures us of our readiness for his return. Jesus is coming. Take the initiative. Build. Be ready.

fields.verse: Jude, a servant of Jesus Christ and a brother of James, To those who have been called, who are loved in God the Father and kept for Jesus Christ: - Jude 1:1 (NIV)
fields.content: The opening of a letter identifies its recipients. Jude makes clear who his audience is--the People of God: those who have been called out of darkness, loved as His prized possession, and kept until the coming of Jesus. In the centuries that have passed since the penning of this letter, the audience has not changed. The message is timeless and timely. It is prophetic, poignant, and personal. It has the clear ring of the Divine voice behind it. As you read the rest of this short letter, your spirit and soul will bear witness that God, through Jude, through time, speaks to us. Speak Lord; your servant is listening.

fields.verse: To him who is able to keep you from stumbling and to present you before his glorious presence without fault and with great joy— to the only God our Savior be glory, majesty, power and authority, through Jesus Christ our Lord, before all ages, now and forevermore! Amen. - Jude 1:24‭-‬25 (NIV)
fields.content: Let's begin the day with a benediction. A benediction is a statement of completion, a summary, a closing. It is meant to put a period on the end of a letter or meeting. It dismisses us from the present  to go forward to live out the directives gleaned from our time together. But a benediction is as much a statement of faith as it is a summary of fact. And so at the beginning of our day we commit ourselves to the hopes to which we aspire for end of our day, living for the "glory, majesty, power and authority, through Jesus Christ our Lord." So, go forward in peace to love and serve the Lord. At the end of the day, we'll see how we did.

fields.verse: Dear friends, although I was very eager to write to you about the salvation we share, I felt compelled to write and urge you to contend for the faith that was once for all entrusted to God’s holy people. - Jude 1:3‭ (NIV)
fields.content: There is a time to live contentedly in the faith, a time to defend the faith, and a time to fight for the faith. Jude understood the times when he undertook the writing of this short letter. It was time to urge the people of God to take the offensive against the enemies of God. We too are living in such a time. Attacks on Jesus, the Gospel, and the Christian way of life are increasingly common. False teachers of worldly philosophies, and heretics within the church are dividing God's people. It's time for true believers to put on the whole armor of God, wield the sword of the Word and take up a humble but confident offensive. The gates of hell must not, and shall not prevail. Jesus, lead on!

fields.verse: I have much to write you, but I do not want to do so with pen and ink. I hope to see you soon, and we will talk face to face... - 3 John 1:13‭-‬14a (NIV)
fields.content: There are few things that are more enjoyable than a face to face conversation with a dear family member or friend. Live and in person often includes hugs, kisses, and tears. Appropriate intervals of silence, tears and hearty laughs are also included. With all the developments of modern technology, we cherish any time and way we can spend together. We are grateful for emails, texting, and video calls, but sitting on a deck or porch, sipping on coffee or iced tea with a friend, is much more fulfilling. Yes, we stay in touch through contemporary mediums, but we yearn for our up close and personal times together. There is an ultimate reunion day on schedule. It will take place in the New Jerusalem. Our beloved family and friends will be there. We'll be fellowshipping around the table of the Lord, and God himself will be seated at the head. Look forward to it; there has never been, nor will there ever be, anything like it!

fields.verse: It gave me great joy when some believers came and testified about your faithfulness to the truth, telling how you continue to walk in it. I have no greater joy than to hear that my children are walking in the truth. - 3 John 1:3‭-‬4 (NIV)
fields.content: Ease of travel has made it possible for friends and family to scatter and relocate, literally all over the world. Whether it is on the other side of town, another state, or country, it is always nice to visit or get a visit from family or friends. When we meet we exchange news and views of what is happening in our respective circles. For believers, there are no sweeter words than to hear our friends and family are walking steadfast in their faith. It warms the heart and encourages the soul. Live in such a way that we will be good news news to others far away.

fields.verse: Dear children, keep yourselves from idols. - 1 John 5:21 (NIV)
fields.content: Rockstars, sports stars, actors, royalty, the rich and the famous, all attract our attention as we gaze upon them in awe and envy. Every industry, trade, and profession has it's own version of admirable people who are at the top of their game. No doubt there is a science lab where a pictorial calendar hangs of the 12 most handsome or beautiful accomplished scientists in the world. It seems we can't help but give an overly lofty level of importance to those and that which we idolize. An idol is anyone or anything that competes for and distracts us from the only One who is fully sufficient. In Him are no empty promises. He alone is worthy of our full allegiance and adoration. We need nothing else, because nothing can compare.

fields.verse: This is the confidence we have in approaching God: that if we ask anything according to his will, he hears us. And if we know that he hears us—whatever we ask—we know that we have what we asked of him. - 1 John 5:14‭-‬15 (NIV)
fields.content: Tacking on "according to your will" at the beginning, middle, or end of a prayer may sound humble and submissive, but it can also be a hedge to explain away an unanswered prayer or one answered opposite of what was prayed for. Before we petition God, take some time to discern his will by rightly interpreting scripture, remembering and rehearsing how he has answered prayer in the past. Diligence in doing so results in confidence and boldness in approaching God with our intercession, knowing he is eager to confirm his word and promises. Pray confidently.

fields.verse: This is how God showed his love among us: He sent his one and only Son into the world that we might live through him. This is love: not that we loved God, but that he loved us and sent his Son as an atoning sacrifice for our sins. Dear friends, since God so loved us, we also ought to love one another. - 1 John 4:9‭-‬11 (NIV)
fields.content: The standard of love has been set. If love was a scale, most of us would fall somewhere between Mother Theresa and Atila the Hun. When God became flesh and dwelt amongst us in order to rescue us from sin and death, he recalibrated the love meter. It is impossible for any of us to rank ourselves on a scale of that magnitude. However, we are encouraged to set God-like love as a goal and strive for it in practice. It is a worthy and worthwhile pursuit because every act of love brings us closer to God, while helping us appreciate his love all the more. We live in a time and world where manifestations of God's love are needed. Go out and love someone today.

fields.verse: Dear friends, now we are children of God, and what we will be has not yet been made known. But we know that when Christ appears, we shall be like him, for we shall see him as he is. All who have this hope in him purify themselves, just as he is pure. - 1 John 3:2‭-‬3 (NIV)
fields.content: When children are created in the womb, the Scriptures proclaims that they are "fearfully and wonderfully made." We don't know what they will ultimately look like, or what shape their lives will take, but when nurtured in love, they most often take on the best parts of the soul and personality of the parents. They are created, and then formed. When we are born again, the same process takes place. The God of everlasting love, nurtures and guides, provides and protects, and leads by principle and precept. We may not know now what our lives will look like later on down the road, but we have a pretty good idea. We will be like Him.

fields.verse: If we claim to be without sin, we deceive ourselves and the truth is not in us. If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just and will forgive us our sins and purify us from all unrighteousness. - 1 John 1:8‭-‬9 (NIV)
fields.content: We are created in the image of God and thus have a great deal of potential to do good and great things. But as a result of the Fall in the Garden of Eden, there is also a propensity passed onto us that derails us from reaching the fullness of our identity and call. We all have it. Let's call it what it is...sin. We can deny it, but its manifestation appears at the most inopportune time. We can deceive ourselves, but sooner or later, we must face it, and acknowledge it, if we are to walk in the greatness of His grace. Simple confession, humble repentance, and yielding to the leading and power of His Spirit, keeps us walking in purity. It works because God is faithful and just in forgiveness.

fields.verse: That which was from the beginning, which we have heard, which we have seen with our eyes, which we have looked at and our hands have touched—this we proclaim concerning the Word of life. - 1 John 1:1 (NIV)
fields.content: The message we have accepted has its origin in fact. It is the witness of that which was heard, seen, and touched. What is recorded by the writers of Scripture, is not a fanciful tale, philosophy or religion; it is the Story of redemption and reconciliation. In our most helpless condition, God took on flesh to defeat sin and death, and to offer us eternal and abundant life. We must stifle the temptation to share just a way of life. Instead we are to confidently proclaim Jesus as Savior, friend, and brother. It's about embracing our roles as sons, daughters, and siblings. It goes beyond just believing or living right; God, the Father, sent Jesus to reclaim his family. His coming is real. His promise is true.

fields.verse: Above all, you must understand that no prophecy of Scripture came about by the prophet’s own interpretation of things. For prophecy never had its origin in the human will, but prophets, though human, spoke from God as they were carried along by the Holy Spirit. - 2 Peter 1:20‭-‬21 (NIV)
fields.content: It is never the correct question to ask; "What does this Scripture mean to you?" The proper question is, "What does this Scripture mean? Our purpose in reading, studying, and interpreting Scripture is for determining what God says and means. Divine discernment beats personal interpretation every time. It is because He is infinite and we are finite that we must bring humility into the process of interpreting the Bible. There are some promises of God that will only be fulfilled when the fullness of the Kingdom is revealed, but for the most part, when we "claim" promises of God made in Scripture, and we don't experience their fulfillment in a reasonable amount of time, perhaps it is time to take a step back and do a do over. Our limited understanding should readily give way to his infinite wisdom. The Word of God is life. Let God speak.

fields.verse: His divine power has given us everything we need for a godly life through our knowledge of him who called us by his own glory and goodness...So I will always remind you of these things, even though you know them and are firmly established in the truth you now have. - 2 Peter 1:3, 12 (NIV)
fields.content: Reminders, we all need them-- some more than others, but we need them. It is easy to forget when we are inundated with tasks to do, places to go, and people to meet. We forget basic fundamentals so we try to come up with new solutions to issues, believing the problem to be unique. But God has supplied us with a well equipped tool shed to meet the challenges of life. There is no need for hand tools when we have the proper power tools. By His Word and the wisdom of His Spirit, we have what it takes to get the job done. Go back to the tool shed and look inside. Let me remind you, what you need is there.

fields.verse: Cast all your anxiety on him because he cares for you. - 1 Peter 5:7 (NIV)
fields.content: Anxiety is fear on steroids. It is an explosive mixture of one part facts, 2 parts feelings, and 3 parts imagination. The things that cause us anxiety rarely come to pass, and even when they do, are less often as bad as felt or imagined. We are not asked to deny facts, feelings, or even our imaginations; we are encouraged to take them, cast them, on the Lord. He will give us a measured, accurate response to the things that cause us to be anxious. Cast away! He cares.

fields.verse: Your beauty should not come from outward adornment, such as elaborate hairstyles and the wearing of gold jewelry or fine clothes. Rather, it should be that of your inner self, the unfading beauty of a gentle and quiet spirit, which is of great worth in God’s sight. - 1 Peter 3:3‭-‬4 (NIV)
fields.content: There was a time when the first part of this passage was directed solely to women; but oh how the times have changed! Unfortunately with the first part being overly emphasized, the second part was often lost in the shuffle. Our "inner self, the unfading beauty of a gentle and quiet spirit, which is of great worth in God’s sight" is the emphasis of this passage. As we work on that, our attractiveness grows exponentially. After all, under the pressure of life, what's inside will ultimately reveal who we truly are. Be beautiful.

fields.verse: For 'you were like sheep going astray,' but now you have returned to the Shepherd and Overseer of your souls. - 1 Peter 2:25 (NIV)
fields.content: When led to pasture, sheep don't race to a field at the first sight of fresh green grass; instead they lower their heads and slowly start grazing, concentrating on the sweetest morsels they can find while they slowly move along. So intense is their concentration, they lose track of where they are and can find themselves isolated from the flock and the shepherd. They bleat in confusion and fear. The shepherd follows their signs of distress and gently leads them back to the fold. Chances are, most of us did not plunge headlong into a lifestyle that widened our separation from God. Our concentration on the pursuit of happiness caused us to lose sight of that which is ultimately fulfilling. The gentle, merciful and gracious Shepherd, hears our despairing cry. He looks for us, finds us, and lovingly coaxes us back to join his flock. He knows our predisposition, and does it every time. Patient is he.

fields.verse: Therefore, rid yourselves of all malice and all deceit, hypocrisy, envy, and slander of every kind. Like newborn babies, crave pure spiritual milk, so that by it you may grow up in your salvation, now that you have tasted that the Lord is good. - 1 Peter 2:1‭-‬3 (NIV)
fields.content: This morning I thought I would let the Word of God speak for itself as I simply post this companion passage. Taste and see."I will extol the Lord at all times; his praise will always be on my lips. I will glory in the Lord; let the afflicted hear and rejoice. Glorify the Lord with me; let us exalt his name together. I sought the Lord, and he answered me; he delivered me from all my fears. Those who look to him are radiant; their faces are never covered with shame. This poor man called, and the Lord heard him; he saved him out of all his troubles. The angel of the Lord encamps around those who fear him, and he delivers them.  Taste and see that the Lord is good; blessed is the one who takes refuge in him. Fear the Lord, you his holy people, for those who fear him lack nothing. The lions may grow weak and hungry, but those who seek the Lord lack no good thing. Come, my children, listen to me; I will teach you the fear of the Lord. Whoever of you loves life and desires to see many good days, keep your tongue from evil and your lips from telling lies. Turn from evil and do good; seek peace and pursue it. The eyes of the Lord are on the righteous, and his ears are attentive to their cry;  but the face of the Lord is against those who do evil, to blot out their name from the earth. The righteous cry out, and the Lord hears them; he delivers them from all their troubles. The Lord is close to the brokenhearted and saves those who are crushed in spirit. The righteous person may have many troubles, but the Lord delivers him from them all; he protects all his bones, not one of them will be broken. Evil will slay the wicked; the foes of the righteous will be condemned.  The Lord will rescue his servants; no one who takes refuge in him will be condemned." - Psalms 34:1‭-‬22 (NIV)

fields.verse: When they hurled their insults at him, he did not retaliate; when he suffered, he made no threats. Instead, he entrusted himself to him who judges justly. - 1 Peter 2:23 (NIV)
fields.content: Living right is the best defense for being right. Most of us have suffered the indignity of being unjustly accused. A wrong word at the right time, or even a right word at the wrong time can cause unintended harm and result in our getting branded as being cruel, uncaring, or simply out of touch. But a consistent lifestyle of compassion and humility will shut down most opposition and will most often result in grace extended to us when we commit our infractions. Let our trust in God's mercy and justice come through loud and clear. After all, He is the one who's favor we desire. We strive to be perfect, but being consistent is the evidence of a life well lived.

fields.verse: But you are a chosen people, a royal priesthood, a holy nation, God’s special possession, that you may declare the praises of him who called you out of darkness into his wonderful light. Once you were not a people, but now you are the people of God; once you had not received mercy, but now you have received mercy. - 1 Peter 2:9‭-‬10 (NIV)
fields.content: As recipients of God's mercy, we are a chosen people. We are now adopted sons and daughters who can claim royal lineage. When we look into a mirror, we see a transformation from pauper to prince, from wedding attendant to Bride. We have been given a new purpose and a destiny; we have been enlisted to be world changers and shapers. Whatever we do and say, wherever we go, is for the glory and praise of the King, until the knowledge of his kingdom will be known to the ends of the earth.

fields.verse: For, “All people are like grass, and all their glory is like the flowers of the field; the grass withers and the flowers fall,  but the word of the Lord endures forever.” And this is the word that was preached to you. - 1 Peter 1:24‭-‬25 (NIV)
fields.content: The leaves are starting to turn color, and the grass is growing slower. All of nature is beginning its slow-down and some things will stop altogether. Sunny days will be rare and a ghostly gray pallor will be cast over the landscape. Our hemisphere is preparing for the suspended animation of winter. During this time it is not unusual for our spirits to be subdued and suppressed as well. All seems a bit dismal and fruitless... except that God has given us his Word. Wait patiently for a few months. Endure the shorter days and longer nights. Brave the cold temperatures and the seasonal challenges. Spring will return with the sun shining, birds chirping, the grass growing, and flowers blooming. God has spoken; life will prevail.

fields.verse: Though you have not seen him, you love him; and even though you do not see him now, you believe in him and are filled with an inexpressible and glorious joy, for you are receiving the end result of your faith, the salvation of your souls. - 1 Peter 1:8‭-‬9 (NIV)
fields.content: We have been given a promise of redemption. A promise is the down payment for a gift we will receive at a later date. It is the source of our anticipation, as we wait for its delivery. Peace, joy, and contentment are the characteristics of a faith engaged, which is often difficult to explain. But know this; the one who made the promise is the same one who will deliver, and he himself will be the gift.

fields.verse: Now listen, you who say, “Today or tomorrow we will go to this or that city, spend a year there, carry on business and make money.” Why, you do not even know what will happen tomorrow. What is your life? You are a mist that appears for a little while and then vanishes. Instead, you ought to say, “If it is the Lord’s will, we will live and do this or that.” - James 4:13‭-‬15 (NIV)
fields.content: Life is unpredictable. Life is fragile. Our best laid plans can easily end up in the scrap heap when a situation we didn't foresee forces its way into our lives. Life is too short to waste a lot of time floundering. Any plan must be drawn up with potential adjustments for the unseen. It's a good thing to have a plan, but James' admonishes us against making plans without consulting God. A plan without God's input is presumptuous and likely to fail. God knows every twist and turn in our lives. Let's give Him the first and last word in our planning.

fields.verse: Submit yourselves, then, to God. Resist the devil, and he will flee from you. Come near to God and he will come near to you. Wash your hands, you sinners, and purify your hearts, you double-minded. Grieve, mourn and wail. Change your laughter to mourning and your joy to gloom. Humble yourselves before the Lord, and he will lift you up. - James 4:7‭-‬10 (NIV)
fields.content: Sometimes, in between "submit yourselves" and "humble yourselves" is a lot of "resisting, coming near, washing, purifying, grieving, mourning, wailing, and changing." In the end, if we undertake the challenge, we experience the sweet joy of surrender. The way up, is down. God desires to lift you up.

fields.verse: ...You do not have because you do not ask God. When you ask, you do not receive, because you ask with wrong motives, that you may spend what you get on your pleasures. -James 4:2‭b, 3 (NIV)
fields.content: Our motives play an integral part in the answer to our prayers. We must not mistake our wants as needs. God directs his most vigorous response to those prayers that address the needs of others. When we examine our motives by taking inventory of how God has already richly blessed us, the focus of prayer becomes clearer. It's time to pray elsewhere. The longest distance we travel can often be the road from ourselves to others. Make the journey. Jesus, lead on.

fields.verse: Peacemakers who sow in peace reap a harvest of righteousness. - James 3:18 (NIV)
fields.content: The difference between a peacemaker and a peace faker is the end result of their efforts. When settling a dispute, look for the good, right answer. Don't compromise by going along to get along. It's ok for one to be right over another. Prayerfully discern the process to follow that will bring about lasting, righteous peace. Everyone wins when that happens.

fields.verse: When tempted, no one should say, “God is tempting me.” For God cannot be tempted by evil, nor does he tempt anyone; but each person is tempted when they are dragged away by their own evil desire and enticed. Then, after desire has conceived, it gives birth to sin; and sin, when it is full-grown, gives birth to death. - James 1:13‭-‬15 (NIV)
fields.content: We are all born with a desire to taste forbidden fruit. It was birthed through a temptation coming from a serpent in a lush garden. It was passed onto us from our first parents, and persists in every generation to this day. Temptation is the Enemy's way to coax a continual harvest of thoughts and actions that keeps us alienated from God. Acknowledging that desire for forbidden fruit is inherent within us, is the initial prompt in thwarting the purpose of the Tempter. It is the first step to appropriating the promise of God that he would give us the opportunity to defeat the temptation, or provide a way for us to avoid it. The victory can be ours. Choose to win.

fields.verse: Remember your leaders, who spoke the word of God to you. Consider the outcome of their way of life and imitate their faith. Jesus Christ is the same yesterday and today and forever...Have confidence in your leaders and submit to their authority, because they keep watch over you as those who must give an account. Do this so that their work will be a joy, not a burden, for that would be of no benefit to you. - Hebrews 13:7‭-‬8‭, ‬17 (NIV)
fields.content: Follow your leaders. Keep your eyes wide open! Give heed to the teachings of your mentors; they are characterized by truth, and an outcome in their lives that matches. We are under no obligation to follow blindly, but can honor our teachers by our submission to the word of life they speak. Make their lives a joy to serve you, while you reap the benefits of their work.Trust, but verify is the order of the day. Once verified, humbly obey.

"Keep your lives free from the love of money and be content with what you have, because God has said, 'Never will I leave you; never will I forsake you.'” - Hebrews 13:5 (NIV)Money talks, but what does it say? Money can't buy happiness, but it can buy you a Jet-Ski! It's been said; "The best things in life are free." That's usually said by people who don't have much; and there is much that can be said about that. When properly earned, spent, invested, or shared, it can be a blessing indeed. But when acquiring it becomes an obsession, money can distract from the things in life that really matter. Money is a gateway to many things -- good and bad. If contentment is your goal, money offers you a spotty record of coming through. On the other hand, God's grace is offered richly and freely...and it delivers contentment that money can't buy.

fields.verse: No discipline seems pleasant at the time, but painful. Later on, however, it produces a harvest of righteousness and peace for those who have been trained by it. - Hebrews 12:11 (NIV)
fields.content: A good father knows that discipline is more often for correction rather than for punishment. When we do something that displeases our Father, the punishment is most often the natural consequence of the infraction. We don't desire insult to be added to injury. The correction comes into play to instruct, steer, extrapolate wisdom, and build a life of discernment and wisdom. There is no benefit in learning the hard way, but the father doesn't abandon us during the difficult time of our failures. Listen and learn. A good Father will teach you the easy way, or the hard way. It's most often your choice.

fields.verse: Therefore, since we are surrounded by such a great cloud of witnesses, let us throw off everything that hinders and the sin that so easily entangles. And let us run with perseverance the race marked out for us, fixing our eyes on Jesus, the pioneer and perfecter of faith. For the joy set before him he endured the cross, scorning its shame, and sat down at the right hand of the throne of God. Consider him who endured such opposition from sinners, so that you will not grow weary and lose heart. - Hebrews 12:1‭-‬3 (NIV)
fields.content: Picture a man (or woman) running a marathon. Our first thought may be centered on how that person got there to begin with. We marvel at the amount of training and discipline that it took. The starting horn sounds and the trek begins. 26.2 miles loom before our runner. He begins with the bulk of the pack. At that point, everyone is in first place. Eventually the runners break off into groups led on by the cheers of the onlookers on the sidelines. The herd begins to thin, there is greater distance between runners, and eventually he finds himself running alone. The crowds begin to evaporate as more and more friends of the other runners have left. He realizes there is no one behind him, and he can't see anyone in front of him. He comes to the realization that he is in last place. Yet, he plods on. Long after the race has been decided and the winners confirmed, our runner appears in the distance. The finish line is within sight. His most loyal supporters are waiting, cheering, as he finally crosses the finish line. There is a painful smile on his face. He finished. He knew he wasn't going to win the race, or even compete with some of the elite runners. His aim was to finish. He endured the training, the struggles, and loneliness, in anticipation of crossing that line. Let us fix our eyes on Jesus. He is the prize. Run to finish, for Joy awaits.

"For he was looking forward to the city with foundations, whose architect and builder is God." - Hebrews 11:10 (NIV)Abraham walked when and where God told him to walk. He didn't know his final destination but had faith God would show him where it was. In his heart Abraham pictured a place God Himself would build.What kind of place would God design and build? It is a place where everything we consider to gather as wealth (gold and precious stones) are used as common, everyday building materials. Streets of gold and gates of pearls aren't worth considering much when the pure adoration at our destination is reserved for the glorious King who dwells there. We are going to the house he built, to dine and fellowship. His sons and daughters will be welcomed home. Keep walking. We are closer than we think.

fields.verse: By faith Abraham, when called to go to a place he would later receive as his inheritance, obeyed and went, even though he did not know where he was going. - Hebrews 11:8 (NIV)
fields.content: The conversation went something like this...God: "Abraham, start walking."  Abraham: "Where to Lord?"  God: "I'll let you know when you get there."So Abraham started walking. Sometimes we don't know where God is leading us. Perhaps if we knew, we'd be hesitant to go, or ask him to send someone else. But we recognize his voice, point our nose in the direction we sense his calling, and start walking. Along the way we may question our choice, but are compelled to keep moving.  No matter the harshness of the desert, the danger of robbers and thieves, the fear of the wild animals and the sounds of gnashing teeth in the dark, and the nagging doubt and fear that we've made the wrong decision, we walk. One day we climb up on a ridge overlooking a lush valley that extends as far as the eye can see. And then we know. The trip was worth it. Jesus, lead on!

fields.verse: Now faith is confidence in what we hope for and assurance about what we do not see. This is what the ancients were commended for. By faith we understand that the universe was formed at God’s command, so that what is seen was not made out of what was visible. - Hebrews 11:1‭-‬3 (NIV)
fields.content: Faith cannot be manufactured by facts. We can believe without facts, or choose unbelief even when we are surrounded by facts. Faith is an inner soul acknowledgment that there is more than meets the eye.  Faith is ultimately a response of our spirits to the something believable beyond the senses. Faith is the glue that holds the facts together. God has given us adequate confirmation that He exists. We place our hope in One we cannot see.

fields.verse: But we do not belong to those who shrink back and are destroyed, but to those who have faith and are saved. - Hebrews 10:39 (NIV)
fields.content: Because of Jesus' work on the Cross, the burden has fallen off our backs. He has released us from the slavery of sin's chains. Our past is in the rearview mirror and gets smaller with every day lived by obedience in faith. We have the joy of today and the hope of future eternity. There is no turning back--no surrender. We move forward and onward with confidence and resolve. Jesus, lead on!

fields.verse: Let us hold unswervingly to the hope we profess, for he who promised is faithful. And let us consider how we may spur one another on toward love and good deeds, not giving up meeting together, as some are in the habit of doing, but encouraging one another—and all the more as you see the Day approaching. - Hebrews 10:23‭-‬25 (NIV)
fields.content: There is confidence in being adequately prepared. Confidence means that, whatever loose ends may remain, there is enough faith and evidence to overcome our reluctance and fear. The People of God have been hearing of Jesus' Second Coming for over 2,000 years. It is enough to tax the patience of anyone who believes it. But we can trace the history and experiences of God's people throughout the centuries and see the handprint of God in his sustenance and preservation of the faithful. Hold steady!  Faithful is He who said it, who will also do it.

fields.verse: Nothing in all creation is hidden from God’s sight. Everything is uncovered and laid bare before the eyes of him to whom we must give account. - Hebrews 4:13 (NIV)
fields.content: You're not paranoid. Someone is indeed watching us. He sees our coming in and our going out. He has a record of our deeds and our shortcomings. He knows our every thought, and the motives behind them. He has good intentions for us. The Sculptor takes a slab of granite with a picture in his mind of what the finished piece of art will look like. He sees in us the image of His Son. He chips away everything until the work is done. It will look like what he imagined. It is that for which we will give an account. Chip away, Lord.

fields.verse: For the word of God is alive and active. Sharper than any double-edged sword, it penetrates even to dividing soul and spirit, joints and marrow; it judges the thoughts and attitudes of the heart. - Hebrews 4:12 (NIV)
fields.content: The word of God is living and active in that it is endued with the same Spirit that raised Christ from the dead. Left alone to marks on paper, the gift of scripture becomes mere  legalism arbitrating our actions in black and white, right and wrong. But God's Spirit reveals intention and attitudes. He adds dimension to our actions. He can salvage our failures by revealing our hearts were in the right place. He can bring subtle conviction when our actions are betrayed by our attitude. God's Spirit makes life a joy as He helps us understand God's word in the dynamic tension of kingdom living while we are inhabitants of this world.

fields.verse: ...how shall we escape if we ignore so great a salvation? This salvation, which was first announced by the Lord, was confirmed to us by those who heard him. God also testified to it by signs, wonders and various miracles, and by gifts of the Holy Spirit distributed according to his will. - Hebrews 2:3‭-‬4 (NIV)
fields.content: "The kingdom of God is at hand!" This is the message Jesus proclaimed. He sent his disciples to take it to the ends of the earth. It was a message beyond mere words competing among a myriad of philosophies of the day; it also included the confirming testimony of eye witnesses to the truth. But one element made the Jesus message stand out among the rest. It came with demonstrations of Divine power; signs, wonders, miracles, and gifts of the Spirit, that even circumvented nature. We cannot win the world through fine tuned arguments and explanations alone. We need an intervention of genuine God power. Pray that God would confirm His message and messengers with signs that follow. That'll get their attention!

fields.verse: We must pay the most careful attention, therefore, to what we have heard, so that we do not drift away. - Hebrews 2:1 (NIV)
fields.content: It doesn't take much to steer a ship off its course. The tiniest move of the rudder can keep it going to its destination, or veer it miles from its intended port. Careful attention must be paid, and countless adjustments must be made, if the ship is to make it to it's final goal. On our journey to our permanent home, we may grow weary of the neverending diligence. We may grow frustrated of fighting the winds, waves, and currents. We may experience fear as we venture out to the deep water and lose sight of the shore. But remain focused. Don't lose heart. Stay the course. You may think you're steering, but Jesus is the Captain of the boat.

fields.verse: Because he himself suffered when he was tempted, he is able to help those who are being tempted. - Hebrews 2:18 (NIV)
fields.content: "I know how you feel." In an attempt to make an empathic connection, we may find ourselves uttering these words. Most of the time we only know how someone feels in a general way. Our distinctive perspective, experience, and circumstance makes the situation unique. In our need, we cry out for an individualized, personal connection. We want someone who has firsthand knowledge of our specific predicament. Go down the list. Who has embraced the world in all its pain: the sorrow, loneliness, rejection, and separation, the spiritual agony of being abandoned and judged, the physical pain that comes from torture, the unjustified scorn, accusations, and humiliation? He was not deserving of any of it, yet yielded himself to all of it, in order to relate to those who needed the solace and comfort he came to provide. Jesus knows. Jesus cares. Jesus can relate. He knows how you feel.

fields.verse: He also says, “In the beginning, Lord, you laid the foundations of the earth, and the heavens are the work of your hands.  They will perish, but you remain; they will all wear out like a garment.  You will roll them up like a robe; like a garment they will be changed. But you remain the same, and your years will never end.” - Hebrews 1:10‭-‬12 (NIV)
fields.content: History has a timeline, a beginning and an end; eternity has an arrow pointing in both directions, into the past and the future. Eternity is infinite and cannot be fully understood by the finite mind. Yet God knew us before we were inserted into history, and he has prepared a place for us in eternity through his Son. Our place in history is destined to end. The beams of the Cross are at the intersection of history and eternity. When the pages of our history are turned, He will still remain. He invites us through his Son to continue with him in the next chapter of eternity.

fields.verse: In the past God spoke to our ancestors through the prophets at many times and in various ways, but in these last days he has spoken to us by his Son, whom he appointed heir of all things, and through whom also he made the universe. - Hebrews 1:1‭-‬2 (NIV)
fields.content: There is a golden thread woven into the fabric of redemptive history. From the first moment of Creation, God made a world of people who would have to look outside themselves to give meaning to their existence. Life only makes sense when we look at it through the Divine lens. Families and clans passed their knowledge of Him through stories and traditions. Prophets, priests, and kings revealed His person and plan in their proclamations, liturgies, failures and successes, in leading the people. One day, God stepped down from heaven to dwell amongst us. He revealed himself to us in perfect, humble humanity. The thin thread that adorns the fabric and holds it all together, is Jesus. Watch him. Follow him. Listen and learn. Jesus, lead on!

fields.verse: For the time will come when people will not put up with sound doctrine. Instead, to suit their own desires, they will gather around them a great number of teachers to say what their itching ears want to hear. They will turn their ears away from the truth and turn aside to myths. - 2 Timothy 4:3‭-‬4 (NIV)
fields.content: There is an abundance of teaching but a shortage of truth. Couple that with the tendency to surround ourselves with people we agree with, and it becomes a dangerous combination. Building a house on the shifting sands of desires and whims will certainly guarantee a house will collapse. Being affirmed in folly is no virtue. Being challenged to build line upon line and precept upon precept ensures that our house is built on a solid foundation that can withstand unpredictable winds. Build carefully. Assess your teachers, their teaching, and the times. Most importantly, desire and seek Truth. For a time is coming, and now is...

fields.verse: All Scripture is God-breathed and is useful for teaching, rebuking, correcting and training in righteousness, so that the servant of God may be thoroughly equipped for every good work. - 2 Timothy 3:16‭-‬17 (NIV)
fields.content: First and foremost, become proficient in the understanding of the Scriptures. They are the why to what we do and who we are. They are the lens through which we focus our lives and the world we live in. The divinely inspired principles and precepts found therein, can shape us into the kind of people we need to be. No one can consider themselves sufficiently educated without a working understanding of scripture. Regardless of your chosen profession, let God breathe life into it through the Scriptures.

fields.verse: But mark this: There will be terrible times in the last days. People will be lovers of themselves, lovers of money, boastful, proud, abusive, disobedient to their parents, ungrateful, unholy, without love, unforgiving, slanderous, without self-control, brutal, not lovers of the good, treacherous, rash, conceited, lovers of pleasure rather than lovers of God— having a form of godliness but denying its power. Have nothing to do with such people. - 2 Timothy 3:1‭-‬5 (NIV)
fields.content: Perhaps it is time to take a step back. Whether it's a child, spouse, neighbor, or co-worker, sometimes there is a point of diminishing returns in a relationship, or the point of no return at all! It may seem contrary to the gospel to give up on someone, but we are not giving up on them; we are giving them up -- turning them over and prayerfully asking God to bring someone in their lives who can make a difference. God can handle even the toughest cases. If you've hit a wall, it may be God speaking. He may have another plan, and it's ok if it doesn't include you.

fields.verse: Reflect on what I am saying, for the Lord will give you insight into all this. - 2 Timothy 2:7 (NIV)
fields.content: God desires to be make himself known. He has appointed teachers to assist in the process.The best teachers encourage their students to seek independent confirmation. The Bereans of the Bible were lauded for their diligence in searching the Scriptures to affirm what they were being taught. The searching and reflecting for the Spirit's insight is not to find what is wrong with a teaching, but to find whether the teaching is true. Trust your teachers, but verify.

fields.verse: And the Lord’s servant must not be quarrelsome but must be kind to everyone, able to teach, not resentful. Opponents must be gently instructed, in the hope that God will grant them repentance leading them to a knowledge of the truth - 2 Timothy 2:24‭-‬25 (NIV)
fields.content: It is tempting to try to shout down our opposition. Those who are entrusted with the privilege of knowing the truth must be careful to avoid being smug, dismissive, and contentious. Instead we are to cloak ourselves with humility, patience, and gentleness. Tearing apart an argument can result in tearing down a person. Being right is not the goal. Remember, we have been called to make disciples, not win arguments.

fields.verse: ...Yet this is no cause for shame, because I know whom I have believed, and am convinced that he is able to guard what I have entrusted to him until that day. - 2 Timothy 1:12 (NIV)
fields.content: We may be shunned, ridiculed, and falsely accused. Throughout history, and even in the present, fellow believers have been persecuted, jailed and put to death, because of their identification with the risen Christ. The Apostle Paul reminded Timothy and us of this certainty; faithfulness to the Savior may be hazardous to our health.The secret of survival is to know Who you believe, to be persuaded in His ability: to get you on the road, walk with you on the road, and be with you when you reach the end of the road -- and beyond. Entrust yourself to Him. He is able

fields.verse: Here is a trustworthy saying that deserves full acceptance: Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners—of whom I am the worst. But for that very reason I was shown mercy so that in me, the worst of sinners, Christ Jesus might display his immense patience as an example for those who would believe in him and receive eternal life. - 1 Timothy 1:15‭-‬16 (NIV)
fields.content: "Mission creep" is a term used to describe when an individual or organization adds on, or veers from, the original and prime reason for what that individual or organization was founded for.Mission creep often stems from good intentions, for example when an urgent need arises that takes priority over the stated and understood message. Mission creep is subtle and often leads to more mission creep. The most successful people stay focused on only those tasks that are mission essential.Paul reminds Timothy that, "Christ came into the world to save sinners..." That is our mission. Anything and everything that is done in service to Jesus must confirm to that purpose. Even the WORKS of the gospel must serve the WORK of the gospel. Stay true.

fields.verse: But the Lord is faithful, and he will strengthen you and protect you from the evil one. - 2 Thessalonians 3:3 (NIV)
fields.content: Living in peace, on this side of the Great Divide, is the exception rather than the rule. We live in a broken world, and all around us, people are scratching and clawing trying to get by or ahead. Where there is a kingdom presence it is less so, but trials, temptations, and even persecution, is plentiful. It was like that in first century Thessalonica and becoming increasingly the norm in 21st century America. God offers strength and protection. History amply reveals that the people of God are resilient and ultimately victorious in every generation. Hold on! Fight through! God will again prove to be faithful.

fields.verse: :...make it your ambition to lead a quiet life: You should mind your own business and work with your hands, just as we told you, so that your daily life may win the respect of outsiders and so that you will not be dependent on anybody. - 1 Thessalonians 4:11‭-‬12 (NIV)
fields.content: There's an awful lot of noise surrounding us. With a 24 hour news cycle, the presence of the internet, social media, TED talks, email, text messages, etc., it is difficult to steal away quiet moments for reflection, prayer, or just enjoying life. Sometimes it's difficult to find help or empathy because everyone seems so busy and we don't want to be a bother. Christians can be an island of peace, a calming influence during stormy weather; the quiet dock where boats can moor. Be that person. Simplify your life.

fields.verse: As for other matters, brothers and sisters, we instructed you how to live in order to please God, as in fact you are living. Now we ask you and urge you in the Lord Jesus to do this more and more. - 1 Thessalonians 4:1 (NIV)
fields.content: The teachings of our mentors go beyond the exchange of information. Their instruction is designed to foster a life that pleases the Lord. When we are helped to understand a principle of kingdom living, mentors encourage us to put it into practice. The principles are the building blocks for dynamic growth. They are more than just another item in our development to be checked; they become a catalyst to inspire us to other things - deepening our walk and relationship with the Life giver. Good mentors stir up within us a holy dissatisfaction spurring us on to be more.

fields.verse: Let the message of Christ dwell among you richly as you teach and admonish one another with all wisdom through psalms, hymns, and songs from the Spirit, singing to God with gratitude in your hearts. - Colossians 3:16 (NIV)
fields.content: From Gregorian chants to modern contemporary Christian music, we've all got our favorites. In addition to a book of 150 psalms, songs are interspersed throughout the Bible. Songs are instructional and inspirational; they encourage, admonish, sooth, and heal. Whether in groups or alone - Loosen the vocal chords! Raise your voice and sing!  Make a joyful noise to the Lord! Whatever the circumstances or emotions, there's a song for that.

fields.verse: When you were dead in your sins and in the uncircumcision of your flesh, God made you alive with Christ. He forgave us all our sins, having canceled the charge of our legal indebtedness, which stood against us and condemned us; he has taken it away, nailing it to the cross. And having disarmed the powers and authorities, he made a public spectacle of them, triumphing over them by the cross. - Colossians 2:13‭-‬15 (NIV)
fields.content: Picture in your mind, a procession of the personification of everything that is wrong with the world, marching on the main street of downtown. Pride, greed, murder, famine, calamity, theft, lust, anger, bitterness, and a seemingly endless stream of its foot soldiers are marching in lockstep, saluting and being reviewed, by the chief architect of destruction.Now picture that same horde in chains and shackles being paraded in shame before the resurrected King Jesus. This is the power of the Cross. Yes, the battle is over and the victory is complete

fields.verse: I can do all this through him who gives me strength. - Philippians 4:13‭
fields.content: Some treat this passage as if it means believers are endowed with some superpower for performing Herculean feats. Others approach it as a magical incantation that when chanted reduces everything to a manageable size. But the context reveals the true power of what Paul is conveying. Whether in need or in plenty, good times or bad, Christ provides us with the contentment of knowing He is right there with us. We are never alone; he is there providing, sustaining, equipping, encouraging, reminding us, that we can do it.

fields.verse: But our citizenship is in heaven. And we eagerly await a Savior from there, the Lord Jesus Christ, who, by the power that enables him to bring everything under his control, will transform our lowly bodies so that they will be like his glorious body. - Philippians 3:20‭-‬21 (NIV)
fields.content: "Life is tough, and then we die." Whoever said that, was probably having a tough day. The Bible depicts for us a different scenario. Believers are promised abundant life here, and eternal abundant life in the hereafter. It's all made possible by the One who took away the sting of sin and death and adopted us into his family. We are now living as citizens of a different land under the lordship of an omnipotent King. Life is good, and it will only get better.

fields.verse: Not that I have already obtained all this, or have already arrived at my goal, but I press on to take hold of that for which Christ Jesus took hold of me. Brothers and sisters, I do not consider myself yet to have taken hold of it. But one thing I do: Forgetting what is behind and straining toward what is ahead, I press on toward the goal to win the prize for which God has called me heavenward in Christ Jesus. - Philippians 3:12‭-‬14 (NIV)
fields.content: We can't control the length of the course or the pace of the race. There will be twists and turns as well as hills and valleys. Along the way our mettle and resolve will be tested. We will rely on friends and even strangers when we get hungry and thirsty. We will get winded and weary; at times we will want to quit. One thing will help us finish; putting each step taken behind us, and taking one step at a time toward the goal. The crown at the end of the race keeps us going. The joy of knowing we have endured brings deep satisfaction. Celebrating with our proud Trainer and friends makes the race worth it. You can finish the race. You will get the prize. Press on!

fields.verse: Join together in following my example, brothers and sisters, and just as you have us as a model, keep your eyes on those who live as we do. - Philippians 3:17 (NIV)
fields.content: Being a role model carries a lot of responsibility. Good leaders remind their followers that a goal is obtainable and roadblocks can be traversed. Leading by example is the best way to maintain hope and enthusiasm as others look to us. Spreading the credit to others who are being successful convinces others that they too can succeed. Following Christ victoriously is possible. Look to others who are following well and follow them as they follow Christ. In doing so eventually you will have followers who will look to do the same.

fields.verse: What is more, I consider everything a loss because of the surpassing worth of knowing Christ Jesus my Lord, for whose sake I have lost all things. I consider them garbage, that I may gain Christ - Philippians 3:8 (NIV)
fields.content: That which is inherent in human nature, that we believe will affirm and define our value, is fleeting at best. It's not the new fancy sneakers, the arm candy we enter a room with, the house in the right part of town, exotic vacations, or expensive toys that shout to the world "We've arrived!" Rather it is knowing Christ Jesus as Lord that really matters. As we plod along on this ancient sod, "the things of earth will go strangely dim in the light of his glory and grace." All else pales in comparison.

fields.verse: And this is my prayer: that your love may abound more and more in knowledge and depth of insight, so that you may be able to discern what is best and may be pure and blameless for the day of Christ, filled with the fruit of righteousness that comes through Jesus Christ—to the glory and praise of God. - Philippians 1:9‭-‬11 (NIV)
fields.content: The apostle's prayer is loaded and deep. His is not a generic prayer for his friends. He petitions God for: abounding love, knowledge and depth of insight, purity and blamelessness, and the fruit that accompanies righteousness. He knows that it will hugely benefit his friends, but also results in glory and praise of God. Lord, teach us to pray with substance.

fields.verse: Pray also for me, that whenever I speak, words may be given me so that I will fearlessly make known the mystery of the gospel, for which I am an ambassador in chains. Pray that I may declare it fearlessly, as I should. - Ephesians 6:19‭-‬20 (NIV)
fields.content: This was a passage I would read often on Saturday evening as I put the finishing touches on my sermon for Sunday morning. Preaching and teaching is not just an exercise in the transferring of information; they are instruments by which the Spirit of God reveals the mysteries of the Gospel. Preachers and teachers are not looking for a mere nod in agreement, we earnestly desire a gripping of the heart which changes outlook and behavior. That is why we humbly pray and ask others to join us. Sunday is coming. Pray for your pastor. Eternity hangs in the balance.

fields.verse: Finally, be strong in the Lord and in his mighty power. Put on the full armor of God, so that you can take your stand against the devil’s schemes. - Ephesians 6:10‭-‬11 (NIV)
fields.content: "Finally." After a series of teachings, commands, warnings, and encouragements, the Apostle reminds us that what came previously can only be accomplished through spiritual warfare. It is by being strong in the Lord, trusting in His power, and putting on the full armor of God, that we can defeat the Enemy who is trying to destroy us. Being a believer is no cakewalk. At times it takes intense fighting. Don't ever forget; God is fighting with us and for us. He has equipped us with all the weapons and armor to guarantee victory. Go out and fight. Go out and win!

fields.verse: Have nothing to do with the fruitless deeds of darkness, but rather expose them. It is shameful even to mention what the disobedient do in secret. But everything exposed by the light becomes visible—and everything that is illuminated becomes a light. - Ephesians 5:11‭-‬13 (NIV)
fields.content: Mark Twain said, "Man is the only animal that blushes. Or needs to." The sins that are  committed under cover of darkness are many. Most believers agree these acts should be avoided. But we must go one step farther. Darkness must be dispelled and denounced. In the face of injustice, and iniquity, believers must be engaged in calling out sin. The antidote to darkness is light. Light exposes the sins done in darkness and gives them no place to hide. We are surrounded by much darkness. We are called to be light. Be humble, but be light.

fields.verse: For you were once darkness, but now you are light in the Lord. Live as children of light (for the fruit of the light consists in all goodness, righteousness and truth) and find out what pleases the Lord. - Ephesians 5:8‭-‬10 (NIV)
fields.content: Different motivations lead to different pursuits. When we were living outside of a relationship with the living God, our prime aim was to seek that which gave us happiness, fulfillment, and wholeness. These desires are in themselves worthy goals, but they fall short in our understanding of God's plan for our lives. Finding our place in God's order as redeemed children of God, our motivations are supposed to change. Our charge now is to "find out what pleases the Lord." It is him that we live, move, and have our being. Walk in the Light.

fields.verse: So I tell you this, and insist on it in the Lord, that you must no longer live as the Gentiles do, in the futility of their thinking. They are darkened in their understanding and separated from the life of God because of the ignorance that is in them due to the hardening of their hearts. - Ephesians 4:17‭-‬18 (NIV)
fields.content: Hardening of the heart is not a condition that affects only unbelievers; if it was there would be no need to warn believers against it. Hardening of the heart can manifest itself as stubbornness and rebellion, or reveal itself as passivity or carelessness in pursuit of the presence of God. Resist futile speculative thinking which can darken our understanding. Our hearts must remain soft, warm, and gentle. This is best accomplished by focusing our minds and hearts on the mysteries of God revealed in his awesome plan to save His creation.

"He came and preached peace to you who were far away and peace to those who were near. For through him we both have access to the Father by one Spirit." - Ephesians 2:17‭-‬18 (NIV)Some people are so nice and kind they don't seem in need of redemption. Others are so far gone it is difficult, if not impossible, for us to see how they can be saved. Whether near or far, the message is the same; we all fall short and are in need of the grace of God offered freely to all by the death, burial, and resurrection of His Son, Jesus Christ. Reach out to those who are far separated from God; but don't forget to pray for your good friends who are just as much in need of salvation.

fields.verse: Let us not become weary in doing good, for at the proper time we will reap a harvest if we do not give up. - Galatians 6:9 (NIV)
fields.content: There are times when we may wish God turned his back for a moment while we "took care of business" in front of us. An unruly teenager, an ambivalent customer service rep, or an irresponsible neighbor can bring that out in us. The situation needs to be fixed, and it has to happen now! Let us not mistake our impulses for the righteousness of God. He is on a timetable and will exercise his righteousness in due time. Let's not grow weary in our waiting. Perhaps he is working on developing the virtue of patience in our lives. Patience takes time.

fields.verse: Are you so foolish? After beginning by means of the Spirit, are you now trying to finish by means of the flesh? - Galatians 3:3 (NIV)
fields.content: Salvation is a work begun with the Spirit and sustained by the Spirit. We are saved by faith. It is not works that lead to faith, faith and works, or even faith that results in works. We are saved by faith THAT works. The Spirit stirs up faith, activates faith, and affirms faith. Nothing can, or needs to be added to it. Acknowledge and accept the free gift. Live by faith, live in faith. It suffices. It is enough.

fields.verse: If I must boast, I will boast of the things that show my weakness. - 2 Corinthians 11:30 (NIV)
fields.content: The Apostle Paul had the quintessential resumé. It would be difficult to find a better candidate to lead the cause of reaching the Gentiles. But Paul knew he needed something more than giftedness, skills, and training. Only God can bring about the conversion of a soul. In our strength, God can be hidden. In our weakness, He is revealed. Humility is simply recognizing that we need God. Count yourself among the needy.

"But I am afraid that just as Eve was deceived by the serpent’s cunning, your minds may somehow be led astray from your sincere and pure devotion to Christ. For if someone comes to you and preaches a Jesus other than the Jesus we preached, or if you receive a different spirit from the Spirit you received, or a different gospel from the one you accepted, you put up with it easily enough." - 2 Corinthians 11:3‭-‬4 (NIV)We are all vulnerable to serve a god of our own choosing, a god who checks all our boxes. The kicker is when a circumstance comes up when the god we have chosen to believe in ceases to work. Do we double down and try to pound our square god into a round hole, or do we allow the circumstance to challenge and refine the way we think about the one true God? False gods undermine the sincerity and purity of devotion to the God who is. Stay on course with the apostolic witness. All other roads lead to a dead end.

fields.verse: Now finish the work, so that your eager willingness to do it may be matched by your completion of it, according to your means. For if the willingness is there, the gift is acceptable according to what one has, not according to what one does not have. - 2 Corinthians 8:11‭-‬12 (NIV)
fields.content: The Corinthians were commended for their zeal in addressing a need, but Paul encouraged them to take their zeal across the finish line. Zeal gets us started. It takes faith and perseverance to be successful. Our intentions must be matched by our efforts. Remember, we are asked to do only what God knows we can do. Press ahead. Finish the task.

fields.verse: And now, brothers and sisters, we want you to know about the grace that God has given the Macedonian churches. In the midst of a very severe trial, their overflowing joy and their extreme poverty welled up in rich generosity. For I testify that they gave as much as they were able, and even beyond their ability. Entirely on their own, they urgently pleaded with us for the privilege of sharing in this service to the Lord’s people. And they exceeded our expectations: They gave themselves first of all to the Lord, and then by the will of God also to us. - 2 Corinthians 8:1‭-‬5 (NIV)
fields.content: Some of the most notable examples of generosity recorded in scripture are of how those who had the least materially were willing to give sacrificially in spite of their need. If we wait for a windfall to give to a cause, the windfall may never appear and the need will go unmet. If we step out in faith with the little we have, God's ability to provide will be made known even to the extent of our need being met as well. Don't wait. Be joyfully generous.

fields.verse: Therefore we do not lose heart. Though outwardly we are wasting away, yet inwardly we are being renewed day by day. For our light and momentary troubles are achieving for us an eternal glory that far outweighs them all. - 2 Corinthians 4:16‭-‬17 (NIV)
fields.content: As we go through life, we inevitably slow down. There are many reasons (aging, the grind of life, etc.) and eventually we will all stop.
